story:
Short Summary

In existence since 2005, SPARC Theatre is one of
the only ongoing theatre ensembles in Australia comprised of people who live in unstable housing.   

SPARC members are people with an experience of long term mental illness and psychiatric disability.

SPARC Theatre has presented performances in community settings and
professional theatre venues as well as at conferences and seminars.

In the first half of 2014 SPARC have embarked on a creative journey
exploring all things ‘Elvis’.  Elvis connects all the members of  SPARC and Artistic Director, Katie Lockett has supported this topic of creative exploration,  which is appealing and meaningful to all SPARC members, and many music fans within the wider community.

SPARC Theatre hold Elvis’s music and films in extremely high regard, members are filled with tales, stories, controversial opinions and conspiracy theories. Elvis Presley is a subject matter about which many of the members of the ensemble are experts and fanatics.

What We Need & What You Get

We are fundraising to support SPARC Theatre ensemble and staff to travel to The Parkes Elvis Festival in New South Wales, Australia in January 2015.

This Idiegogo campaign is just one way we are raising funds for the trip to Parkes. We are also holding a carnival and applying for philanthropic funding. The more money we raise the more people we can take and make their dream come true.

Parkes Festival organizers are committed to helping SPARC come along to this unique event. We are fund raising early to plan what (if any) additional resources we may need come festival time in early 2015. Parkes Elvis Festival organizers are currently working with the local community to ensure we have the best possible accommodation for the SPARC group (many of whom have high support needs).

It’s been over 36 years since Elvis left the building, yet an expected 18,000+ Elvis fans will gather in the Central NSW town of Parkes, doubling the population, to celebrate Elvis Presley’s birthday in January each year.

The Parkes Elvis Festival features a jam-packed 5-day program of events including a Miss Priscilla Competition, the Elvis Street Parade, Cars of the Era Show, free main stage entertainment, look-a-like contests, Tribute to Elvis Competition, Elvis Gospel Service, Renewal of Wedding Vows, Busking Competition, Poets Breakfast, displays of Elvis memorabilia (including Greg Page’s: The Kings Castle), Wall of Fame, and over 150 unique Elvis-style events.  Check out the website here: Parkes Elvis Festival

The Impact

SPARC Theatre has the capacity to engage and entertain broad audiences, change community attitudes and create debate about the experience of people who live in unstable housing including those living with psychiatric disability and long term mental illness.

SPARC provides ensemble members with professional and well planned cultural
participation opportunities which will directly enhance and inform their
theatre creation.

SPARC supports arts and cultural participation of people who live with mental
illness and psychiatric disability, which may also be socially isolated and
require a complexity of service provision.

SPARC performances Impact community attitudes whilst providing participatory opportunities for individuals from the margins to be actively supported in training,
mentoring and social skill development.

SPARC's opportunity to attend the 2015 Parkes Elvis Festival will be an enormous catalyst for change and growth among the SPARC membership. The festival will provide much needed social connectedness as well as generating opportunities for ongoing cultural exchange between SPARC and the broader community.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute directly to this campaign you may wish to 'like' our Facebook Page or comment on our Youtube channel. Connect to SPARC!

story:
What is Unheard Voices?

Amerian Slavery Project:Unheard Voices brings to life some of the 419 nameless African descended men, women and children slave, free and indentured, who lived, loved, dreamed and toiled in Lower Manhattan during the 17 & 18th centuries.  They were buried in the African Burial Ground and re-discovered only two decades ago.

The American Slavery Project commissioned a collective of 17 writers to research the graves at the African Burial Ground. These graves are identified only by burial number, gender, age and description of the contents.  The ASP Writers Collective has imagined the lives and experiences of these anonymous souls by creating original texts for them.  Actors perform the monologues in theatrical venues and eventually in a site-specific performance at the African Burial Ground itself. May 18th, 2012 we had a sneak peek performance of the collected work at the Malcolm X and Betty Shabazz Center, NYC. 

This Indigogo campaign is to help fund two more performances. October 15th presented by CAP21 Theatre and Oct. 17th presented by the New-York Historical Society. For details on these performances go to: http://www.americanslaveryproject.org

Why it's Important?

Many people don't know there was slavery in colonial New York, how Manhattan was built or that it was the labor of slaves and indentured servants who cleared the island, leveled the hills and erected the great wall that stood where "Wall Street" came to be. Even fewer know about the African Burial Ground.

There are so many wonderful stories to tell and so many generations forgotton. People often think of slavery in monolithic terms; sweeping generalized themes of cotton, chains and beatings. This is reality, but there's more to the story. Individuals inhabited that era. Slavery in New York had its own distinct features. "Unheard Voices" honors the love, laughter, day-to-day struggles, the humanity and endurance of those who lived their ordinary lives in what we look back on as extraordinary times in New York.

American Slavery Project: Unheard Voices is unique. We are putting human faces on those who were not afforded that dignity while alive. We are giving voice to those unheard. We are making colonial New York come alive and including people from that era who have too long been forgotten. 

The Ask

We need to raise at least another $3,000 to continue this good work in 2012. 

All contributions go through our 501(c)3 Fiscal Sponsor: The Vera Institute of Justice

The Breakdown

$3,000 will allow us to produce the final two performances of 2012 including:

• Pay an honorarium to 6 performers and director 

• Pay an honorarium to photographer & videographer

• Cover fees to our fiscal sponsor

• Publicize the performances

• Cover supplies & printing

More will allow us to:

• Commision another class of writers to tackle more burial #'s

• Develop an "indoor" and "outdoor" script that we can tour to schools, community centers, Historical Societies and other Burial Grounds around the nation.

• Edit the monologues for publication.  African American actors for the first time can audition with  17th and 18th Century characters in their own voices.   

Please help us realize our artistic vision while we honor our ancestors!

story:
Our Story

Brian (Perry Gratton) and Morgan (Evan Hall) have become separated following the invasion of the zombie hordes. They find themselves alone, and frantically trying to survive. Brian heads north to seek refuge from the undead in Canada’s cold climes, while Morgan heads south, or so he thinks. As the story unfolds through the notes they write to each other, we see two different people coming to terms with this terrible event in their own desperate way.

We are BrainPile Productions, a new theatre company in Edmonton, Alberta. We came together to produce the world premiere of Notes from a Zombie Apocalypse for the 30th Annual Edmonton International Fringe Festival. The script originated as a collection of poems created by Brian Trimboli and Megan Moriarty, two MFA candidates living on different ends of the United States.


Evan and Perry are students of the Bachelor of Fine Arts Acting program at the University of Alberta in Edmonton, Alberta. The program is a conservatory acting program that accepts only twelve students a year, and spans the course of three years. They had both appeared in other Fringe productions, and sought to become more involved in the process of developing, producing, and showcasing their own work. Through a serendipitous series of events, they were introduced to Notes from a Zombie Apocalypse, and quickly fell in love with the story. The collection was not originally intended to be performed, but the writers were more than happy having the collective adapt and perform the piece. 


Evan and Perry approached their mutual colleague and friend Jamie Cavanagh, an Edmonton based actor/improviser and fellow BFA Acting graduate to direct the work, and Brainpile Productions was born. The Collective then asked Lisa Dalmazzi, American-born and Canadian-trained Designer/ Stage Manager to collaborate on the production and the team was complete. As Director, Jamie's desire was (and remains) to keep the writing as-is, with minimal changes to the script in order to suit the stage, but to keep the letter format of the work intact.


Our Mandate

BrainPile Productions aims to present professional, well-crafted stories, either as new work or as adaptations and interpretations that explore the extremities of the human condition to a diverse audience.


Notes from a Zombie Apocalypse  will premiere in King Edward School (venue #5) at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival, which runs from August 11 - 21 2011.


Show Times:

August 12       2:15 pm – 3:00 pm

August 13       12:15 pm – 1:00 pm

August 15       11:45 pm – 12:30 am

August 16       9:15 pm – 10:00 pm

August 20       6:15 pm – 7:00 pm

August 21       4:00 pm – 4:45 pm


What We Need

Our campaign goal is $3000.00USD. This will cover set, costume, props, publicity (posters, programs, handbills, radio spots, and a media kit) and a very humble living-wage for the members of the company while working on the show in the weeks leading up to the performance. Our goal is to enter the opening performance of Notes from a Zombie Apocalypse with our budget in the black, so that ticket sales go directly to our company and the writers.


Here's our budget break-down:

Entry Fee (Venue Rental, Technicians): $750

Set: $100

Costume: $100

Props: $50

Publicity (Design, Printing, Photography): $250

Director Wage: $350

Actor Wage: $700 ($350 x 2)

Stage Manager/Designer Wage: $350

Initial Reparations to Writers: $350

---

Total: $3000.00


The Impact

BrainPile is a company composed entirely of emerging theatre artists, and as such, we are on the cusp of visibility. We have the opportunity with this show to attract large numbers of people that do not normally see theatre, and who are not familiar with our work. The Edmonton International Fringe Festival is the largest and longest-running festival of its kind in North America, and the 2nd largest in the world (after the Edinburgh Fringe). It includes more than 200 acts.


This presents our company with the unique opportunity to expose our work to unprecedented crowds. We are trained theatre professionals with the skill-sets necessary to succeed in this industry, and the work ethic and will to put in the work needed.


We intend to have a strong media presence (we have paired with a newly-formed PR company called The Gypsy Church), and are committed to presenting a professional-level show that will reflect well on ourselves and our supporters.


Regardless of our financial support, we will be going forward with this project and its presentation. If our financial goals are not met, however, we will be working with a zero-budget, and will have to sacrifice valuable rehearsal and production time to work to pay for the show's expenses as well as our own. The support you give will allow us to commit 100% of our energy and time to this show, which will lead to greater exposure and artistic success. The level of success will dictate our future efforts to work together as a company, and our future work as artists in this community.


2010 Fringe Stats (From Transalta's 2011 Festival at a Glance Media Release):


- Upwards of 160 productions by theatre companies from Vancouver to Halifax, Seattle to Brooklyn, Belfast to Yokohama, and Edmonton to Leduc, played more than 40 stages throughout the city. Additionally, 200 outdoor performances, more than 50 busking acts, KidsFringe activities, vendors and artisans took to Old Strathcona’s streets for 10 days.


- 93,000 patrons enjoyed the Festival's indoor shows, as upwards of 400,000 people partook in performances, food, arts and crafts on-site between August 12 and 22.


- For the first time in the Festival’s history, Frequent Fringer and Double Fringer passes sold out in less than 24 hours. More than 1,000 single tickets sold on day one of sales; in 2009, just less than 650 tickets sold on the Box Office’s opening day.


Other Ways You Can Help

We would like to spread the word about our production to as many different groups of people as possible. Our success with the performance is only one of the possible positive outcomes of this venture with IndieGoGo - there is the opportunity to introduce our company to the wider world, which would be unable to see the production. The possibility of filming our opening performance and presenting it to our larger investors means we can not only reward their financial support, but we can break through to markets otherwise restricted to the theatre industry.

story:
Portland's Excellence in Entertainment Recognition Awards exist to foster Greater Portland's theatrical future by highlighting current theatrical excellence.

Once a year we gather as a professional theater community to celebrate the theater companies and theater artists that through vision and sacrifice commit to Greater Portland's growing cultural vibrancy and vitality, as well as honor outstanding representatives from the most recent theater season by presenting awards.

PEER Awards. You have been honored by a jury of your peers.

This year we've added categories and online nominations!  This campaign's purpose is to pay for the generous space at Lucid Stage, the lovely Awards, and hopefully a semi-open bar.  Please be as generous as you can, and we'll see you at Lucid Stage on September 16th!

Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/PEER-Awards/2106...

Check out the website: http://www.peerawardsportland.com/

NOMINATE: TECH http://www.surveymonkey.com/s/XF6C9BX 

STAGE http://www.surveymonkey.com/s/X3WHKZ3

story:
Roots&Branches Theater is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit art service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Roots&Branches Theater must be made payable to "Fractured Atlas" only, and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

WHAT ROOTS&BRANCHES WILL DO

Roots&Branches Theater (R&B) has brought seniors and young people together through theater for 25 years. In 2016, we’re bringing our unique intergenerational theater performance and workshop program to five senior centers in NYC for free.  We’ll bring five youth groups along, making 5into5 an amazing intergenerational experience.

Our senior center partners include:

  • Allen Street Senior Center (Lower East Side, Manhattan)
  • West 74th Street Senior Center (Upper West Side, Manhattan)
  • Mosholu Montefiore Senior Center (Bronx)

For many of the seniors in these centers, R&B is the only performance they will see all year. For most of them, this is a rare opportunity to connect as a creative human being with young people.

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

We bring theater arts programming to people who can’t afford it. It will cost us $1,200 per location to do that work.  

  • We bring a show of paid actors, a traveling set, costumes, projectors and sound equipment;
  • We provide trained facilitators for our workshops, and class materials; 
  • and we give a final takeaway for participants, in the form of a performance, video and/or booklet.

Roots&Branches Theater receives funding from the NYC Department of Cultural Affairs, the New York State Council on the Arts, and numerous private funders, but we need you to make 5into5 happen.  And to say thanks, we're offering perks that directly stem from our work in these centers:

  • photo albums so you can see your gift at work;
  • digital downloads of performances by R&B;
  • creations by the participants in these workshops. 

WHAT IT MEANS TO PEOPLE

Seniors need to share their stories as part of the natural process of aging.  Young people need to hear those stories, and derive self-worth from working with elders.  Through 5into5, you can help R&B reach further than ever before in its 25 years of serving these needs.

"Besides offering our seniors a rare opportunity to discover and display their own hidden talents, Roots&Branches allows a venue for true interaction among the generations."

Rita S., Senior Center Coordinator

"...a delightful show, fun and insightful for the audience, who are still telling me how much they enjoyed it!"

Susan S., Activities Director

"R&B gave me a renewed 'raison d'etre', and the realization that an active and creative life could continue joyously, even unto my current octogenarian stage."

Yvette P., Senior Performer

PLEASE, TELL EVERYONE

We know we can make this happen, especially if lots of people hear about it!  Please tell your friends and family about our work.  Every little contribution helps, and every time you share this on social networking, it increases our odds of success.  Let’s get 5into5!

"Besides offering our seniors a rare opportunity to discover and display their own hidden talents, Roots&Branches allows a venue for true interaction among the generations."Rita S., Senior Center Coordinator"...a delightful show, fun and insightful for the audience, who are still telling me how much they enjoyed it!"Susan S., Activities Director"R&B gave me a renewed 'raison d'etre', and the realization that an active and creative life could continue joyously, even unto my current octogenarian stage."Yvette P., Senior PerformerPLEASE, TELL EVERYONE
We know we can make this happen, especially if lots of people hear
about it!  Please tell your friends
and family about our work.  Every
little contribution helps, and every time you share this on social networking,
it increases our odds of success. 
Let’s get 5into5!

story:
Our Story

All the Windows On Alcatraz
a play by Rebecca Pouslon
directed by Dina Vovsi
co-produced by Isobel Bruce & Rachel Park

featuring:
Samantha Debicki, Gene Gallerano, Kathleen Littlefield, Zachary Moody, and Tracy Willet

Beth is throwing a party. She has a lot to celebrate--she’s quitting smoking, her friend with benefits is driving her insane, and she’s not particularly good at dealing with the fact that she’s recently tested HIV-positive. While her Fulbright-winning childhood friend arranges veggies in the kitchen, the party is crashed--by an eight year-old wearing stirrup pants and proclaiming her love for LeVar Burton. To these faces from the past, Beth is forced to explain how her present came to be so different from the future she once dreamed of, why she doesn’t have a window seat, and how your brain on drugs is actually entirely different from Rachel Leigh Cook hitting an egg with a frying pan.

“I’m having a really hard time being a grown-up.  I think I’m going to quit.”  -Eight

All the Windows On Alcatraz saw its first incarnation at the University of Michigan in 2009 in Charles “OyamO” Gordon’s Playwriting-into-Production class.  Written by Rebecca Poulson, the script attracted the attention of director Dina Vovsi because of its honest portrayal of young people struggling with coming to terms with a disease that would seemingly never dare to touch them.  Two years and many miles later, the duo of female theatre artists has reunited and is bringing the show its New York premiere at the 2011 NYC International Fringe Festival with Whiskey Rebellion.

The Impact

As emerging female theatre artists in New York City, we are trying to make a presence for ourselves in an industry dominated by male playwrights, directors, and producers.  We feel that the best way to do this is by taking matters into our own hands and self-producing in order to get our work up on stage and seen by the New York theatre community.  FringeNYC is an incredible opportunity for us to do so - but we need your help!  Not only must we shell out thousands for rehearsal space, marketing, and more, we also believe in the significance of paying our artists - our actors, designers, and production team - who often find themselves working for free.

What We Need & What You Get

First and foremost, your support buys us the most difficult commodity to come by in New York- space.  Rehearsal space is an expensive and unavoidable expense.  Your donations also help us build the show from the ground up, literally - the fire escape, the fish tank, the Little Mermaid T-shirt.  They help give us the chance to market this show until our fingers bleed from Facebook-ing and addressing postcards.  And last but not least, your support allows us to offer stipends to our actors and designers who will be putting in hours and hours of their time and hard work into this play.

$10 pays for an hour of rehearsal space
$100 covers preliminary printing costs of scripts for the cast and crew
$1,000 pays three design team members for their creative services

Other Ways You Can Help

It's not only your donations that make a difference, but your support as we set out on this creative endeavor.  Every friend you tell, every e-mail you send, every tweet, status update, text message, “like” on Facebook, and note to a co-worker - every little bit helps us spread the word and garner more support to realize this production of All the Windows On Alcatraz.

story:
Summary

Left of Centre is seeking generous donations for a production of Jon Hartmere and Damon Intrabartolo’s musical, bare. With enough funding from donations, Left of Centre can produce and run bare in the heart of downtown Halifax, at the Neptune Studio Theatre, for the duration of Halifax Pride. Our show will run July 24th - 29th, with performances starting at 8:00pm each night. 

We are lucky to be able to showcase the talent of many young artists in Halifax, including talented graphic designer, Shayla Miller who is designing the promotional material.

 Our cast (alphabetically):

Allie Macdonald – Jason
Anders Balderston  - Priest
Ann Doyle – Claire
Avery Brennan – Alan
Francesca Barnett-Cowan – Rory
Helena Pipe – Sister Chantelle
Justin Moir – Zach
Kaleigh Graham – Tanya
Rebecca Guilderson – Nadia
Ryan Henwood – Peter
Sarah Smith – Kyra
Sophie Boileau – Diane
Stephane Gaudet – Lucas
Stephanie Hood – Ivy
Taylor Long – Matt

Directed by Tina Gallant
Conducted by Brian Cable
Set and Lighting Design by Nathaniel Bassett

WHAT IS BARE

Bare - as defined by Merriam-Webster’s dictionary
a. exposed <laying bare their secrets>
b. destitute <bare of all safeguards>
c. devoid of amplification or adornment <the bare facts>

Featuring a mid-sized cast of 15, bare is a malleable pop-musical that advocates for acceptance and equality using music that expresses the struggles that affect most young adults, such as bullying, suicide and homophobia.  bare is not  limited to the story of two young men's struggle with acceptance, but the variety of social pressures that young adults face as they approach independence.  Issues regarding their sexuality, their vices and the pressure to succeed, mold the relationship of 12 students.  Their young minds are subjected to conflicting messages from their parents, religion, and role models.  bare explores how the reactions of our mentors, and the guidance they provide  to inexperienced youth, can have  a dramatic impact on the outcome of that person’s life.

Left of Centre hopes to reach their audience with a vision that is as touching as the lyrics are themselves. We are working to discover the depth of the text, and show how the subtle change in understanding of ‘one simple word’ can have a profound effect on how we see and relate to others.


What We Need & What You Get

We have broken our production down into a projection of costs:

$ 345.00 Performance-venue rental deposit
$2110.00 Theatrical Rights and script materials
$1500.00 Construction and property materials
$ 600.00 Costuming and draping materials
$ 400.00 Printing and promotional materials
$  45.00 Glow-sticks and strobe-lights
________

 $5000.00

In the column on the right side of this page, you’ll notice:
indication of the reciprocation is noted by the denomination of your donation!

The Impact

The final product will be on the stage at the end of July which will be the result of countless hours of work from the cast, crew and musicians.  Without your support, live theatre plays to an audience of none.  Help us keep one of the most multifaceted and disciplined forms of art alive. You can help by linking this fundraising campaign to your social networking outlets. Facebook, and tweet about us, tell your friends and family about this amazing show, or contact us to offer your support in your own unique way.

Other Ways You Can Help

COMMERCIAL SPONSORSHIP

It is never too late to affiliate yourself with local artists, and affirm your support of our artistic community. Share our pride and people will notice. We invite you to contact us to discuss a commercial or material sponsorship. You can reach us through email at baremusical@gmail.com.

story:
Growing Our Own Gardens

This June, collaborators Matthew Cumbie, Tyler French, Jessica Hale, Sam Horning, and Darryl Pilate travel together to the Boston area to present the next phase of Growing Our Own Gardens. With generous support from a number of individuals and partners, we have been able to cover many of our costs- but we still have a ways to go. We are asking for your support to help us get there! Through this campaign, your contributions will go directly towards paying artists for their time in rehearsal and on stage.

Growing Our Own Gardens is a performance project rooted in queer world-making that positions us to ask what our queer future might look like: what are we moving towards? How do we know when we have arrived? How have we come to be here? The project brings artists, activists, and communities together to travel backwards and forwards in time to look at how we find a place of  belonging and hope outside of what we know. Part performance, part choreographic conversation, we use dance, spoken word, and drag to remind us of the central role our bodies play on this journey and to create opportunities for each of us to find ourselves in these constellations of queerness.  

When & Where

We have been invited to share our work in THE SHOW: A Celebration of Queer Voices, an evening of performances curated by Stephen Ursprung of Reject Dance Theatre. Our creative residency will include two performances at the Dance Complex in Cambridge, MA, and a movement-based class at AS220 in Providence, RI. Join us in class on Monday, June 13th at 6:30pm at AS220 and come to the performances on Friday and Saturday, June 17th & 18th at 8pm at the Dance Complex.

What We Need

Our goal is to raise $5,000 to pay artists' for their time and to cover the costs of food while on our residency. No gift is too small- any amount helps! Through other funding avenues- grants, partnerships, and some personal contributions- we have been able to cover all other costs associated with this residency. Things like travel, housing, and some artists fees. We need to meet this goal, though, if we are to support the time of the people involved! Help us continue to inspire others to understand the work of artists as valuable and necessary and worth compensation by showing your support.

Our Vision

Over the next year we will continue developing our work together and with local communities, and building our collaborative team, through a series of residencies and focused rehearsal periods. We will be working towards a premiere of an evening-length iteration of Growing Our Own Gardens, building on our multi-year process. Our hope is that through these experiences, we can catalyze conversations and action across distances that connect queer communities, that deepen relationships between people and place, and that plant the seeds of intergenerational, collaborative creative strategies for change.

Thank You

We want to thank you, our supporters and our community, for all that you do. We know that we could not do this work without your support, and we acknowledge the responsibilities we have as artists to our communities. Thanks in advance for helping us get there! We look forward to seeing you in the studio, at the shows, or out in the world soon!


Matthew Cumbie Projects is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profits arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Matthew Cumbie Projects must be made payable to "Fractured Atlas" only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Our Story

Almost 2,5 years ago Marc and Kevin got excited about adapting Mark TwainÂ´s "The diaries of Adam and Eve" for a stage musical. WeÂ´ve been working on this since then, did several rewrites, a workshop, readings and now we want to get it out there!

Marc is a brilliant composer who has been a leading-singer in various German musical productions and is now moving to new horizons as a composer and also vocal coach. Kevin who originally also started out as a musical theatre actor has been translating a bunch of famous Broadway shows like Sound of Music or Sister Act for German productions and is now trying to establish himself as an original lyricist and bookwriter.

"The diaries of Adam and Eve" tells the story of Adam and Eve stuck in the conflict of GodÂ´s creation and Darwinism. A very ironic but at the same time dearly honest view on men, women and life. AdamÂ´s struggle to protect Eden from "this new creature with the long hair" ends with one of the greatest lines Twain has written: "Wheresoever she was, there was Eden"  

We are producing it ourselves here in Berlin because we believe that this piece could become something extraordinary and we donÂ´t want to give our little precious to just any theatre in "Posemuckel an der Knatter" ;-)We got producers and theatres interested but we have to put the show on stage to really convince them.

And thatÂ´s what we need you for!

The Impact

So musical theatre in Germany? Yes we are doing musical theatre here but rarely original... rarely comedy... The amazing national German funding system is not so amazing anymore when it comes to so called "entertaining theatre". ItÂ´s hard to get any funding at all no matter the quality of the piece or having "Mark Twain" on your credit list. Even private institutions are rarely interested if itÂ´s not "real art" or big enough to get them a good deal of PR.

We were lucky to have a private institution that was going to support our production but 2 weeks ago we got the message that they were admonished to not give funding to any kind of project that is not "serving the public good/non-profit"

So the money we were expecting is missing now and if we really cut it out of our budget it will be hard to achieve the artistic standard we are aiming for to convince potential producers, especially in terms of set and costumes. It will also push the personal risk of our investment to a level which could make us quite nervous during rehearsal when we would love to focus on the show. So we have two choices: cut set and costumes or spent even more money than we already do which we hardly can...

Or we have a third: Convince you!


What We Need & What You Get

We wonÂ´t make any profit with the Berlin production at all. We are even expecting to face some losses but thatÂ´s fine. ItÂ´s an investment for things to come, so we are kind of the midwife for our own baby!
Please help us to raise the 7500$ we are missing now and support us in producing the show we envisioned. On a budget like that $7500 less really hurt! If you like to know more please send an email to kevin@adam-eva-musical.de and we are happy to give you more details about our budget and where the 7500$ come from.

The opening on 3rd of March at Admiralspalast, Berlin will happen, we canÂ´t go back now. But please help us to get it done as it was originally conceived. In exchange for your contribution, you will receive our special perks listed in the sidebar, as well as our promise to get this heartfelt comedy out to the world. No matter where you are, if in the U.S., Brazil, Japan or Israel, we would love to have the chance to bring it to your country and see international versions!
We have brilliant artistic team, two fantastic actors and chance to create something that might have an important impact on how German musical theatre is perceived. We know itÂ´s just musical theatre but what else is serving "the puclic good" better than an evening of laughter and truthfulness?

Every gift makes a difference. Every gift is highly appreciated. Thank you so much for your support for our piece!

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out and share, share, share!!! The show is written in German, yes, but we believe people will share our spirit or get a feeling on how passionate we are in creating this. The clip you can watch here is from a reading we did of the show. We put an English subtitle in so people will get an idea of what is being said/sung.


You can find us on Facebook, take a look at our website or get your own copy of TwainÂ´s original. ItÂ´s brilliant and if you like that you will love our musical! :-)

story:
"Sacrifice" is about two families, Black and Latino, having to co-exist in a city-style apartment. A father's unwillingness to let go of his past causes major problems for his upcoming future.Things take a turn for the worse, because the parents realize their kids are falling for each other. Racial sparks begin to fly, bringing the drama to a boiling point. During these heated interactions and subtle history lessons; “On where we ALL come from”, the characters are brought to a crossroad, having to Sacrifice something or someone. The natural humor in this play will have you laughing while the dramatic experiences will have you sitting at the edge of your seat waiting to see what happens next.


Written by Marcus B. May and Caleb Nunez

story:
WHO ARE WE AND WHAT ARE WE DOING

Original Practice Shakespeare Festival

OPS Fest is a team of performers united by two things: our love of Shakespeare's plays and our willingness to be part of a dangerous experiment. "Original Practice," or OP is a technique as well as a goal. We strive to recreate the original conditions in which these plays were produced to best illuminate the drama and historic details surrounding the world's greatest English-language writer.

We believe the plays were performed unrehearsed and without a director, which means even with the help of some unique theatrical skills and features, things often go weird, or scary, often funny, and sometimes very, very wrong. And our audiences love it! We're entering our seventh summer and we are so proud and grateful for the Portland summer Shakespeare fans who have been gathering by the hundreds to sit in the hot sun or the rain and mud to heckle us. THANK YOU, PORTLAND!!

Laurelhurst Festival - The OPS Fest Challenge

Each year, as the company has developed, we've added new titles to our summer touring calendar, and each year, we celebrate our new record in a Laurelhurst Festival, mounting each of the shows in our repertoire once, all in one place, one after another. It's the peak of our season, a huge chunk of our summer performances, and it takes place in beautiful and beloved Laurelhurst Park in SE Portland, so it's lots of fun for the neighbors.

Initially we added one new comedy a year, then expanded to one comedy and one tragedy. This summer brings a total of eleven different plays to our season, and Laurelhurst Festival 2015 will span two weekends, Thursday, July 23 - Sunday August 2. (Our poor apprentices even have a three-show-day to look forward to!) We hope to eventually test our mettle, muscle, and memories against the model of the 16th century masters, whose schedule regularly involved producing six different plays in six days, or seasons consisting of 26 performances of 16 different plays, a couple of which would be premieres!

Become a Patron of the New Old Arts

Please support our efforts by making a monetary gift towards our Laurelhurst Festival. As fascinating as it is to run into the same limiting factors as our predecessors - the original Original Practicioners - we are not solely conducting the OP experiment as an exercise. Our performers do step into the shoes of 16th century professionals and walk miles in them all summer long, so we are less excited about exploring how they struggled with their model than where it succeeds in 21st century Portland.

Read further to learn more about supporting our festival, what it means to OPS, and what we have to offer your community. Or, if you're ready to give, check out the sidebar to the right of your screen and find a level of giving that matches your means and your corresponding gift!

THE DEAL

What We Need...

Our shows are always free, so we depend on audience donations to cover costs, plus grants and the support of schools and a few private theatre patrons. The base rate for actors to cast this years Laurelhurst Festival alone will cost approximately $3,000!

We humbly request the support of those in our community with the means to help us raise $3,000 - a substantial portion of our operating budget, symbolic of mounting the Laurelhurst Festival. As catchy as it sounds to ask you to "Pay an actor's salary!" this year, our success in this season's campaign will determine our operating budget for next year's festival. We would love to show you what we can do with a significant increase in production value! But none of our actors will be going hungry this summer.

Of course we don't expect all our supporters to be season sponsors. When you join us in the park, we'll ask you to drop a small contribution into a post-show bucket (our version of passing the hat), and if you are able to give more than spare change or cash on hand, we will gladly accept a check or credit card donation on site. Huge thanks to everyone who has given and continues to give regularly in person. We can't do it without you.

...And What You Get

If you are prepared to make a larger scale donation to our Laurelhurst fest, thank you in advance! And please check out the many awesome and hilarious rewards for giving. Patrons of Shakespeare's company were known to favor individual actors, sometimes directly supporting them with personal tips or gifts, sometimes voting with their wallets in other ways, expanding an actor's wardrobe to help him appear wealthier and more attractive on stage, perhaps in turn helping him win larger, more impressive roles. Although we encourage supporters to give on an organizational level, we've taken some inspiration from the older economic structure in designing your perks...

Sponsor an actor and you have the option to have a creative exchange over a role, perhaps inspiring the kind of character, costume, or behaviors you'll see on stage. Business owner? Running for office? Shakespeare's plays are notoriously referential - his audience was used to hearing jabs at rival playwrights, shout outs to favorite taverns, or send ups of contemporary political figures. Find a level of support that works for you and you could orchestrate a better (not to mention more historically accurate) ad lib than we alone can pull off. (See the full list of perks and levels of giving to the right.)

If we don't make our goal this summer, we may not be able to expand to an eleven-show festival next season, but all proceeds will certainly still go towards then development of the company, primarily paying theatre practicioners to exercise their skills on and off stage.

WHY?

The Impact

OPS Fest has been developing our own version of cue script technique over the past six summers, based on the pragmatics of the contemporary stage. (For example, we now allow women to perform!) Many of our long-time performers have begun to master the tricky combination of subtle text analysis, vocal and physical athleticism, and improvisation skills through a combination of training and some truly rigorous experience, impossible to recreate without a viable company. This invaluable development of the performer is not only a gift to our audiences, but also increases their personal value in other theatre circles and careers.

With the help of Ronni Lacroute and the Willakenzie estate, we've been able to hire professional actors at far more competitive rates and find ourselves a home in the local theatre community, sharing actors with sister companies such as Portland Actors Ensemble, Anon It Moves, Portland Shakespeare Project, Fuse Theatre Ensemble, Post 5 Theatre, and Northwest Classical Theatre, among many others, and participating in the city-wide Complete Works Festival - two years to mount all of Shakespeare's plays and poems in honor of the 450th anniversary of his birth and 400th anniversary of his death. 

The last piece of the puzzle is accessibility. We do our part by keeping costs low so we can expand the reach of our free-of-cost tour into more and diverse neighborhoods. We are able to do this by honing our improvisation skills, trusting our actors, and streamlining production design to match that of The King's Men - an impressively a sustainable model. Relative to the modern tradition of massive set construction and architectural verisimilitude, our universal set is lightweight, compact, and reusable. That and minimal properties are able to meet actors on location in just one pickup truck, so we are able travel all over the greater Portland metro area and beyond.

Now we need you to do your part – assuming our post-show bucket donations stay consistent with previous years, this Indegogo campaign must earn $4,500. That way, we'll be on track for next summer's even larger festival, more and more experienced actors, more extensive training for an ever-growing list of roles, and staffing a few 12-hour production marathons. Not only is it a stunt, but the shows are FUN! Come see for yourself why kids of all ages makes our seasons an integral part of their summer.

HOW?

Risks & Challenges

Shakespeare depicts actors as talented, mentally gymnastic, and hungry.  OPS is proud to focus our annual budget on paying the artists, but 16th century London was a grim period in which to struggle financially, and actors generally did, often oscillating between feast and famine. 400 years later, the state of the arts has evolved, but not been drastically overhauled. Though the theatre is still a hub of cultural life (perhaps most obvious on the summer park tour circuit), live performance competes with countless forms of audio/visual entertainment and other media to bring people together. We have not yet escaped the challenges of arts funding.

OPS Fest also demands a great deal of training and outside preparation from the actor, and for this investment we are dedicated to paying a competitive wage. We offer training in techniques unique even within the Shakespeare community, and qualified performers may play upwards of a dozen roles in one season. Not all performers are prepared to make this kind of commitment to one writer.

We understand that not everyone can support live theatre like Queen Elizabeth. This is one reason that, at least economically, we veer from the 16th century model: to celebrate the quality of living that came with the civil rights movement. YOU, our audience, can afford to support the humane treatment of actors!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Hear the Plays

As one famous title character says, The play's the thing. Monetary contributions help us operate, but our raison d'être is, of course, mounting as many plays as we can squeeze between Midsummer and Labor Day, and as accessibly as possible. It's just not a play without an audience, so check out the touring calendar on our website, http://www.opsfest.org/tour-calendar.html, and share it with your friends!

Share This Campaign!

Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us promote our goal for next season!

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT! WE LOVE YOU!!!

story:
Help Me Create Help Me, Wanda!

Along with four fantastic musicians, I will be debuting a show inspired the music of Wanda Jackson, the preeminent Queen of Rock. Blending storytelling and songs from both the rockabilly and the modern eras, Help Me, Wanda! will let audiences in on a little bit of Wanda's life, a little bit of mine, and a whole lot of great music.

The Lowdown About Me

I've been acting in the DC area since 1999. I hate bragging about myself, but since some of you might not know me, you can find a bit more about me here and here.  You'll see I've been performing rock cabarets with Pinky Swear Productions since 2011. If I had to stop performing today, I can look back without many regrets. I've worked hard, and I've been blessed.

But I've never done something of my own. I knew I wanted to write and perform a solo show, but nothing really inspired me to do so. Then I discovered Wanda Jackson on YouTube. 

That's all it took! Wanda is now my muse. Her life and her music are helping me create a cabaret that shares my love of rock music and my passion for celebrating women in rock.

What I Need

I've got great support from a recently-formed artists collective called DISTRICT MISFITS. They are just as passionate about this project as I am. But "artists collective" is not synonymous with "tons o' cash lying around," so we need some extra assistance. Let me emphasize that I am NOT getting a dime for this.

This is a labor of love for me, but I realize that it's not like that for everyone involved. My biggest priority is paying the band. These guys are working so hard to create that unique, rockabilly sound as well as all of the other crazy musical ideas I'm throwing their way. They are putting in lots of time in rehearsal and time on their own, not to mention performance time. 

Whatever money we make on this campaign, even if we don't make our goal, the first cut will go to the band. We want to pay them at least $1,000 for their time and talents, and if we can, more than that. As someone who knows how hard it is to make a living as an artist, I want to make sure that anyone who is helping me achieve this dream is paid well.

The rest of the funds raised from this campaign will go to production expenses: it's not cheap to rent space, acquire sound equipment, and ensure that the word gets out about the show. Whatever you contribute will go fully into making sure this project comes to life. 

And if I don't raise all of the money I need? Don't worry: this is happening, people! Wanda IS coming!

What I Can I Give? 

I'm not gonna ask you to give without giving a little something in return. The first thing I'll give is a big THANK YOU, but I can offer a bit more. The band and I LOVE to jam, so we'd love to sing you a song or two. We'd also love to meet you at a dress rehearsal! Also there's some merch that's in development that we think you'll enjoy. Not only that, you'd be on the ground floor of a show that has potential to stick around for a while. How cool is that?

Other Ways You Can Help!

I totally get if you can't contribute. Paying for a band for a rock 'n roll cabaret written by a middle-aged, left-handed, Filipina-American woman is not going to be a priority for some folks. But getting the word out will not cost you a dime. Just hit the F, the bird, or the camera--or whatever social media site that floats your boat--and you are instantaneously part of the Help Me, Wanda! tribe.

I can't thank you enough for any dollar amount you can contribute! Please know that the band and I are working our butts off to create a great show for you and we hope to repay in tenfold all the love we get!

story:
The Company

PORTLAND YOUTH BALLET  was founded in August 2007 by Christopher Tabor and Lynn Brennan Tabor who were former dancers and staff with the Cleveland Ballet.  PYB is a pre-professional troupe of young dancers which provides performing opportunities throughout the year including their annual holiday ballet, Winterglow; a Spring Recital; and the August Gala with guest performances from other youth companies in the Oregon/California/Washington areas. 

PYB's goal is to provide a nurturing environment for young artists, to help them not only learn the craft of ballet, but find their own unique form of expression in interesting and challenging choreography. 

Part of PYB’s  mission is to continue to collaborate with other youth companies in Oregon and support each other in an often fragile arts world. In addition to their home season, PYB is delighted to perform yearly in Coos Bay with Ballet Pacific each February, and also to participate in the Northwest Dance Festival in Eugene in April.


What We Need & What You Get

PYB needs $3000 to help create a new snow scene for the 2016 production of Winterglow.  We are hoping to add new costumes and lighting.  We also have the challenge of higher theater rental in downtown Portland.  With its escalating property values, Portland has become the hot destination now, and we’re experiencing incredible growth in the city.  With property having a higher price tag here we have learned that we must now come up with more funds to continue to do what we do.  Our cool snow scene needs to survive the Portland heat wave!

On the right you'll see some amazing thank yous, including limited edition items and creative gift ideas.  Act fast if you see something you or a dancer you know might like, as the campaign will only be live for a short time! 


The Impact

As part of its mission, PYB is committed to presenting socially relevant, family-friendly productions.  In 2012, Portland Youth Ballet presented the original dance-centered musical RECOGNITION, and was nominated for six Portland Area Musical Theater Awards (PAMTAs), winning the award for Best Ensemble, the only Portland dance company to be so honored.

Opportunities for dancers to learn their craft under expert guidance in a nurturing environment are extremely rare - it is a gift and privilege to have such a school in our community.  You can impact current and future dancers and their families by donating today!


Other Ways You Can Help

Let people know about the FUNdraiser!  Invite local  friends and family to the Studio Open House on May 14th for cookies and a view into PYB community.  You can forward this link   https://igg.me/at/pyb   to out-of-town family and friends, and even post it to Facebook with a story about your experience at Portland Youth Ballet - stories build connections, and connections create support!  Thank you in advance for positively impacting the lives of the dancers, staff and families of PYB!

story:
Short Summary
  • Tin Can People are an upcoming theatre & performance company based in Preston developing their performance - Remember Me - to a full hour length show.
  • Tin Can People are campaigning for your support which will fund the creative and marketing development of their debut show Remember Me. Therefore your money will be vital as it will fund the materials needed, enabling them to tour their work on a national circuit.

What we need

  • As a company we're aiming to raise £1000 - This will fund the production of a video trailer meaning we can entice audiences to come and see our show.
  • Your money will fund a showcase event so we can share our work to new audiences - This will mean we can further establish our reputation as a company.
  • If we don't reach our target goal we will still intend to use the raised funding to go towards developing the marketing side of Remember Me.
 The Impact
  • The impact of your money means we are able to further establish our reputation and make our show marketable and presentable to new audiences.
  • Your support to this campaign will mean we are more likely to receive arts funding in the future.
  • In light of recent cuts across the arts early career companies like ourselves are finding ways to creatively and independently raise initial funding to get projects up and running. 
 Risks & Challenges
  • We have platformed our work across the UK at various festivals, events, and received local support from They Eat Culture (non-profit arts and cultural production company based in Preston). However the risk we take is being successful in touring our work on a national circuit. 
  • As a company we have worked hard in developing relevant contacts across the UK and we intend to pursue these for support when contacting programmers/venues to showcase our work. 
 Other Ways You Can Help
  • If you cannot donate money, then you can help us by spreading the word to all you know!
  • Use the IndieGoGo share tools

If we don't reach our target goal we will still intend to use the raised funding to go towards developing the marketing side of Remember Me.     The Impact  The impact of your money means we are able to further establish our reputation and make our show marketable and presentable to new audiences.
Your support to this campaign will mean we are more likely to receive arts funding in the future.
In light of recent cuts across the arts early career companies like ourselves are finding ways to creatively and independently raise initial funding to get projects up and running.     Risks & Challenges
 
We have platformed our work across the UK at various festivals, events, and received local support from They Eat Culture (non-profit arts and cultural production company based in Preston). However the risk we take is being successful in touring our work on a national circuit. 

As a company we have worked hard in developing relevant contacts across the UK and we intend to pursue these for support when contacting programmers/venues to showcase our work.   Other Ways You Can Help
 
If you cannot donate money, then you can help us by spreading the word to all you know! 
Use the IndieGoGo share tools

story:
Our Story

A brand new, original Marx Brothers Play - "Lab Birds" - bringing the familiar and hilarious antics that long-time fans and a new generation will love and cherish. 
Storyline:  Set in the 1930's and accompanied by musical performances and wonderful chaos, Lab Birds takes us to a Laboratory where Groucho "works" alongside his mischievous partners, Chico and Harpo, and an Aviary where a Zoo Keeper and her lover are in dire need of help.  With Margaret Dumont, the traditional 'straight woman', as the Lab's benefactor and a stern, hot tempered lab head doctor, nothing but hilarity will ensue when the Marx Brothers take over.


The Impact

This campaign is to help this play become the best it can be, from bringing in the best possible talent and crew, to promotion, to costuming, minor special effects (vaudeville-style), music, sets, and insurance.  

There have been no new, original full story Marx Brothers plays or movies in decades and we hope, with your help, to make this happen and encourage others to do the same.  The Marx Brothers' unique style of comedy, like Monty Python's and Mel Brooks', made a huge impact on society, influencing many who would become great entertainers, and will continue to do so with this play.

Be a part of a revival and help bring in the new generation to brilliant comedy! By contributing, you become a part of this special and unique opportunity!

On the dark side of the force, if we cannot raise enough money, we will possibly lose good talent and crew who would be otherwise unable to help out without some compensation for their efforts.  Don't let the world lose a marvelous, original production that would help influence new generations of comedians, which, as a result, would give you better entertainment in every form of media.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $12,000 to be able to pay something to the crew who work the lighting every show, construct the stage and move it, work the sound, and to the cast who sing, dance, and explode with comedy and sweat at every rehearsal and show for the audience.  We also need to cover basic costs for costumes, sets, minor special effects (vaudeville-style), theatre usage, promotion materials, and it would be great to have a little extra to cover gas/transportation costs.  We also will be charged between 4-7% on anything we raise between paypal and indiegogo fees, so our campaign amount takes this into account as well.
We have no other funding sources at this time so we're currently relying on Indiegogo (our first time using it), so please give us hope!
If we can't raise enough to meet our entire goal, the money raised will still go toward the production, which will absolutely happen! If the play can't go live on the raised amount by October, then we can keep the most important aspects on tap to do the show at a later time when the rest of the money needed is raised.  If we get even half of what's asked for, we can still do it, but it will make it riskier to do as the main concern is in keeping the hard-to-find cast handling the physically and mentally demanding principle roles of Groucho, Chico, and Harpo.  Finding them is hard enough - keeping them is super important and promise of compensation really helps ensure that.

Perks for contributing to our campaign!  You will have our undying love and access to a wonderful production!  Yes, even if you don't live near Los Angeles, or can't make it to a show, we will be filming it and putting it up online for you to be able to watch.


Other Ways You Can Help

If for some reason, it is impossible for you to contribute monetarily, or in addition to such contribution you wish to help out in other ways, we would totally appreciate you getting the word out in as big a way as you can!  The more people that know about this production the better.  It means that our actors can have a bigger audience, the play has a better chance of touring in more areas, more people will come to indiegogo to make a contribution, and more babies will grow up to be awesome entertainers!  Maybe your babies!  Maybe someone else's and you didn't even have to raise the little ones!
Don't forget about the Share Tools on this project/site to help you get the word out.
Thank you for your help and we hope to have this puppy barking in no time!
~Adrianne


About the Company:

Emernoir Productions, overseeing this endeavor, is a brand new company aimed at providing quality entertainment utilizing various media (film, internet, theatre, and comic books). Adrianne Grady, head of Emernoir Productions and a hardcore Marx Brother's fan, is one of the Creative Directors of Labyrinth Masquerade Ball, Writer and Assistant to the Director on the show "Hurry Up and Wait", Creative Consultant and Technical Advisor on the movies "Role Models" and "Knights of Badassdom" and has produced, written, directed, and acted in numerous plays and live shows. She is also responsible for the design and construction of many creature costumes, period costumes, sets and props for live shows and managed the band Knollwit, also serving as lead singer, songwriter, and composer. 


Production Details:  We're looking for rehearsals to begin in August and the play to run starting late September / early October.  We have already begun looking through casting submissions and will have auditions as soon as all three potential principles have submissions from applicants.  The play will be performed in Los Angeles and we hope to have a tour that will take it beyond.

story:
Short Summary

The Laugh/Riot Performing Arts Company is reaching the end of our first season as Edinboro University's Resident Theatre program, and we're preparing for a bigger and better second season.  We're asking for your help to make sure that our season reaches its full potential.  We have several different projects coming up this year that we're excited for:

  • Our second theatrical season, based around a Theatre of Cruelty theme: Agamemnon 2.0, The Bacchae, No Exit, Jet of Blood, The Collector, and our annual New Works festival.
  • A Northwest Pennsylvania Theatre Festival highlighting the best performances from area high schools, presented at Edinboro University in May 2014.  We will also be recognizing the top performers with either a scholarship or savings bond.
  • An audition workshop that will bring theatre and film directors, as well as summerstock theatres and amusement parks, together to help people learn about the different types of auditions and how to best prepare for them.  People who attend may also be given the ability to audition for some of these places.
  • A biweekly or monthly television program highlighting the performing arts events in Erie and Crawford counties.

We are committed to keeping the arts affordable and available to everyone - our most expensive tickets are only $10. 

By sponsoring our second season, you can help us complete all of these projects and still keep them affordable for everyone.  In addition, you'll be recognized as a proud supporter of a quickly growing community theatre!

 

What We Need & What You Get

Every dollar of your sponsorship will be used for our projects:

Our 6-show season has a budget of $2,500 to cover the cost of rights, scripts, and scene supplies.  This budget is extremely low for such a large season, but we feel that it's enough to provide high-quality productions.  For this campaign, we are looking to raise $1,500; any money past that goal will be used to reach our $2,500 budget.  Should we surpass $2,500, those funds will be split between the show budget and the Theatre Festival awards.

For your sponsorship, you can receive recognition in our programs, advertising for your business or service, and free tickets - which you can use or donate to area high schools!

Should we not reach our goal, the funds will be divided accordingly for the shows in our season.

The Impact

Your help can assist us in creating an even stronger arts community in the area and provide students with the knowledge and ability to keep performing arts a vital part of their lives past high school and college, as well as allow community members to experiment with theatre for the first time:

Every Laugh/Riot show from our first season had at least one actor who had never stepped onstage since high school, if even then.

Our artistic director and several of our Board members have graduate degrees in theatre and/or education.  We have made theatre (and theatre education) a vital part of our lives and offer high-quality productions and actor training during our rehearsal processes.

Our audience has grown for each of our performances, and the critical response to each production has been amazing.  These positives challenge us to make sure that each production is stronger than the last.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute monetarily, you can still be a great help:

  • Get the word out and let people know about this campaign!
  • Post a YouTube or Vimeo video about your experience with Laugh/Riot to let others know what you think about us (please use "Laugh/Riot" as a keyword so we can easily find and share them).

 Thank you for your support!

story:
The Gist

I'm a young actor who is relocating to an internship at The Milwaukee Rep Theater! I got the job, I have housing, I even have enough money to get there. Now the real issue is surviving on $50 a week stipend...  

This internship is a great opportunity for any actor fresh out of school - like myself. I'll be working as an artistic intern for Milwaukee Rep in Wisconsin. Here's a link to the company:

http://www.milwaukeerep.com/index.htm

What's The Deal?

In early August, I fly out to Wisconson to join 13 other talented young actors. The goal of this internship is "to further the development of the next generation of American theater artsits." To do that, I'll be understudying professional actors from across the country as well as filling principal and ensemble roles in their 11 show season. This internship has not only been running for 50 years, but it is also one of the most highly respected programs in its field. However, once August hits I will be getting by on food stamps, which isn't too bad it builds character. But I will not have enough money to even pay my cell phone bill. I'm asking for donations to help me eat, pay bills, and move out of Milwaukee when the internship is over. 

Who Am I?

A classically trained actor out of the University of Houston Professional Actor Training Program. I'm the first in my family to go to college, let alone hold a Master's Degree. Raised in Philadelphia I grew up with a love of improv! I then went right into graduate training. At the University of Houston I became proficient in multiple dialects, was recognized in five different weapons for stage combat, and produced scene work ranging from Tennesse Williams to William Shakespeare. Grad school opened my eyes to how big the world of acting is. Now I plan on exploring and defining where I will work and what kind of work I will be doing in my career. 

 

What the Rep can do

  • diversify my work 
  • showcase my work for Milwaukee and Chicago based companies
  • expand my professional network
  • earn EMC points

here's the link to Milwaukee Rep's intern page:

http://www.milwaukeerep.com/about/internship.htm 

In the world of theater, Milwaukee Rep is high on the food chain. And much like other professions, the best way to secure great work is to work for great companies. The Rep is one of them: check out this write up about Milwaukee and other 'arts' cities here 

http://www.artplaceamerica.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/AMERICAS_TOP_ARTPLACES_2013.pdf

 

What I Need & What You Get

Ok so here's the deal:

I need $2000 to survive my nine months in Milwaukee. This money will be used to pay my cell phone bill, grocery shop, and help me move to Chicago in May. The only thing I can really afford to give those that donate is my thanks. Your support will be forever appreciated. I will send out posts and shout outs to recognize people that are helping me make the next step in my career. To those that contribute larger amounts, I will film a monologue of their choosing and post it to youtube! I'm pretty excited about that perk and hope to recieve some creative suggestions.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? You can still help!

Help me put the word out there by telling friends and/or family about my Survival Fund. Use the share tools on the page to post this campaign to Facebook/Twitter.

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Who are we?

Dirty Laundry is a brand new comedy written by Rachel Hirons (When Women Wee, A Guide To Second Date Sex and Powder Room), directed by Kat Hoult and produced by Joe Brown. The show will run at the prestigious Underbelly venues for three weeks during this year’s Edinburgh Fringe Festival... But we need your help!

What are we doing?

Voyeuring through the dirty laundry of her colourful array of customers, local busy-body Esther becomes accidentally embroiled within the darkest, juiciest scandal her small town has ever known. Disappearances, suspicious characters and inescapable evidence points to one haunting conclusion and proves madness is closer to genius than ever imagined.

Why do we need you?

Any money pledged by you would be used to cover the costs of our set design, set build, accommodation and travel to the festival. Any little helps and to show our gratitude we have included a list of perks so that no donation goes unrewarded.

How else can you help?

Please share this page on Facebook and Twitter to better our chances of reaching our target.

 

 

Thank you for all your support!

Joe x

 

 

@AllDirtyLaundry

facebook.co.uk/dirtylaundryplay

story:
PuppetART in Detroit

We have been an operating puppet theater, studio, and museum for the last 15 years, offering diverse storylines, rooting from cultures all over the world.  Our repertory includes folklore from Russian, West African, Central American, Jewish, Japanese, Native American, and Western European!  However, post-2009 recession we have had trouble budgeting development funding for new productions in today's climate.  BUT we're still here, and we're still committed to Detroit and want to bring you our newest installment, "Mouk's Adventures".

Backstory

"Mouk's Adventures" will be our first show based from Wilhelm Hauff's fairy tale collection from 1826; specifically Der kleine Muck, rooted from Arabic culture.  Through these magical stories we have been inspired to create an adaptation of the tale, to add to our permanent repertory.  "Mouk's Adventures" follows a young boy, in the desert, who has much misfortune, and is teased by his neighbors for having very large feet and an oversized head.  Little Mouk, also known as "mook" or "muck", finds himself looking for happiness and fortune. Through many trials and mishaps on his journey he ultimately finds what he seeks. 

Where we are

As a year-round center for the arts, specifically puppetry, our mission to serve the youth of Detroit has never been greater.  However, we need to remain engaging and fresh to our audience, as well as sensitive to who are audience is.  Keeping this in mind, Metro-Detroit houses the largest population of Arab-Americans in the country and because of this, along with the countless fieldtrips from Dearborn area schools, we have been compelled to include a story relating to Arabic culture to our collection.  

Currently, we are about 30% done with the production of the show.  We have a team of actors rehearsing every week, sketches, audio, masks, small props, and a storyline.  What we need now is the opportunity to bring it to life!  The next steps include the fabricating of full scale puppets, costumes, and stage sets.  With your generosity and support we know that we can do this!!  For as little as $1 you can make this a reality for kids AND adults all over Metro-Detroit! 

For any further questions you may have please do not hesitate to ask!  We are available by email at pr@puppetart.org or by phone at (313) 961-7777. 

Best,

PuppetART Team

story:
UPDATE: even though we've made our campaign goal, we are still shy of our total season budget, which includes our upcoming winter show. The bigger bite we take out of that with this campaign, the closer we are to making this and future projects a reality! Join us in the home stretch!


Who We Are

Anon It Moves was founded by Erica Terpening-Romeo and Caitlin Fisher-Draeger in 2012.  We are a mostly female-lead company focused on combining Shakespeare's rich text with non-verbal storytelling mediums such as shadow play, puppetry, dance, and music.


One Month, One Cast, Two Plays!

Still buzzing from the success of our inaugural season, we are embarking on our most ambitious project yet: Shakespeare's "Hamlet" and Tom Stoppard's "Rosencrantz & Guildenstern Are Dead"--a kind of existential spin-off of Hamlet which follows two minor (but by no means insignificant) characters on a journey into, out of, and through the scenes in Hamlet in which they appear. Both plays will be performed over the course of one month, with the same cast playing the same characters in both plays! 

To tackle this monstrous enterprise, we have joined forces with String House Theatre, another fresh, new Portland Company dedicated to bringing magic to the stage. 

The shows will run from July 24th-August 23rd, on Thursday through Sunday nights and Saturday afternoons. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern will perform Thursday and Saturday evenings, and Hamlet will perform Friday and Sunday evenings, and Saturday afternoons. 

Some Fun Facts: 
-Ours will be Portland's first professional production of "Hamlet" with a woman in the title role. 
-We are flying out renowned L.A. Director, Elizabeth Watt to tame the "Hamlet" beast, and celebrated actress, vocal coach, and co-founder of Naropa University MFA Theatre program, Ethelyn Friend to play Gertude. Elizabeth and Ethie will begin the rehearsal process by leading the cast and company in an intensive two-day voice and movement workshop. 

What We Need 

Our Budget for the joint production of "Hamlet" and "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead" is as follows:

  • Rehearsal space - $1,700
  • Performance space - $4,250
  • Actor Stipends - $5,000
  • Production Staff Stipends - $3,750
  • Construction Materials - $700
  • Publicity - $800
  • Advertising - $2,000

Between large season sponsorships and fundraising events, we have sourced, or are in the process of sourcing, roughly half that, so we are only asking your help with approximately half our season budget: $8,000.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can donate, but your passion for this project can still help make a difference!

  • Share our campaign with friends and family
  • Volunteer to usher, take tickets, or help build scenic or costume elements
story_txt:

The bigger bite we take out of that with this campaign, the closer we are to making this and future projects a reality! story:
Thank you for visiting SOLE Defined's Indiegogo Campaign

SOLE Defined is a new percussive dance show that fuses tap dance, stepping, beat boxing, West African dance and drum all set to a live DJ. SOLE Defined's newest creation, Black Amer I Can, explores a young man's journey to self acceptance and death to the word NO! 

This show is one of a kind- up beat, funky, and full of energy, SOLE Defined: Black Amer I Can brings to life the inner thoughts and emotions of one young man through hot beats and a musicality that can't be matched.

Co-creators Ryan Johnson and Quynn Johnson merge their talents and passion for percussive dance with a theater actor, Grammy Nominated musician, and full cast of percussive performers.

The cast and crew are excited to premier SOLE Defined at the Atlas Performing Arts Center this November 2013 and May 2014. "It feels so amazing to bring SOLE Defined: Black Amer I Can to life. The story line of the production is very dear to us and we believe in the connection it will have to people from all walks of life," says production co-creators.

How can you help?

Your contribution plays a vital role in bringing SOLE Defined to life. Donations will go towards

  • Production and Artist Fees
  • Hiring a Lighting designer
  • Photographer
  • Videographer
  • Administration costs
  • Studio Rental
  • Equipment Rental 
  • and much more!!

Additionally, 10 percent of your donation will be given to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society in an effort to find a cure for blood cancer. This particular cause is very dear to production cast. 

Thank you for your continued support and we look forward to seeing you at the new production SOLE Defined: Black Amer I Can at the Atlas Performing Arts Center on November 15th and 16th at 8pm.

story:
THE HEAD HUNTER is about Casmir, a screenwriter, and his Mafia hitman cousin Salvatore, as they confront the family issues that tore them apart. Casmir has relinquished the rights of his screenplay about his family to a sleazy, scum bag producer. Casmir needs Salvatore to help him get his script back. Actors Studio Member Scott McCord and Finalist Ali Arkane were drawn to this gritty, dark comedy from award-winning playwright and Actors Studio Member Mark Borkowski. They were invited to perform in New York's eco-friendly, socially-conscious, Planet Connections 2018 Theater Festival, and have an opportunity to produce this tremendous play. 

THE HEAD HUNTER debuted Off-off Broadway 14 years ago and has had one other production in 2013 at New York's Producers Club. Elias Stimac of Backstage, wrote "...one of the best plays of 2000 has emerged on the New York theatre scene...Mark Borkowski's 'The Head Hunter' is an intensely inventive and fiercely funny new drama which mixes shades of Shepard and Mamet ...Borkowski fills his play with wicked twists and turns that catch viewers off-guard each step of the way."

This 2018 production of THE HEAD HUNTER, directed by David Zayas Jr., and starring Ali Arkane as Salvatore and Scott McCord as Casmir needs your contribution. As Salvy would say, "Theater is fucking expensive, especially in New York." 

We appreciate your support here. Art is important! If you are not able to contribute financially, you can still help us. Please spread the word by sharing on social media. We wouldn't be able to do this without you, everything helps.
