story:
In just a few days, critically acclaimed Artistic Directors of NobleMotion Dance (Houston, TX) will walk into the studios at USF to restage their masterful work, Spitting Ether on your favorite Moving Current Dancers!!


Spitting Ether: A Reality Bending Dance, is a collaborative work with light designer David J Deveau that integrates projection design into the live performance space. A nightmare with spiritual undertones, Spitting Ether is a haunting work that enters a subconscious mind in transitional phases of life, death, and afterlife. This is the work that Artistic Directors Andy and Dionne Noble will set on Moving Current dancers in December 2014 for its Florida debut in January 2014. This work is a wonderful addition to the Moving Current repertory as it will showcase the strength of our dancers’ artistic integrity and athletic virtuosity. It will also allow our Florida audiences the opportunity to see a dance work that seamlessly crosses the elements of lighting and movement, merging technology and dance in an evocative and innovative way. Spitting Ether blends projection design with dance resulting in several very different effects. One section that Moving Current will perform entitled Lorelei’s Whisper, uses the simplicity of a single projector as a light source in a sea of fog. The effect creates walls of light that the dancers magically pass through, appearing and disappearing like beautiful wraiths. This 32 minute work will create the second half of the evening’s program.  The first half will offer new and restaged work by Moving Current Directors Shelley Bourgeois, Erin Cardinal and Cynthia Hennessy.

NobleMotion Dance
is one of Houston’s hottest up and coming dance companies. Recently they were featured in AAA Texas Journal, a publication of one million, as one of three contemporary dance companies making their mark to help Houston become “The Big Apple of the South.” Currently NMD employs ten dancers of varying styles from culturally diverse backgrounds. The company has a broad repertory and remains focused on creating new work that challenges the status quo of dance. Their dances have steadily grown in thought and execution and are increasingly recognized across the United States including a nod from Dance Magazine as “an A-list company”.

Spitting Ether seamlessly integrates technology with the dance. This type of groundbreaking work has never been presented on the Tampa dance stage. What’s even more exciting is that Andy and Dionne Noble are originally from the Tampa Bay area, both graduating from the University of South Florida in Dance.  This is a wonderful opportunity for the arts community to support a multi-faceted work in modern dance created by artists who were born and raised in their city and have continued to build their successful careers in modern dance!

 

The funds from this campaign will go towards the following:

Choreographers’ artistic fees

Dancer’s artistic fees

Technical crew

Technical stage equipment rental fees

Theater rental


 

This amazing opportunity for Moving Current and the Tampa Bay audiences is so exciting!!  We are so eager to share not only the performance but also the process of how the piece is created. So, during our January rehearsals with Andy and Dionne in the theater, we will offer a free lecture/demonstration, open to the public.  This will provide a wonderful opportunity for EVERYONE interested in the project, to get an inside look at the work and how is came to fruition.

During our performance weekend, we will present a Friday morning performance for homeschooled children which will include a program that talks about dance, technology and the mixing of the two.  For the evening and matinee concerts, artists will join the audience on stage for a question and answer session.  These after performance chats have become one of the best parts of our performance weekend. It allows our audience to ask questions about the work and creates a dialogue about the creation and presentation of modern dance.


If a monetary donation just isn’t in the stars for you, please pass this information on to
anyone you think might be interested.  Your support for this wonderful work of art will be gratefully appreciated!  And don’t forget to get your tickets and come to the theater January 17-19 to see Spitting Ether!!

All photos by Lynn Lane

story:
What is Actionplay?

Actionplay is an NYC-based 501(c)(3) programming, outreach, and education organization dedicated to providing people  on the autism spectrum and related conditions equal access to education, arts, and culture. Actionplay is dedicated to improving the lives of individuals on the autism spectrum, their families, and the community at large.

We've had a FANTASTIC YEAR! Our Actionplay Chorus (comprised of teens in our AIMS program) was featured singing "Yoda" with Weird Al Yankovic and Jodi DiPiazza on the 2015 Comedy Central's "Night of Too Many Stars" Event.  Actionplay's programs were also featured with the Tony Award-winning Curious Incident of the Dog in the Nighttime in American Theatre Magazine. 


What We Need

We are raising funds in order to sustain and grow our current programs:

  • We want to expand our AIMS Workshop to 1-2 more locations, serving over 50 youth on the autism spectrum. AIMS is an inclusive improvisational music, art, and performance workshop for children, teens, and adults on the autism spectrum and related conditions that creates original pieces written and performed about the unique interests and passions of our performers in an inclusive space. The goal of this program is to encourage greater confidence and communication skills, social skills, and the awesome experience of a performance on an inclusive stage! 

Cast and crew of Revenge of the Godz, the newest show created by the AIMS program teens. 

We are excited to introduce a BRAND NEW program, DOCUTISM

  • We want to introduce DOCUTISM, an out-of-school documentary film workshop for teens and adults on the autism spectrum. Students on the autism spectrum will learn filmmaking techniques, receive professional filmmaking training, and create and edit short documentary films about their own experience of autism that will be featured on the Docutism website, YouTube channel, and film festival to educate the community-at-large about autism from the autistic perspective. 
We are going to record a GREATEST HITS album
  • We want to create an album that will feature the best songs from our shows in the last five years: including the classic hits "New York City Overload", "Intergalactic Crisis Center",  and "This Show Needs a Ballad". 

What You'll Get Back 

  • Our appreciation for helping us to sustain and grow our programs, and create the GREATEST of greatest hits albums ever featuring students on the autism spectrum!
  • Check out all of the awesome rewards that are available! Each perk is named after characters and settings from the past five AIMS workshops shows.
  • Rewards include: our greatest hits album, a DVD of our most recent show Revenge of the Godz, tickets to our Holiday Fundraiser, and songs written especially for YOU by our very own Actionplay teens!

story:
Hello!

My name is Becky Namgauds, I'm a dancer and choreographer based between London and Birmingham, creating dance work which explores the female experience and pushes boundaries between art forms and movement disciplines.

I am crowdfunding to raise £1500 for a project my new project, Rodadoras.

Rodadoras is a strong, physical and female driven work, responding to challenging themes of femicide and eco-feminism, specific cases like Los Feminicidios where women’s bodies were found in rivers and wastelands and the affects globally. Connecting the female form and the earth.

This is a fresh, exciting work; current in content and theme, the piece explores a specific and unique movement language. Drawing on contemporary dance and Capoeira a highly physical and visually commanding aesthetic is created, alongside a rich rhythmical sound score. The soil creates an immersive texture and visceral quality to the work, and is enhanced by performing outdoors. The subtleties that nature allows, when the wind blows the dancers hair or a change of light, all cultivates a rich atmosphere and surreal imagery. 

This will be my first independent creation where I will have the time, space and the support Ineed to create the vision. I have been researching and developing ideas for this work for the last two years, gathering a creative team, supporters and partners, and now more than ever feel ready to create the vision. The piece is being created over 3 weeks with 3 fantastic dance artists in Birmingham with performances already booked during spring and summer in Edinburgh, London, Birmingham and the Netherlands. With more to come!

Rodadoras is being produced by Amy Sheppard, a freelance dance artist and producer who brings over 6 years’ experience across the dance, theatre and charity sectors. She gained excellent skills in producing, project management and coordination and artist management through her positions at IdeasTap and East London Dance. She is currently working in a freelance capacity as a dance artist and producer with the Royal Opera House, Royal Academy of Dance, Jeanefer Jean-Charles and ShepsDance. Together we have developed a wonderful partnership and with her support we secured funding from the Arts Council as well as some fantastic programming dates. 

Any contributions will greatly help us to achieve the best version of this show possible. With the money, we will be able to produce a show of the highest quality.

We are aiming to raise £1500. This is less than 5% of our total budget. The rest of our costs are covered by funding bodies, partners and money raised by myself through teaching workshops. Though 5% doesn’t sound like much, £1500 is still a lot of money to raise but will help us to create Rodadoras the way we envision it. We will ensure we give back as much as we can through performances in the future once the show is created.

This money is going directly to the purchasing and construction of the set, costumes, and a videographer to film the work. As an artist, individual and company who cares about the environment and local community, all the products we buy will be from small businesses and independent creators. We do our best to be as green as possible when creating work.

These parts come together to create a specific aesthetic and value. We hope you will want to invest in this work the way we invest in people. As an outdoor piece the festivals and performances we will perform at will be mostly unticketed and free, so any money invested in Rodadoras will go back into the community through our performances. We want to share the work with you!

-£500 will be spent on the set which includes 500 litres of soil, tarpaulin covers and the materials and labour to create a wooden frame which will act as a flower box to contain the soil.

-£200 will be spent on costume for the 3 dancers, these will be sourced from ethical and ecological materials and sustainable clothes makers.

-£600 will be spent on a film of the show. An independent professional film maker and photographer who will film and edit a performance and new images for us to easily market the work into the future.

-£200 will be spent on the design for new marketing materials and online media.

Creating a set and costumes which are durable and sustainable means we will be able to use them for longer and avoid costs to repurchase or fix any damages. Investing in quality materials will support the long term of this work and insure we can reach more people with more performances. The impact of your contributions will also allow us to ensure we can pay the dancers, collaborators and organisers in line with industry standards and the fees they deserve.

I am passionate about making dance for the outdoors because it creates visually exciting work and immerse the performers and audiences in their surroundings. This is magical and unique to each performance and very different to theatre based work. It also allows us to perform to many people especially those who may not have access to dance theatre.

Making and performing outdoor work is very rewarding and brings the art form to various communities because it's free and accessible. Therefore, we don't take any ticket sales and it makes putting work on very challenging so any help you can give, even £1 will really help! 

Even £5 goes such a long way, but if you are unable to donate, that's ok! We encourage you to come see our production live. For more info contact info@beckynamgauds.com or follow us on facebook, instagram or twitter.

If you would like to support our campaign but are unable to donate then you can still help us by sharing the campaign via social media, email or word of mouth! Spreading the word and sharing our project with your friends will help us a lot.

Rodadoras is supported by Arts Council England, DanceXchange Choreography Award, East London Dance, Hofesh Shechter and University of Wolverhampton. We need a further £1500 which will contribute towards the production if the work.

-£200 will be spent on costume for the 3 dancers, these will be sourced from ethical and ecological materials and sustainable clothes makers.
-£600 will be spent on a film of the show. An independent professional film maker and photographer who will film and edit a performance and new images for us to easily market the work into the future.
-£200 will be spent on the design for new marketing materials and online media.
Creating a set and costumes which are durable and sustainable means we will be able to use them for longer and avoid costs to repurchase or fix any damages. Investing in quality materials will support the long term of this work and insure we can reach more people with more performances. The impact of your contributions will also allow us to ensure we can pay the dancers, collaborators and organisers in line with industry standards and the fees they deserve.
I am passionate about making dance for the outdoors because it creates visually exciting work and immerse the performers and audiences in their surroundings. This is magical and unique to each performance and very different to theatre based work. It also allows us to perform to many people especially those who may not have access to dance theatre.
Making and performing outdoor work is very rewarding and brings the art form to various communities because it's free and accessible. Therefore, we don't take any ticket sales and it makes putting work on very challenging so any help you can give, even £1 will really help! 
Even £5 goes such a long way, but if you are unable to donate, that's ok! We encourage you to come see our production live. For more info contact info@beckynamgauds.com or follow us on facebook, instagram or twitter.
If you would like to support our campaign but are unable to donate then you can still help us by sharing the campaign via social media, email or word of mouth! Spreading the word and sharing our project with your friends will help us a lot.
Rodadoras is supported by Arts Council England, DanceXchange Choreography Award, East London Dance, Hofesh Shechter and University of Wolverhampton. We need a further £1500 which will contribute towards the production if the work.

story:
Scribblin' at the Automat

In the spring of 1955 two high school friends meet at and Automat (a streamlined eatery frequented by many in its day) on 42nd street in New York to catch up on ole times. When the friends in question are James Baldwin and Richard Avedon one would want to hear what they might have to say. America in the mid 50’s the politics; McCarthyism, Civil rights and existing in a post war nuclear age. The culture of Americana; striving for the perfect family. Music; jazz has gone mainstream but everything has taken a back seat to Rock and Roll. The arts, television and film. They have more than enough to chat about.

Scribblin’ at the Automat a fictional account based on dynamic careers of these two icons in their respective fields’. At this critical juncture in their careers, the success of Go Tell it on the Mountain, James shouldering the burden of the black writer, anxious as to how his next work will be received by the literary world and the public at large. Avedon already successful as a photographer and editor for Harper’s Bazaar, during this conversation he gains some insight on the perception of celebrity from James point of view.

Midtown International Theatre Festival

Midtown International Theatre Festival (MITF) celebrates the diversity of theatre in New York City and abroad. MITF welcomes theatrical storytelling across a broad spectrum of genres, forms, identity, cultures and appetites. MITF seeks to nurture these new ideas, perspectives, and stories on its stages. with an eye on set guiding these productions toward future sucess and longevity. The festival represents a fantastic, often paradoxial, adventurous and intriguing cross-section of the theatre community. The MITF proudly hosts production companies from across the country, and around the globe, uniting talent in one of the biggest theatre capitals in the world.

How You Can Help

We need to raise $12,000 to participate under a showcase code in the Midtwon International Theatre Festival. This money will pay for transportation, set and materials to build, costumes, props, designer salaries, audience development, mentors, press rep, marketing team as well as paying our actors who will be taking time off from their day jobs to travel and perform. Yes, you guess pretty much everything you need to produce a show in the festival.

The Impact

African Arts Theatrical Productions produce plays that explore and open dialogue that analyze the political, social, cultural and historical issues that are part of the African Diaspora. As a part of that goal we highlight both unknown and established playwrights of color whose works are uncovered gems being introduced to the stage. 

We are excited to be part of the development and workshop process of Scribblin' at the Automat and honored that Arthvr Alleyne (playwright) has chose to grow with AATP.  The audiences will benefit from this amazing production.  Scribblin' at the Automat will reach the hearts of those who remember the automat and those who endeer James Baldwin's work to those who can still see Richard Avedon's photography.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help us out with a gift of money, please consider helping us out by spreading the word.  Let your friends and family know about our campaign and help us reach our goal!

story:
May 25th-June 10th. Details and tickets available at: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2936734

 

Short Summary

"__________", An Opera  is an invitation inside the brain of a writer while she's in the process of writing an opera. We follow the writer and her characters--a wooden egg, a grand lady in 1922 Greenwich Village and her motherless granddaughter, a suicidal pirate, a black leather armchair, and the brain of Bertolt Brecht--as they each try to pursue or avoid the truth.  

A year ago, Ethelyn Friend attended a three-day silent writing retreat led by Playwright Erik Ehn. Out of that silence and space, to her great surprise, emerged the first draft of a very loud and crowded story. At the end of those three days, Ethelyn was certain of two things: this story had to be told as an opera, and the opera's music had to be improvised. She partnered with long-time colleague and collaborator Gary Grundei and assembled an ensemble of performers from all over the country. We started training right away. Our vision included working in a "retreat" atmosphere and going further with the integration of extended vocal work with somatic training and Viewpoints work, based on the innovations of Naropa's MFA Contemporary Performance Program. So we brought Erika Berland and Wendell Beavers on board as consultants.

What sets this opera apart: 

  • improvisation: While the libretto--the text of the opera--is memorized, the music is improvised live each night. We have spent the last year training together so that we can achieve a level of quality and precision even as we improvise on the spot! 
  • audience participation: Because the opera takes place inside the brain of the writer, and the audience is in there with us, they play a role in steering the course of the opera as well. The audience has the power to, among other things, title the opera, pause the opera, freeze and focus on just one character....and more!
  • "home" viewing: The opera is performed inside a small, Victorian house, with only fourteen audience seats each night, creating an uniquely intimate and immersive audience experience.  

What We Need 

This has never been done before, and we need your help to pull it off. Your contribution allows us to: 

  • Hire designers and consultants: Fitting a full-scale, improvisational opera and an audience inside an actual person's actual house is complicated, and we want to make sure that nothing is lost and everything gained in translation. This means enhancing the audience experience with costumes, lights and seating tailored to this unique and intimate setting, without losing any theatre magic. 
  • Compensate our performers for a full run: compensating our performers for this challenging task is an essential value some of whom are travelling across the country to work on this project. 
  • Market and promote the opera: For the last year we have been crafting the world of the opera mostly in isolation, with a few invited audience members to test the material. Now, it's time to share it more widely, and of course that comes with costs. 
  • Keep ticket prices affordable: with our limits for audience size, we feel it's important to keep ticket prices affordable, offering group rates as well as a reasonable general admission price

The Implications

A new kind of performance: It is not hyperbole to say this has never been done before. There is no precedent for an opera with a complex, memorized libretto and entirely improvised music, let alone one set in a house, let alone one in which the audience is invited to interact with the world of the opera. The implications, not just for the future of this piece but for the future of an entirely new way of training and performing, are limitless. 

Healing through art: This is, more than anything, a story about trauma and recovery. What we've found even in our earliest stages of sharing this opera with audiences, is that the impact of the story is magnified by intimacy of the space and the power of improvisation. Here are some things we heard from audience members in our work-in-progress showings: 

" the journey was very cathartic and healing - if we don't debride wounds, they won't heal. I didn't feel at all like I was reliving my own trauma, I wasn't at all triggered, yet I've known trauma and therefore was able to connect deeply and compassionately with the characters."

 "It was a physical experience. While the audience is seated at the edges of the space, it also feels as if we’re sharing the space. The house setting feels very important in that we’re occupying the social space of the family."

"intriguing, beautiful, horrifying"

"It felt like we transported to an entirely other reality, watched the opera in this alternate universe, and then returned safely back to earth at the end. It also felt hot, and raw, authentic, seeping with deep soul work and presence."

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Spread the word! 
  • Share our campaign on Facebook! 
  • COME SEE THE OPERA:

May 25th-June 10th. Details and tickets available at: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2936734

Who "we" are: 

Ethelyn Friend, vocalist/actor/writer is a teaching member of the Roy Hart Theatre of France, and a founding faculty member of Naropa University’s MFA in Contemporary Performance. 

Gary Grundei, a composer, pianist and teacher whose music has been heard at national venues including the Kennedy Center, Denver Center Theatre Company, and New York Stage and Film. 

Erica Terpening-Romeo, a director, actor and writer who founded Anon It Moves, an experimental Shakespeare company in Portland, Oregon.

Erika Berland designed innovative movement curriculum for Naropa's MFA program based on Body-Mind Centering and experiential anatomy and is the author of Sitting The Physical Art of Meditation.

Wendell Beavers, dancer, choreographer, an early director of NYU's Experimental Theatre Wing, founded Naropa MFA Contemporary Performance Program and is one of three major developers of The Viewpoints.

Allison Caw, a performing artist, contemplative educator, writer and activist who facilitates expressive earth connection workshops in the outdoors. 

Jessica Cerullo, a performer, writer, & producer of work that is socially and civically engaged, a professor of Theater at Whitman College, and leader (with Joanna Merlin)of MICHA, the Michael Chekhov Association.

Barrett Ogden, a certified Feldenkreis teacher who performs internationally in film, theatre, & TV including haunting English castle ruins with Shakespeare, & playing bass for a psychedelic post-punk space-glam band.

Special thanks to Siena Pinney for help with video editing. Check out her beautiful work at www.sienapinneyphotography.com

story:
Who We Are

We are playwright/designer/metalsmith Eva Adderley and media artist/director/educator Jordan Lee Thompson, longtime friends and brand new artistic collaborators. Back in May, we presented We Had A Second Bathroom as a work in progress as part of Savage Umbrella’s Night of New Works. We developed the script with the help of an amazing ensemble of actors (Joni Griffith, Helena Mueller, Nayely Becerra, Kit Bix, and Meagan Kedrowski). We are thrilled to say to two members of our original ensemble, Helena Muellar and Nayely Becerra, will be joining us for the full production. We are equally excited about the new faces we have in our cast: Lillian Noonan, Natalie Turner, Renee Werbowski, Rob Ward, Andrew Lindvall, and Juliette Aaslestad. Also on board are Ben Harvey as lighting designer and Steve Looten as fight choreographer. 

What's This about a Bathroom?

Based (very loosely) on true events, We Had A Second Bathroom is about a young woman (Lea) who returns to her childhood home where she rediscovers a room that her family had forgotten about for years. Opening the door leads Lea down a rabbit hole of self-discovery as strange things start to emerge from the forgotten room, including memories and fantastical characters from the Queendom of Zor, an imaginary realm that Lea and her best friend created as children.

In the last year as We Had A Second Bathroom has been developed, we have been forced to ponder notions of collective forgetting and the falsehoods we share, in both the larger culture and the intimately personal. This play is imaginative, surprising, and intimate, and the incorporation of improv means it will change every night. The audiences of each performance will share a unique experience, and we hope that you will join us for one of them.

Why We Need Funding

We're so excited to bring this show to the stage. But to make it as phenomenal as it can be, we need your help! These are some of our biggest costs:

REHEARSAL SPACE

The Phoenix covers a lot of our rehearsal space for free, but we'll also have to rent space. We think we can keep this cost down to $100.

COSTUMES / SETS / PROPS

We want to create a beautiful show, full of puppets, magical staffs, spectacular gowns, glowing doors, obscure Canadian sports equipment, and even a gargoyle. In order to bring the world of We Had A Second Bathroom to life, we will need $600 to buy building materials, set pieces, puppet making supplies, costume pieces, and props.

ARTIST STIPENDS

Lastly, as artists ourselves, we know how important it is to get paid for the work you do, and we believe that our artists deserve to be paid fairly. Help us make that a reality for these hard working people!

What You Get

We know that the perks aren't why you're investing in us, but we're excited to offer some great tangible thank-yous for our supporters!

  • A loving thank-you with your name in our program
  • Signed, artist-designed 18" x 24" poster
  • Finger puppets of each of Lea's imaginary childhood friends
  • Limited Edition Print of the Show (only 10 available)
  • Invitation to meet with playwright Eva Adderley and director Jordan Lee Thompson over coffee/tea

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to support us in other ways?

  • Most importantly, come to the show!
  • Bring your friends to the show!
  • Share our campaign with your friends and family (there are conveniently placed buttons for this on the top of the page) and convince them that they want to invest in us as well!

Thank you! We couldn't make this happen without your support.

story:
UPDATE 9/21

AmericanJustice is featured as one of 6 "BADASS" Activist Projects to WATCH! 

http://www.alternet.org/beyond-election-six-bad...

HOP ABOARD THIS MOVING TRAIN AND DONATE NOW!

UPDATE 9/13

TODAY 1000s of ppl are blowing whistles against the NYPD's racist policies including stop and frisk and harassing those who photograph police brutality. I will donate 20% of all proceeds raised TODAY ----->http://www.indiegogo.com/searchingforaj?a=1029688 to the STOP STOP AND FRISK MOVEMENT. #ajmia (american justice MISSING in action)

 

UPDATE 9/12

TODAY is my mother's BDAY!!!! Won't you join me? In honor of my mommy Yvonne, I'm donating 20% of all $$$ raised TODAY to http://www.womenarts.org/ to support women artists and voices!

And now - What's this crazy IDEA of mine anyway??????????????

I am searching for American Justice. Children in bad schools are searching. College students drowning in debt are searching. Overqualified yet under/unemployed are searching.

We are all $earching for American Justice.

"I think the first duty of society is justice." ~Alexander Hamilton.

I’m an educator, actress, writer and comedian. I am still searching for justice in America.

$earching for American Justice: The Pursuit of Happiness is an interactive satire inspired by my exploration of our Bill of Rights as a history teacher. My innocent students stopped by the police without a warrant are searching for American Justice. My summer school students expected to learn in classrooms without AC are searching for American Justice. My students working hard to achieve the American Dream yet drowning in college debt and no job prospects, are searching for American Justice.

If you were able to meet AmericanJustice, what would you say? 

As election2012 gets closer, $earching for American Justice: The Pursuit of Happiness explores our American Dreams and Nightmares as we pursue happiness. In America, despite 16 million children languishing in poverty, unemployment still hovering at 10% and record levels of homelessness, increasing numbers of reality tv shows, magazines and websites are dedicated to 24 hour celebrity gossip and some news outlets pretend to be fair and ballanced. 

#reality

Hence $earching for American Justice: The Pursuit of Happiness, stars a legally blonde and legally blind socialite named AmericanJustice who loves being loud and right at the same time. AJ is preoccupied with red carpet appearances as she strives to elevate herself from d-list to A-list celebrity status. Her patriotic bling symbolizes her love for current policies that benefit the rich. Will justice see the light of day in America?

Tell AJ your AmericanDreams.

$earching for American Justice: The Pursuit of Happiness is inspired by various movements to gain justice throughout history. From The American Revolution to Occupy Wall Street. 

Thomas Jefferson asked-

What country can preserve it's liberties if their rulers are not warned from time to time that their people preserve the spirit of resistance? 

What We Need & What You Get

Your contributions will help sustain this marathon performance of 10 shows in the streets for the Art in Odd Places Festival during a pivotal time in history. Let’s call attention to the issues that matter and focus on solutions to our domestic and global problems instead of celebrities and other false pursuits of happiness. This show is ideal for all ages and will have an educational focus due to my teaching and policy experience. 

Your support will help secure.....

  • Rehearsal space
  • Props and costumes
  • Pamphlets for the audience
  • Signs and Missing Persons posters
  • Video, photography and editing
  • $$$ for the performers
  • food and refreshments so we don't DIE while we feed your soul
  • a projector and generator to project questions and statistics about Justice on buildings
  • transportation and storage of props
  • Public Relations
  • Books, magazines, newspaper for research- now even the NYT charges a fee per month:(
  • website design (my sites NEEDS some help lol)
  • bailout fund in case I get arrested

Check out our awesome array of liberating awards including the BlondeBombshell, Laptop/Rooftop party, and more for your contributions! 

Other Ways You Can Help

PLEASE PROMOTE THIS PROJECT 

  • Social media and websites

    http://www.facebook.com/pages/American-Justice-AJ/220902771339041

    https://twitter.com/SearchingForAJ

    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XRSKOd01IH0&feature=relmfu

    http://pinterest.com/americanjustice/

    http://www.searchingforaj.com/

Thanks again! Your support will go along way to raise awareness and advocate for a better, brighter future.
story_txt:
UPDATE 9/21
AmericanJustice is featured as one of 6 "BADASS" Activist Projects to WATCH! 
http://www.alternet.org/beyond-election-six-bad...
HOP ABOARD THIS MOVING TRAIN AND DONATE NOW!
UPDATE 9/13
TODAY 1000s of ppl are blowing whistles against the NYPD's racist policies including stop and frisk and harassing those who photograph police brutality. I will donate 20% of all proceeds raised TODAY ----->http://www.indiegogo.com/searchingforaj?a=1029688 to the STOP STOP AND FRISK MOVEMENT. #ajmia (american justice MISSING in action)
 
UPDATE 9/12
TODAY is my mother's BDAY!!!! Won't you join me? In honor of my mommy Yvonne, I'm donating 20% of all $$$ raised TODAY to http://www.womenarts.org/ to support women artists and voices!
And now - What's this crazy IDEA of mine anyway??????????????
I am searching for American Justice. Children in bad schools are searching. College students drowning in debt are searching. Overqualified yet under/unemployed are searching.
We are all $earching for American Justice.
"I think the first duty of society is justice." ~Alexander Hamilton.
I’m an educator, actress, writer and comedian. I am still searching for justice in America.
$earching for American Justice: The Pursuit of Happiness is an interactive satire inspired by my exploration of our Bill of Rights as a history teacher. My innocent students stopped by the police without a warrant are searching for American Justice. My summer school students expected to learn in classrooms without AC are searching for American Justice. My students working hard to achieve the American Dream yet drowning in college debt and no job prospects, are searching for American Justice.
If you were able to meet AmericanJustice, what would you say? 
As election2012 gets closer, $earching for American Justice: The Pursuit of Happiness explores our American Dreams and Nightmares as we pursue happiness. In America, despite 16 million children languishing in poverty, unemployment still hovering at 10% and record levels of homelessness, increasing numbers of reality tv shows, magazines and websites are dedicated to 24 hour celebrity gossip and some news outlets pretend to be fair and ballanced. 
#reality
Hence $earching for American Justice: The Pursuit of Happiness, stars a legally blonde and legally blind socialite named AmericanJustice who loves being loud and right at the same time. AJ is preoccupied with red carpet appearances as she strives to elevate herself from d-list to A-list celebrity status. Her patriotic bling symbolizes her love for current policies that benefit the rich. Will justice see the light of day in America?
Tell AJ your AmericanDreams.
$earching for American Justice: The Pursuit of Happiness is inspired by various movements to gain justice throughout history. From The American Revolution to Occupy Wall Street. 
Thomas Jefferson asked-
What country can preserve it's liberties if their rulers are not warned from time to time that their people preserve the spirit of resistance? 
What We Need & What You Get
Your contributions will help sustain this marathon performance of 10 shows in the streets for the Art in Odd Places Festival during a pivotal time in history. Let’s call attention to the issues that matter and focus on solutions to our domestic and global problems instead of celebrities and other false pursuits of happiness. This show is ideal for all ages and will have an educational focus due to my teaching and policy experience. 
Your support will help secure.....

Rehearsal space
Props and costumes
Pamphlets for the audience
Signs and Missing Persons posters
Video, photography and editing
$$$ for the performers
food and refreshments so we don't DIE while we feed your soul
a projector and generator to project questions and statistics about Justice on buildings
transportation and storage of props
Public Relations
Books, magazines, newspaper for research- now even the NYT charges a fee per month:(
website design (my sites NEEDS some help lol)
bailout fund in case I get arrested



Check out our awesome array of liberating awards including the BlondeBombshell, Laptop/Rooftop party, and more for your contributions! 
Other Ways You Can Help
PLEASE PROMOTE THIS PROJECT 


Social media and websites
http://www.facebook.com/pages/American-Justice-AJ/220902771339041
https://twitter.com/SearchingForAJ
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XRSKOd01IH0&feature=relmfu
http://pinterest.com/americanjustice/
http://www.searchingforaj.com/



Thanks again! Your support will go along way to raise awareness and advocate for a better, brighter future.

story:
Who We Are:

Heritage High School Rising Stars is the theatre group at Heritage High School, a public high school near San Francisco, which has been creating great high school theatre for 7 years.  Each year we produce a fall play and a spring musical.  Last year we drew record-breaking crowds for our productions of The Grapes of Wrath and Hairspray.  We received nominations in 14 of 18 categories for San Jose's Stage Top Honors awards and won 5 awards, more than any school entered in last year's competition.
We are a self-supporting program.  All money we use to fund the productions are from ticket sales.  No funding is received from the district. We are a 501(c)3 non profit organization.

What We Need:

The Queen Musical, We Will Rock You has never been seen on a high school stage in the US.  Heritage High School has been selected to be the first and only high school in the United States to premiere Queen's incredible rock musical, We Will Rock You, for 2013.   This is a huge  honor.  

In order to bring this musical to our stage in the manner in which is was written, and to create the exciting rock-concert quality appropriate for this musical, we need to purchase intelligent lighting and special effects lighting for our show.

With your contributions we will be able to show our devoted donors, audiences, and Queen's Management Team our appreciation for the honor of bringing this musical to a US high school stage.  Our reputations as performers and Americans are on the line!  To be able to actually perform this show is a dream and and opportunity of a lifetime, not to mention a chance to expand our range as actors.

So, are you in the mood to help some young aspiring actors?  Will you rock us so we can Rock You?

Where's All This Money Going?

Every cent of that $4000 will be going to purchasing the lights needed for this production. We have traditional stage lighting ( fresnels, pars, spots) but to do We Will Rock You right, we need intelligent lighting and assorted laser lights and a hazer to create the appropriate mood and style for the show.

In the unfortunate event that we don't reach our goal in time this campaign will still go towards our lighting needs.  It may not be the special effects lights we need but we will still use every dime on our lighting needs.

The Impact

Having these types of lights and special effects make the show come alive, no doubt, however, these fixtures are different from what we currently have and to give our students the opportunity to install, design, and program this sort of equipment at the high school level enhances their skill sets.  Because we receive no money from the school or the district toward our productions, we must earn all monies above and beyond production costs each year to purchase these items, which are very expensive.  We need at least 5 intelligent light fixtures and at least 6 laser spot fixtures for special effects.  To be able to purchase all the lights we need at once rather than over several years will have a huge and lasting impact on our program and productions.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone interested may be able to donate, but please spread the word and help make the people around you aware of our cause. You can come see the show, which opens March 1, 2013.  If you have intelligent lighting or special effects lighting fixtures you would like to donate, please contact us at hhsrisingstarsboosters@gmail.com

Please help make our dream come true!

story:
WHO WE ARE: Dancing Fish Productions

A New York City contemporary dance company led by Artistic Director, Megan Sipe.

WHAT WE ARE MAKING:

AHY-DUH-HOH-UHN, a homespun storytelling dance based on interviews and tales from Idaho.  This piece embraces the bittersweet roots of where one comes from.

 

INTO THE DEEP, a fluid journey of luscious dance inspired by the motions and physical properties of water.  This is a piece about people going into the unknown and the experiences that shape them.

WHAT WE ARE RAISING MONEY FOR:

  • To produce a weekend (3 show) run of AHY-DUH-HOH-UHN at Space on White in NYC within the next 6 months.
  • To continue rehearsal/development of INTO THE DEEP with dancers.  We plan to premier this work in Fall 2013.
  • To actually pay dancers a stipend for rehearsals and performances.

BUDGET BREAKDOWN:

$1,000 = rehearsal space for both works

$2,000 = dancer/performer stipends

$1,500 = production costs (venue rental, lighting, tech crew)

$200 = props and costumes

$300 = publicity materials

TOTAL = $5,000
 

THE IMPACT:

My small company has been diligently rehearsing and refining these projects. The performers have been volunteering their time and energy because they believe in my work.  I am honored to be collaborating with a team of strong and dedicated artists. 

Both of these projects have already started and will be presented.  Your contributions will allow us to present the work within the year, to finally pay the artists, and to reach a larger audience.  I need your help to maintain this momentum. 

HOW DO WE KNOW WE WILL SUCCEED:

Both of these works have been performed in progress at several NYC venues and were warmly received by both audiences and presenters. 

We have performers and collaborators who believe in these projects including a lighting designer, several composers/musicians, dancers, actors and singers as well as a costume designer.  

We have a clear vision and lots of determination.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Spread the word.  Tell your friends about Dancing Fish Productions and ask them to contribute.

One of our largest expense is space.  Perhaps you may have a contact who could give us rehearsal space or performance space in NYC?

Visit DancingFish.org

Please note:  We are not a 501 (c) 3 organization yet, but have begun the process.  At this time, we cannot offer tax deduction for your donations through this site.

story:
A10 is an upcoming series of art manikins by Paul Siegel that licenses many of the same patented and patent-pending designs established with the Armature Nine series (A9RIG). While A9 will continue to focus on human movement and articulation, A10 is going to be a line of products devoted to portraying accurate laser 3D scanned surface anatomy.

Through this campaign we are hoping to raise sufficient funds for ten pieces to be generated through injection molding and get you the product at a substantially better price. These also happen to be the pieces shared with the A9 series of products and other future A10 releases.

If this campaign does not succeed, we will still sell the product as a fully 3D printed item but it will cost substantially more.

www.armatureten.com

 

Final 3d printed components will feature interwoven materials (wood and plastic) for superior wear resistance.  The back of the torso will have an inlaid universal camera mount adapter so you can mount it with your own stands or these clip stands sold on our website.

 

A doll that captures the grace and beauty of the human form.

 

Questions

How tall is Ballerina?

She's 8" tall. The idea being that she's a 1:6 scale girl or petite woman 

 

What are the variants included with the $50 model?

I feature some screenshots of the models being worked on in the updates tab. These and one more of each will be included with the $50 model.  Have an idea for a foot or hand posture you think would be crucial to have beside those shown? If so, leave a comment with suggestions :)

story:
OUR STORY

The Management creates a haven for a community of artists and patrons to experience relevant, moving, unpretentious, aesthetically and financially accessible theater. We are known for our dark whimsy and critical exposés on American culture and for our commitment to building rock-solid, visceral entertainment.


Visit us here: http://managementtheatercompany.com/ 

 

THIS FUNDRAISER

The Management is dedicated to hiring the best theater artists-- actors, directors, designers, playwrights, stage managers-- so that we can continue providing downtown New York with smart, edgy, offbeat plays like recent hits Crystal Skillman's Cut, Joshua Conkel and Megan Hill's Lonesome Winter, Joshua Conkel's MilkMilkLemonade, Dorothy Fortenberry's Caitlin & the Swan, Joe Tracz's Song for a Future Generation, and now the world premiere of...


OUR CURRENT SHOW
Your Boyfriend May Be Imaginary by Larry Kunofsky! 

It’s a busy, happening Saturday night in the Big City, and everyone we know is having a party in their apartment. Apartments! Parties! People! Music! Dancing! Cell phones! Flashbulbs! Making Out! Longing. Your Boyfriend May Be Imaginary is a stylish and romantic party play about a group of 30-somethings negotiating their way through the pitfalls of coupledom.


Starring: Darcy Fowler,Debargo Sanyal, Danielle Slavick, Maya Lawson, Risa Sarachan, Jordan Mahome, Quinlan Corbett, Kirsten Hopkins, Kunal Prasad, Zach Evenson, Geoffrey Hillback, and Penny Middleton. Lighting design by Grant Wilcoxen. Set design by Kyle Dixon. Stage Managed by Kelly Ruth Cole. 

Running: 4/5-4/28, Thurs-Sat @ 8:00 @ Under St. Mark's

 

BUY TICKETS HERE



100% of the money you donate to this campaign will go DIRECTLY towards paying these artists.

PLEASE NOTE: If you are seeking to make a tax-deductible donation, please donate through our Sponsored Artist Page through The Field by clicking on the following link:  https://www.thefield.org/Profile.aspx?SAID=2731

THE BUZZ

Cut

"An extremely well-conceived and well-executed production—a really terrific collaboration between Skillman and The Management...Smartly designed to maximize the intimate playing space—which I’ve seen feel claustrophobically tiny on other occasions—and directed by Meg Sturiano with crackling energy, the piece builds with kinetic excitement through both writing and performance. All three actors (Nicole Beerman as Rene, Megan Hill as Colette, and Joe Varca as Danno) are wonderful." nytheatre.com


"Skillman's rhythmic dialogue flows like a resentful ode, and director Meg Sturiano stages each confession as if she were choreographing a ballet." Backstage


"The director of “Cut,” Meg Sturiano, nimbly sustains the pace: music that she and Mr. Varca have chosen for the fade-outs keeps the rhythm pulsing...Ms. Hill delivers a posturing aria of hip-hop speak that almost brings down the house, while Ms. Beerman displays touching poise, Rene’s maturity a counterweight to Colette’s breathless zeal." New York Times


Lonesome Winter

"Joshua Conkel possesses one of the most deliciously off-kilter
imaginations currently being put to use in New York." NY Press

"Plays like Lonesome Winter and playwrights like these are exactly
what New York needs right now...Take my word for it that
Lonesome Winter is the funniest feel-bad show of the holiday
season." NY Press

"...the writing is acute, the cast excellent, and Ms. Hill triumphant.
Go see her." Blogcritics

"Exquisitely cast and cleverly directed by Meg Sturiano... under her
guidance, Hill gives a mesmerizing performance..." NY Press

"The Management is an adventurous downtown company good at
tapping into the zeitgeist..." Blogcritics

Song for a Future Generation
"...The Management's latest venture, Song for a Future Generation,
a science fiction spectacle dance party...[is] a party that you should
not miss...Director Meg Sturiano clearly has a keen understanding
of [the play's] style and takes us on a seamless journey from scene to
scene...Nicole Beerman's choreography is exuberant, invigorating,
and both hysterically appropriate and integral to the
storytelling...The Management is among the more imaginative and
resourceful theatre companies in the city. Their fervent energy and
spirit of collaboration is made evident in Song for a Future
Generation; they clearly love making theatre."  nytheatre.com


MilkMikLemonade

MilkMilkLemonade Voted Best Off-Off-Broadway Show 2009

MilkMilkLemonade: one of the Best Ensembles of 2009, New York Post


 "Tucked away in the basement theater of Under St. Marks, MilkMilkLemonade opened to rave reviews (including ours) in September. An angry, bitter and very funny play about growing up gay in middle America, playwright Joshua Conkel and director Isaac Butler have taken the limitations of the space and their budget and transformed them into theatrical gold. This is the kind of political show from up-and-comers you want but rarely get when you think Downtown theater." New York Press


"A welcome breath of fresh downtown air...I could fill an entire review just quoting my favorite lines...Isaac Butler and his brilliant cast have taken his lines and situations and run with them...theres very little better than MilkMilkLemonade anywhere south of 14th Street." New York Press


"Clearly the show is on to something. And that something is old-fashioned stuff like, you know, a funny and poignant play, inventive direction and ace acting. In the end theater isn't much more than this, and it shouldn't be any less." New York Post 


Four Star Review "Conkel and director Isaac Butler are unafraid to go for the belly: They want you laughing, nauseated or both. Its proof of how desperately comedy needs audacity: Here, as on your average chicken farm, only the plucky survive."Also included in "Your Perfect Weekend Sep. 25-27" TimeOutNY


"The campy kind of ridiculousness that allows Conkel to delve into the darker side of childhood...Butler's brisk direction milks the script for all it's worth...the talented cast serves up scintillating performances." Backstage

Their fervent energy andspirit of collaboration is made evident in Song for a FutureGeneration; they clearly love making theatre."  nytheatre.com

New York Press











"Clearly the show is on to something. And that something is old-fashioned stuff like, you know, a funny and poignant play, inventive direction and ace acting. In the end theater isn't much more than this, and it shouldn't be any less." New York Post

story:
WHO ARE WE?

Hi. We’re Lunar Energy Productions. We are a New York-based theater company dedicated to transformation and reimagination. In a culture of habit, routine, and been-there-done-that fatigue, we believe it is vital to seek out the surprising in the familiar. To that end, our productions play with perspective and context in order to reveal unexpected aspects of stories and situations we thought we knew. Previous hits include Before Placing Me On Your Shelf (Manhattan Theatre Source), like the night by Katharine Sherman (The Tank), a return of Before Placing Me On Your Shelf to the 2011 NY Fringe Festival where we earned rave reviews, and christopher marlowe’s chloroform dreams by Katharine Sherman (The Red Room).

Now we’re ready to bring you the conclusion of our first full season! Our fall project entitled By Rights We Should Be Giants is a contemporary adaptation of Chekhov’s Three Sisters, replacing turn-of-the-century Russia with Lorain, Ohio directly after the economic crash of 2008. 

With your support, this incredible world premiere will run for three weeks at the Secret Theatre from October 17th – November 3rd.

 

WHY DO WE NEED YOUR HELP?

Lunar Energy’s work is made possible by our generous supporters. Making theater in New York is expensive, and as an emerging theater company we rely on charitable contributions for the majority of our funding.

We’ve chosen an extremely ambitious project to conclude our first season:a full-length original play by one of our Ensemble Actors Nadia Sepsenwol, and her writing partner Tim Van Dyck. This is unlike anything you’ve ever seen before, and if we don’t raise enough money for the production, you never will!

Every penny we receive from you goes directly into bringing our new production to life. We have a lot of work to do before then, so any help you can offer will go a long way.

 

TELL ME ABOUT THE SHOW!

By Rights We Should Be Giants is an adaption of Chekhov's Three Sisters by Tim Van Dyck & Nadia Sepsenwol, set in America's Rust Belt after the economic crash of 2008.

Original music by Franklin James Fisher

Directed by Christopher Diercksen

Production Stage Manager: Aislinn Curry

"The familiar destruction of the American middle-class as told by New Yorkers to the tune of Anton Chekhov's Three Sisters played in the key of G Major until it resolves to G Minor."

 

WHAT ARE WE DOING WITH THAT MONEY?

We are asking for $6,000 to help cover the significant costs of renting the theatre, renting studio space for 6 weeks of rehearsal, purchasing costumes, finding props, building scenery, promoting the show, and compensating the many artists involved in making our vision a reality.

Any donations above and beyond our goal will be used toward our next season.

 

WHO ARE YOU GUYS EXACTLY?

Our Company Members and Affiliate Artists include alumni of the Brown/Trinity Rep and Columbia MFA programs, Juilliard, The Stella Adler School of Acting, Yale University, The National Theater Institute, and Drama Centre London, as well as current MFA candidates at Harvard/ART, UC Irvine, and the University of Iowa Playwright’s Workshop.
story_txt:
WHO ARE WE?
Hi. We’re Lunar Energy Productions. We are a New York-based theater company dedicated to transformation and reimagination. In a culture of habit, routine, and been-there-done-that fatigue, we believe it is vital to seek out the surprising in the familiar. To that end, our productions play with perspective and context in order to reveal unexpected aspects of stories and situations we thought we knew. Previous hits include Before Placing Me On Your Shelf (Manhattan Theatre Source), like the night by Katharine Sherman (The Tank), a return of Before Placing Me On Your Shelf to the 2011 NY Fringe Festival where we earned rave reviews, and christopher marlowe’s chloroform dreams by Katharine Sherman (The Red Room).
Now we’re ready to bring you the conclusion of our first full season! Our fall project entitled By Rights We Should Be Giants is a contemporary adaptation of Chekhov’s Three Sisters, replacing turn-of-the-century Russia with Lorain, Ohio directly after the economic crash of 2008. 
With your support, this incredible world premiere will run for three weeks at the Secret Theatre from October 17th – November 3rd.
 
WHY DO WE NEED YOUR HELP?
Lunar Energy’s work is made possible by our generous supporters. Making theater in New York is expensive, and as an emerging theater company we rely on charitable contributions for the majority of our funding.
We’ve chosen an extremely ambitious project to conclude our first season:a full-length original play by one of our Ensemble Actors Nadia Sepsenwol, and her writing partner Tim Van Dyck. exist solely to produce new work by playwrights of the Afrikan diaspora.  A distinctly unique voice that has been consistently overlooked and mostly absent from the American theatre.  Without organizations like MPAACT, these contemporary Afrikan voices might never find a home.

We have received a $30,000 matching grant from THE JOYCE FOUNDATION.  Help us reach that goal.  We are getting closer every day.  But we want to reach and exceed this fundraising effort.  MPAACT WANTS TO RAISE $5,000 IN 90 days!  And with your help we can do it!!!!

Thank you for your support and we well see you at the theatre!!

Carla Stillwell

Managing Producer

MPAACT

story:
We are In Your Face entertainment, an independent theatre company here in Montreal.  We have been in the business of creating great musical productions since 2010, but our premiere of Jacques Brel is Alive and Well and Living in Paris could use your help!  In case you've never heard of Brel, he was one of the most prolific singer/songwriters of his time, and he died far too young at the age of 49.  He was considered by many to be the master of the French Chanson.  This beautiful show is a retrospective of some of his most compelling songs, with translations by Eric Blau and Mort Shuman, and featuring a cast of four singing in both French and English to a live 4-piece band.

As can imagine, producing musical theatre is a very expensive venture, and we aim to do it right.  There are many small things that make the difference between a good show and a great show, and we are going to put on an AMAZING show!  Our track record is pretty darn good so far, with well-received musical productions of SING! and The Wild Party under our belt, as well as two sold-out children's theatre shows, but now it's time to step it up a notch.  Plus, it's also time to make sure that not only the production benefits from our fundraising, but so do all the people who work tirelessly to make it happen without ever reaping any benefits - often the case in independent theatre... 

We have put together some fantastic perks for your contributions, from complimentary tickets to the show and posters signed by the cast, all the way up to free voice lessons and a private evening of musical theatre just for you given by our very talented cast.  If those categories are not in your budget, though, know that any contribution you make will be greatly appreciated, and will help make this show Brel-worthy.

Please come see the show!  If you love Brel, you will be thoroughly entertained, and if you don't yet know Brel's music, you are in for a real treat.  Thanks for your support.

MARCH 14-24

MAINLINE THEATRE

www.mainlinetheatre.ca

 

WHO WE ARE...

Nadia Verrucci (Artistic Director/Co-Director/Woman #2):  Select theatre credits include Equus, 42nd Street, The Jazz Singer and Carmela's Table.  Other recent credits include the film Mirror, Mirror, tv show Being Human and video game series Assassin's Creed.

Jacqueline Van de Geer (Co-Director):  Van de Geer has both a Master's in Fine Arts and in Theatre, and has trained with Oleg Kisseliov, Marc Zamitt, Franki Anderson, Peter James, Nathatlie Claude and Split Bridges, among others.

David Terriault (Musical Director): Né à Montréal, David étudie présentment à l'université McGill en piano classique.  Il fut le Directeur Musicale de Créatures, Le Prince et le Pauvre, The Wild Party, Songs for a New World et Godspell.

Serge Turcotte (Man #1):  Après une première participation professionnelle à la
production Elvis Story, on a pu le voir récemment autant sur les planches francophone qu’anglophone dans L’Eveil du printemps, To Be et Titanic.

Martin Provost (Man #2): Martin a chanté à travers le monde, du Moyen-Orient au États-Unis, l'Europe et bien sure le Canada. En 2011 il remporte le prix de l'interprétation de la chanson de l'année au concours Ma Première Place des Arts.

Alisha Ruiss (Woman #1):  Alisha has performed in the Montreal Highlights Festival, Toronto Fringe Festival, Festival de Jazz de Québec and in numerous solo cabarets (The Rivoli, Toronto; Le Balcon, Montreal; Don't Tell Mama's, NYC).

Alex Smith (Lighting Designer):  Select credits include Hamlet (Persephone Productions), A Promise to the Sun (Black Theatre Workshop), and The Exonerated (Third-Eye Ensemble).

story:
The Recipe

Mix
18 actors with
5 playwrights who each write for
24 hours to create a
2,000-word play.
Add directors and designers, give them
4 hours of rehearsal and
1 day of tech.

Yields 2 nights of 5 delicious new scripts performed by a Steppenwolf-trained ensemble, served alongside small bites from Robin Kacyn and live music at Theater Wit. Yummy.

We believe that Chicago needs to hear these fresh playwriting voices, and the Appetizer Plays can serve that up on a platter. Donate today to get these plays cookin'.


The Inspiration: Pavement Group's Amuse Bouche

Pavement Group was a beloved storefront theatre company in Chicago. Through four years of their Amuse Bouche festival, they invited Chicago audiences to taste fresh playwriting voices including Lauren Yee,  Idris Goodwin, Hilary Bettis, Sigrid Gilmer, Bixby Elliot, Greg Moss, Cory Hinkle, Laura Jacqmin, and Joe Waechter. 

Pavement Group ceased production in 2014, but Chicago still needs an outlet for fresh playwriting voices. The School at Steppenwolf's Class of 2014 got together and decided to keep this delicious tradition alive with the Appetizer Plays. 


The People

Over 30 artists are coming together to make the Appetizer Plays. Here's who's on the menu so far:

  • Playwrights Liza Birkenmeier, Kara Lee Corthron, Caroline V. McGraw, Sarah Saltwick, and Joe Zarrow*
  • Directors Skye Robinson Hillis, Steppenwolf Ensemble Member TIm Hopper, Lavina Jadhwani, Ben Kirberger*, and Alexander Lane**
  • Chef Robyn Kacyn, founder of Sauced
  • Stage manager Caitlin O'Rourke
  • Lighting designer Emma Deane
  • Actors Echaka Agba*, Bryan Bosque, Kristin Broadwell*, Doogin Brown*, Clare Cooney*, Jennifer Dymit*, Armand Fields**, Damian Fuller*, Jennifer Glasse**, Nicole Michelle Haskins*, Robert Howard*, Carolyn Molloy*, Riley McIlveen*, Abby Pierce*, Kevin Reyes**, Matt Rockwood*, Christine Vrem-Ydstie*, and Trey Wright*.

    • * indicates member of the School at Steppenwolf Class of 2014
    ** indicates School at Steppenwolf grad from another class


The Numbers

We're starting from scratch. The Appetizer Plays will cost $1,260.

  • Space rental at Theatre Wit: $610
  • Artist Stipends: $360
    Offered to artists invited from outside the Steppenwolf Class of 2014 
  • Pre-Show Small Bites designed by Robin Kacyn: $200
    We serve delicious appetizers inspired by the plays to get audiences into the tasting mood
  • Printing and other miscellaneous costs: $100
We plan to raise $910 in up-front costs through this crowdfunding campaign, and to cover artist stipends through ticket sales.

Imagine the potential of the Appetizer Plays: snacking on small bites from Sauced as well as a diverse set of fresh new plays performed by a spicy ensemble of Steppenwolf-trained actors. Please donate, and we hope that you'll come see the show on May 4th and 5th at Theater Wit in Chicago, because we know it's going to be tasty.

story:
The Chicago Regal Foundation is working to reopen the New Regal Theater in 2015 as a major performing arts center on Chicago's South Side. With your help, we can make this Chicago Landmark available to the public and create a much needed catalyst for development and hope in the community.

Reopening the New Regal Theater will establish a creative outlet for inner city youth through performing arts education programs and spur economic development by bringing jobs back to the neighborhood. The Regal’s prime location at the intersection of four major arteries (79th St., South Chicago Ave., Stony Island Ave. and the Chicago Skyway) positions it well to be a driver of regional commerce and tourism to the area.

View our ABC 7 video below!

On-site video coverage:

abc7chicago.com/uncategorized/new-regal-aiming-to-bring-stars-back-to-landmark-theater/356340/

A Regal History

The New Regal Theater is located in the former Avalon Theater, which opened in 1927 in the South Shore neighborhood. Designed by movie palace architect John Eberson, its Moorish Revival themes were inspired by an ornate Persian incense burner he found in a New Orleans antique store. The complex houses an auditorium and banquet hall which resonate with almost a century of history. Boasting 2,250 seats, a 2,000 square foot stage, and a full orchestra pit, the theater is one of the largest remaining movie palaces in the country.


The Original

Located in Chicago’s Bronzeville neighborhood at 47th and South Park Way was the original Regal Theater, which opened in 1928 and showcased iconic talents such as Duke Ellington, Ella Fitzgerald, Miles Davis, Billie Holiday, Ray Charles, B. B. King, Stevie Wonder, James Brown, and many more. The original Regal played a key role in the development of black music from the 1920s through the 1960s. The theater was closed in 1970 and the building was eventually demolished in 1973 after being partially destroyed by fire.

Looking Forward to the Past

Located 5 minutes south, the Avalon operated as a movie theater through the late 1970s and ultimately became vacant after brief use as a community church. In 1985, the Avalon was purchased by Ed and BettiAnn Gardner, who reopened the building in 1987 after an extensive renovation. The building was rechristened the New Regal Theater- an aspirational reference to its Bronzeville ancestor. The New Regal became a Chicago Landmark in 1992 and was ultimately bought by another group. In 2010, the building went into foreclosure, eventually falling into FDIC receivership.

In the summer of 2011, Landmarks Illinois listed the New Regal as one of the 10 most endangered historic buildings statewide. They noted in their report, "Despite the necessary exterior wall repair work, the New Regal theater space is in good condition and largely operational.”


Construction costs

About $250,000 needs to be invested in the building to begin a phased reopening later this year. The work is scheduled to take up to 90 days and includes, but is not limited to the following:

- Updating theater audio and visual technology 

- Refinishing areas of the stage floor

- Upgrading the facilities

- Producing engineering reports and assessments for further work

Once the theater is reopened, we will be able to roll out a community-focused programming schedule that includes music, dance and theatrical performances, educational youth programming, film festivals, and much more.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Links:

Chicago Tribune


Chicago Architecture Foundation

http://www.architecture.org/architecture-chicago/buildings-of-chicago/building/new-regal-theater/

Landmarks Illinois

http://www.landmarks.org/ten_most_2011_new_regal_theater.htm

story:
ABOUT US 

Bitter Like A Lemon was set up in 2014 to produce LEPER + CHIP, By Lee Coffey. After a successful run of the show in Theatre Upstairs in April 2014 we transferred to The Project Arts Centre in a co-production with Theatre Upstairs in February 2015 for another sold out run and a smashing reception and now we are gearing up to take the show to The Edinburgh Fringe Festival this August.

Our aim is to attempt to reduce the age demographic of Irish Theatre.


OUR PROJECT 

Our new project Occupy Theatre Upstairs is not only exciting but it is the first time a company has performed two world premiers back to back in this space and we couldn't be more excited and thrilled to be given this opportunity.

First up we have.....

PERUVIAN VOODOO, written and Directed by Lee Coffey.

One day. One city. One scratch card. One story. Peruvian Voodoo.

Three men move through life in Dublin City and unbeknownst to them, their stories are interwoven. They don't know each other, but they will soon. They don't know it yet, but they are about to fall victim to fall victim to Peruvian Voodoo. A blackly comic vision of Dublin from Lee Coffey, author of Leper + Chip. 

Cast: Laurence Falconer 

           Finbarr Doyle

           Kevin C. Olohan

Director: Lee Coffey

Set Designer: Aoife Fealy 

Lighting Designer: Colm Sexton


& our second show up  is....


A BOY CALLED NEDD, written by Emily Gillmor-Murphy, 

Directed by Karl Shiels

A Boy Called Nedd tells the story of a sixteen-year-old boy trying to stay the course after his brother’s suicide in a fast moving world, where relationships go from awkward silences to quick fire insults at the speed of light. Step into a world where your last mistake goes viral in the blink of an eye and where the darkest lures of the world are only a mouse-click away. 

Cast: Seán Doyle

           Aislinn O' Byrne

          Jasmin Brady 

          Amilia Stewart

          Conall Keating

Director: Karls Shiels

Set Designer: Laura Honan

Lighting Designer: Simon Burke

           

Show Dates & Running Times

Both our shows run in Theatre Upstairs 

PERUVIAN VOODOO 19th-30th May

A BOY CALLED NEDD 2nd-13th June

@7pm Tuesday-Saturday 

@2pm Matinee Wednesday & Saturday

Thank you so much for all of your support, without which we would not be able to continue to produce new work.

A BOY CALLED NEDD, written by Emily Gillmor-Murphy, 
Directed by Karl Shiels
A Boy Called Nedd tells the story of a sixteen-year-old boy trying to stay the course after his brother’s suicide in a fast moving world, where relationships go from awkward silences to quick fire insults at the speed of light. Step into a world where your last mistake goes viral in the blink of an eye and where the darkest lures of the world are only a mouse-click away. 
Cast: Seán Doyle
           Aislinn O' Byrne
          Jasmin Brady 
          Amilia Stewart
          Conall Keating
Director: Karls Shiels
Set Designer: Laura Honan
Lighting Designer: Simon Burke
           

    
Show Dates & Running Times

 Both our shows run in Theatre Upstairs 
PERUVIAN VOODOO 19th-30th May
A BOY CALLED NEDD 2nd-13th June
@7pm Tuesday-Saturday 
@2pm Matinee Wednesday & Saturday
Thank you so much for all of your support, without which we would not be able to continue to produce new work.

story:
Finding work is difficult, finding work in the arts--nearly impossible. 

Breach Once More sprouted from alleviating this hopeless feeling of not getting work in the arts.  We are that little light of hope you see and hear when you read "nearly impossible", because those two words imply there is hope. We are that hope, we are bridging that gap, we are Breach Once More.

We are a place of community, a place where you will be helping artists become successful. By donating to Breach Once More, you're not only helping fund the company, but you're creating work opportunities for young theatre artists now and in the future. So donate some hope and bridge the gap.


What We Need & What You Get

For this campaign we are hoping to raise $12,000.  Your donation goes towards:

•Show Costs 60%

Our fall show, "Suburbia, by Eric Bogosian

Rights to the show, sets and lumber, costumes, space rental (because as you know SF has the highest rent in the country!), publicist and insurance.

•Creative Team 20%

It is important to Breach Once More that we pay our aspiring artists a wage that they deserve.

sound designer, lighting designer, costume designer, set designer, director, stage manager, and actors.

•Operating Expenses (how we stay afloat) 20%

 website domain, TBA membership, graphic design, NPO paperwork, attorney costs, publicity materials, youth education program, and carryover into future BOM (Breach Once More) seasons...


•Your donation will not come without BOM perks! 

We have perks for all levels of donators- from $1 to $2,500.  Breach Once More will accept and appreciate any and all donations.  Every donator gets a Facebook shout out, and the perks only get better from there! We've got Breach Once More swag including one-of-a-kind bottle openers and T-shirts. In addition our top donators will also receive Giants tickets as well as a Producer credit in our program.  You can find out more about these great incentives in the perks section.  


The Impact

Your donation will allow Breach Once More to provide artistic opportunities to talented semi-professionals with the desire that they may pursue their artistic endeavors.  We can commission young playwrights and afford to start a youth education program. We can bridge the gap between being one foot in the theatre door, and one out. Your money goes to building a self -sustaining theatre, with a clear vision and an altruistic mission.


Risks & Challenges

As many of you may or may not know ticket sales only account for 15% of show costs.  Breach Once More has produced successful shows in the past, however we have decided to "up our game" this year. We are renting from larger venues, we are building a fully-functional 7-11 as our set for "Suburbia," AND we are still dedicated to paying our artists and designers a competitive wage. Knowing how expensive it is to run a theatre company in San Francisco, these are scary obstacles.  We are confident in our entrepreneurial spirit.  We are confident in our talent and abilities as young artists, but we need your help.  Your donation will help us maintain that spirit as a company and for up and coming artists in the San Francisco area. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Breach Once More invites you to share our campaign with friends and family on social media, like us on Facebook, and follow us on Instagram and Twitter!
    We are always looking for volunteers, ushers, and feedback on what you'd like to see next from BOM!

story:
Who We Are:

We are the University of Missouri undergraduate theatre company, University Theatre Association (UTA)!  As an undergraduate group, we do not receive any funding through the university, so your contributions make our productions possible! 

UTA offers student run, student directed, and student produced full-length plays, giving students the opportunity to share their passion for theatre while learning what it takes to create a professional production that is enjoyed by the greater Kansas City community.

We help incoming students connect with the theater community throughout the city, and introduces them to the inner workings of professional theatre.

Your contributions will allow students this summer to take Neil LaBute's "Reasons to be Pretty" from concept to production and help them realize their potential as actors, directors, stagehands, and producers.


What We Need & What You Get:

What does it take to create a theatre masterpiece?

1. A set!  Flats and platforms to build, props, furniture, paint and all the screws, nails and glue to hold it all together.

2. Costumes!  Coats, skirts, accessories...for that perfect 2014 couture look.

3. Advertising!  Posters and programs (like the cool poster pic above)...and of course, with your contribution, your name will shine in lights (well, at least it will be in print in the program with our heartfelt thanks).

Want the full scoop?  $600 in wood, paint, and the building stuff, $100 in costumes, $100 in props, $100 in programs, posters, and advertising  and the usual 10% cost overrun built in…that’s it, $1,000 (okay, $990, but you get the idea).  And any extra funds will go into the UTA account to help with future productions!

     

The Impact:

UTA has successfully staged shows for nearly 10 years, so your donations are supporting a group with a long track record of well-managed, professional shows that captivate audiences with comedy, drama, musicals and more.  Your contributions are carefully spent and utilized to benefit the many students that are learning the art of stagecraft.


Other Ways You Can Give:

You can help in more ways than money…help us spread the word!  Share this campaign, like our Facebook page (and invite people to our event), tweet about us, or just come see the show (hey, it’s free…you can’t beat that). Any support you give is greatly appreciated!
