story:
Hi, Bitch!

My name is David Benjamin Tomlinson.  I am a writer and actor, and... I LOVE BITCHES!!!  More specifically, I love the bitches found in the Hag Horror (Grand Dame Guignol if you're fancy) genre; remarkable characters played by actresses like Bette Davis, Joan Crawford, Olivia de Havilland, and Geraldine Page.  

I've written a play called GASH! which is an homage to the Hagsploitation flicks of the sixties and early seventies.  GASH! is a theatrical experience posing as a cinematic one and is Tarantino-esque in its faithful, outrageous take on a beloved genre.  GASH! does not aspire to be camp, but rather to celebrate it.

GASH! has been accepted into the SummerWorks festival (Canada's largest juried performance festival!), which runs in Toronto from August 7 - August 17.  While very exciting, I'm going to need some help from some allies because GASH! is a big show.


Here's the Plan, Bitch!

I want to raise $5000, which will cover all our production costs, and ensure the creative team gets paid.   By offsetting production costs with raised funds, it means the entirety of our box office earnings will be split between the 7 actors, director, and stage manager (as opposed to using most of our box office to cover these production costs).   Production costs include:

  • Festival entrance fee
  • Rehearsal space rental
  • Administrative costs 
  • Props, wigs, and costumes
  • Set building
  • Union insurance fees
  • Advertising and promotion

I have been working with this company on this show since I wrote it in 2008; we have been through two private table reads, and one public presentation.  The actors are multi-nominated award winners in the Toronto performance community.  So far, they have  already volunteered a lot of their time to help support and develop this project.  Even if we sell out every show (7 in all) the company won't be paid the industry standard, so every little bit helps.   

Raising this money isn't about doing an extravagant production of the show, it's about putting together a smart, cost efficient, and hugely entertaining production, that way audience members and performers both win. In the end, this will naturally attract the attention of someone who wants to produce the extravagant version... at that point we're laughing all the way to the bank and you helped make it happen, Bitch!  

What do you get for helping us out?   The perks are simple.  Help us out, because you WANT to, Bitch.  Support queer theatre because it matters.  Do it because you love bitches.


Bitch, Please.  I'm Not Going To Beg.

If you can't help us out by helping fund this production, that's fine, Bitch.  Why not help us out by letting your bitches (especially the super rich ones) know about this campaign (and hey - if you happen to have any single super rich gay friends, that is something you should let ME know about).

If you're going to be in Toronto this summer, come out and see the show... and bring your bitches with you.  If you know people who are going to be in Toronto this summer, make them come out and see the show... and bring 50 of their bitches.   

It's game time, and we're playing for keeps.  We need your help.

Thanks, Bitch.

story:
WHO IS HOMUNCULUS???


Homunculus Mask Theater is an ensemble based company devoted to creating original work that explores new approaches to using masks in the theater. By incorporating masks with movement, music, dance, and optical illusion, Homunculus aims to introduce a new, contemporary form of mask work to a multi-generational audience. Homunculus produces unique, imaginative, and thought provoking theater that, through the use of original, handmade masks, mirrors the humor, sadness, and beauty of our own existence.


Homunculus has been â€¦ RELOADED!


After several years of producing eye-catching and moving physical theater, we are bringing our talents back to the New York City stage for a limited, two week engagement of our brand new show Homunculus Reloaded.  With a wink to traditional styles of mask performance, Homunculus Reloaded uses our signature style of beautifully grotesque masks (many of which will be unveiled for the first time in this exciting production) to tell image based, non verbal stories.   These stories, some literal and others abstract, are a pastiche of visually arresting scenes set to music that segue seamlessly from one into another.  The show is, in essence, a live cartoon that effectively uses masks to create a parallel universe to the one we live in.


The creative process of cultivating our work is just as unique to Homunculus as our productions.  Through an intense, improvisational rehearsal period, an ensemble of actors, dancers, and musicians, under the guidance of Artistic Director Joe Osheroff, will organically develop the show's material.  The characters, connections, and themes that are explored during this process will eventually evolve and mutate into a fully fleshed out production, resulting in some of the most thrilling mask work being performed today.


Homunculus Reloaded will hit the stage April 5th- 7th and April 12th â€“ 14 at 7:30pm and April 7th and 13th at 3pm at Theater 54 in midtown Manhattan.   But before this can happen â€¦ HOMUNCULUS NEEDS YOU!


Without the generous support of our donors (no matter how deep their pockets, or how big their hearts) we would not be able to grow our company and further invest in increasing our threshold for bold choices.  This includes expanding our arsenal of masks, further utilizing musicians and exploring the possibilities of adding more live music to our shows, performing in bigger and better venues, and the overall opportunity to create even more creatively complex living works of art.


We ask for you to donate anything you can today and invest in the future of a truly unique form of performance that, with your generous support, will be here for generations to come.


We arenâ€™t just putting all of our eggs in one basket, either! 

On Thursday, March 1st from 6pm - 9pm, we will be hosting a Karaoke Fundraiser, Silent Auction, and Raffle at an amazing karaoke bar â€¦ The Gael Pub ( between 82nd and 83rd). Rumor has it, you receive a â€˜free shotâ€™ every time you sing! 


Donations include: 

2 Tickets to 'The Maids' @ Red Bull Theater

A Two Show, Two-Ticket Subscription to 'Theater for A New Audience'

A Walking Tour of NYC

Two Quarts of 'Grade A' Vermont Maple Syrup

Piano Tuning Services

Dog Grooming & Training  

Voice Lessons

Hours of Free Rehearsal Space @ CAP 21

A Basket of Kiehlâ€™s Products

Fragrance & Hair Care by L'Oreal

One Month of Free Tutoring from Sylvan Learning

Stewart/Stand Menâ€™s Wallets 

Your Bar Tab â€¦ Paid! 

And much, much more ...........................


If you are game, visit our Eventbright website at http://homunculusmasktheater.eventbrite.com ... 

Reserve your spot and donate at the door! Only $10!!!


WHAT DOES HOMUNCULUS MEAN TO US???


Due to its intrinsically visual nature, Homunculus tells stories in a primitive language-a vocabulary of images, sounds, music and movement that everyone can understand, relate to, and feel moved by, no matter their age or culture.


Behind the imagery and organized chaos, a powerful and moving message is unveiled. Homunculus is not only entertaining, but is also a catalyst for social change, an antidote to the mundane, and a powerful source of healing for those in need of a deeper connection to the playful child inside us all.


With this campaign's success, Homunculus will be abler to continue to grow as a company.  We will be able to add more masks to our repertoire, hire the best designers and musicians, and have a long and bright future ahead of us full of truly unique performances and events.


HOW TO HELP HOMUNCULUS???


We need $11,000 to get this project up and running properly.


We had $4,500 from previous fundraising efforts, but now need to raise $6,500 to make up the difference and put this show on properly.


Here is a BRIEF breakdown of what we are spending the money you will be donating to us on:


PERSONNEL = $2,800

Including the actors, designers, stage manager, music director, musicians, house manager, sound and light operator, graphic designer and publicist. For all we need, this is a LOW figure. HELP US!


PRODUCTION = $7,300

This includes theater (just this is about 3,000) and rehearsal space, set, props, lighting rental, costumes, insurance, transportation, and the entirety of our essential mask making materials.


MARKETING & DEVELOPMENT = $900

This covers press packets, programs, posters and fliers both their design and printing, post cards, and all important wine for consumption before the show!!! (For a small donation, of course!)


We are in the process of applying for grants and approaching other donors and donating organizations for support, but those avenues take a bit more time and cultivation, and we are anxious to do a show!


HELP US PAY OUR ACTORS!


HELP US HAVE KICK ASS LIVE MUSIC!!!


HELP US BE READY FOR OUR NEXT SHOW, SO WE CAN BLOW YOU AWAY!!!!!


WHY DONATE TO HOMUNCULUS???

Why you ask??

Check out the perks up and over there

Wow!!! Those are awesome!


OH, AND WHAT HAPPENS IF WE GET MORE THAN WE ASK?

You will help us keep performing for longer! Our goal is to keep establishing our company in the community and perform as many times and in as many venues as possible, so be prepared to be Homunculized for lots of time to come!


IMPORTANT NOTE: When visiting our website, there is a donation page. Please be aware that the donation page is NOT linked at all to this campaign.


OTHER WAYS TO HELP HOMUNCULUS???


COME TO OUR FUNDRAISER ON MARCH 1st!!!


TELL ALL OF YOUR FRIENDS ABOUT US!!!


â€˜LIKEâ€™ US ON FACEBOOK -WWW.FACEBOOK.COM/HOMUCULUSMASK -AND FOLLOW US THERE!!!  JUST CLICK ON THE TAB BELOW TO CHECK OUT OUR PAGE.


CHECK OUT THE WEBSITE  - WWW.HOMUNCULUSMASKTHEATER.COM -AND SEND IT TO YOUR FRIENDS!!!  CLICK ON THE TAB BELOW TO VISIT OUR SITE.


And of course â€¦ COME SEE THE SHOW!!!


THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!!

story:
After a successful run and extension in the summer of 2011 in Chicago and productions in Omaha, Charleston, Boulder and San Francisco, 5 Lesbians Eating a Quiche was accepted into the 2012 NYC Fringe Festival! 

The ladies are stretching out their legs and gettin' their hair did in hungry anticipation but first, we need YOUR help to get them there!  Have you ever tried transporting these 5 lesbians? There's a lot of crinoline!  Your donation will directly support travel arrangements, housing in New York and, of course, the quiche-fund (God knows asparagus ain't cheap).

The best part? You can see the girls off during our extremely limited Chicago run before they depart to the big apple!  Help us send them off in style and see what all the fuss is about with these Lesbians.  Learn more about the Chicago run here.

More about the Show:
It’s 1956 and the Susan B. Anthony Society for the Sisters of Gertrude Stein are having their annual quiche breakfast. Will they be able to keep their cool when Communists descend on their idyllic town?

Oh, and by the way, The New Colony is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization so your donation is totally tax-deductible!

story:
Who We Are

 

 

Smart sassy sexy sketch comedians who will tickle your funny bone, win your heart, and then stay the night! This edge gives their brand of comedy a universal appeal, as nothing is off limits. JACKIE BLACKMORE, LAUREN MARTIN, MEGAN PHILLIPS, SIDIKA LARBES, and IVA KAPSIKOVA met while performing with the VFS Sketch Company where they quickly discovered that they had a mutual respect and admiration for each other's talents. Recognizing this rare and beautiful thing, they decided to put their quirky and twisted brains together to entertain & titillate people, but mostly to just make them laugh!

This sketch super group is making it's PREMIERE as part of the 2013 Vancouver Fringe Festival. They need YOUR HELP to make this debut as well put together as a Strapless Prom Dress.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $1200 for:

Props & Costumes for all of us- and boy have we got some strange costume needs!

Sketch Start Up costs/ Marketing/ Publicity- we are a new group starting out with new scripts and bare shoulders.


Our perks include tickets* to the show! Contribute now and guarantee your seat*!

You can also score signed show memorablia, a chance to be a part of the cast (in a picture after the show, that is) and a chance to be IN the show (well, your name in the show!).

Not to mention you will have our gratitude and a chance to be part of Vancouver sketch history!

Thanks to Indie Go Go, we get to keep all the funds we raise SO EVERY LITTLE BIT COUNTS!! Without the support of our friends and family we would indeed be truly STRAPLESS, and feeling bare shouldered out there in the cold world. Mucho Gracias.

Other Ways You Can Help

COME TO ONE OF OUR SHOWS!!!!
 
Tickets $10*/$12*
 
Tickets available now: 
www.vancouverfringe.com/ticket-info
 
 
 
You can find us at the Vancouver Fringe Festival
 
PERFORMANCE WORKS
1218 Cartwright Street
Granville Island
 
We have six showtimes:
 
Sept 5 @ 8:20pm
Sept 7 @ 5:55pm
Sept 9 @ 8:30pm
Sep 11 @ 7:45pm
Sep 12 @ 5:00pm
Sep 14 @ 12:15pm
 
 
* Fringe Membership at an additional cost of $5 is needed for every performance, including comp tickets.

story:
I would like to produce a West End/London reading of the musical Kai HÃ¼sgen and I wrote, WHEN ROSE PETALS FALL. A brief synopsis of the show can be seen below.


Why do you need to have a reading?

Having a professional reading of our musical will help inform our writing process so much! Hearing and seeing our show in an English version, performed by professional actors will help us understand the show's strengths and weaknesses and after the reading, we'll be able to make revisions to make the show stronger. The reading will also give us the opportunity to present the show to industry professionals and West End / Broadway producers.


Our Story

I have written the musical with Kai HÃ¼sgen in German four years ago. We had a succesful reading in Vienna. After that we won a dutch price to develop the musical (Musicalmakersbeurs TeksTpieremenT). With the money we won we could do a small tour in Belgium and Holland. For that production I won the Flemish musicalaward for best creative achievement (music and book). In 2011 we had a German version that played in Hamburg and Vienna, which got great reviews. Now we got the show translated and plan a staged reading of it in London. ThatÂ´s why we need your help!


Synopsis

When Rose petals fall tells the story of the 19 year old Tom. He moves into his student room. His single mum, Rose, died recently from cancer. From now on Tom stands on his own. only the memories and the letters, that Rose wrote before she died, are what is left of her. The letters should accompany him through his life.
The pain and the grief of the not processed death gets bigger when Tom meets Iris. She is of the same age as Tom. They quickly converge, but the livly and open mind of Iris reminds him of Rose. Trapped between his memories and future, Tom seeks help in the letters his mother wrote.
Tom relives the last months of Roses battle agains cancer, moments of despair, hope and most of all love.


What did the press say?

MUSICALS MAGAZINE
The writers tell this rather depressing story with suprisingly lightness and poetry. The music helps to achieve that. every song is weaved perfect into the story. It Ìs a musical with intelligent lyrics. Beautifull, catchy music. With this disturbing, emotional, life-loving story this musical presents the genre on an impressive level, without any limitations.


MUSICALREPORTS.NL
When rose petals fall is a wonderfull, from the first second on, rousing and for many people confronting musical. every second was worth it.


THEATERPARADIJS.NL
When rose petals fall is a moving and soulfull musical with wonderfull music and pure characters.


MUSICALSITE.BE
Composer Rory Six and author Kai HuÌˆsgen knew how to avoid every pitfall and created a pure, truthfull musical with integrity that doesn Ìt hunt for emotional effects. The smart way of storytelling, the real life and clear dialogues and the strong and rich score makes you feel and live with the three characters. There is a lot of fine and essential humor, even in the moments where the tragic is flowing. perfect dosed, never out of place.


THEATER.NL
When rose petals fall is a daring story for a musical. Yes, it Ìs intense. But it offers lots of love, humor and hope. an authentic musical like this is rare to find!


What is the money for?

The funds raised will be used to hire a professional director, stage manager, actors, musicians, and sound engineer. The money will also be used to rent rehearsal/performance space and to pay for photocopies of scripts and sheet music. Some money will also be used to pay for basic transportation costs for out of town actors/creative team.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this with all of your friends and colleagues so we can make the dream of an English version come true!

Share us on facebook, twitter,...

story:
We want to make you laugh

And KILL THE CRITIC! is going to do it.

KILL THE CRITIC! is the new comedy written by Todd Wallinger and helmed by award-winning director Nancy Holaday.

KILL THE CRITIC! will have its world premiere June 28-29 at the Tri-Lakes Center for the Arts in Palmer Lake, Colorado.

The play centers on Trevor Stanton, an ambitous young actor who, on the night of his Broadway debut, kidnaps New York City's most powerful theater critic.

Trevor's goal? To prevent the critic from writing a scathing review that could destroy his career.

There's just one problem. Trevor accidentally poisons the critic, and as showtime nears, he must take increasingly desperate measures to keep the body hidden from a parade of outrageous characters, including his scotch-swilling co-star, his ditzy girlfriend, a cougarish diva, a neurotic hitman and a pair of bumbling cops.

If you like the zany humor of Mel Brooks and the Marx Brothers, you’re going to love KILL THE CRITIC! Not only is it filled with witty, fast-paced dialogue, but in the tradition of the best farces, it's got a boatload of physical humor too.

I mean seriously, how many other plays feature a professional stunt man in the leading role?

But we're really poor

Theatre thrives on new works. But it's not easy--or cheap--bringing a new play to life. There are sets to build and props to buy and actors to pay and performances to advertise.

We estimate total production costs to be about $3500. Ticket sales will cover some of that, but not all. That's why we need your help.

We could ask you to cough up the whole amount. But we're not like that. (And besides, we don't like getting coughed on.) All we're asking for is a measly $1000 to cover the rent on the theater.

If we don't meet our goal, no worries. Any amount we raise will help offset our costs, putting that much more distance between us and complete financial disaster.

What you get

In exchange for your contribution, we offer some fabulous premiums you just can't get anywhere else.

Chip in $10 or more and you'll get a special mention in our program. We'll even take extra care to spell your name correctly (where else can you get a deal like that?). And if you can't attend the production, we'll mail you a program--assuming the US Postal Service is still in business by then.

Steup up to a contribution of $30 or more and you'll receive an 11" by 15" poster featuring the tasteful artwork above and signed by the entire cast. Guaranteed to go with any furniture or decorating scheme.

Prove your generosity with a contribution of $60 or more and you'll receive an autographed copy of the script. No, we can't promise that KILL THE CRITIC! will join the canon of great American plays. We can't even promise that an original script will go for a million dollars on eBay. But if it does happen, and you passed up the chance to retire at an embarrassingly young age, don't say we didn't warn you.

Dig a little deeper into that pocket with a contribution of $100 or more and you'll receive a real live one-of-a-kind coffee mug adorned with our eye-catching logo shown above. Imagine the great start you'll give your day sipping a cup of joe with a picture of a dead theatre critic on it. To check it out, click here.

Make a splash with a contribution of $200 or more and you snag the sweetest deal of all: everything mentioned above plus two reserved tickets to any performance of KILL THE CRITIC! These tickets are right up front, where you'll be able to stretch your legs and disdain the muttering rabble behind you.

If you own a business, and you've always dreamed of being one of those patrons of old, lavishing wealth on the brightest artists in your realm, you might consider contributing $500 or more. In addition to all of the premiums mentioned above, this will get you a corporate sponsorship, and we will do everything we can to promote your business in our program, on all of our advertising materials, on our website and at all performances.

Best of all, contributors at every level can sleep soundly at night knowing that they support brand spanking new theatre.

Other ways you can help

If you can't contribute to our campaign at this time, there's something else you can do:

BUY TICKETS TO THE SHOW!

Tickets are currently on sale here.

Not sure whether an unknown play by an obscure playwright will be any good? Well, don't take our word for it. KILL THE CRITIC! just took 2nd place in the Robert J. Pickering Award for Playwriting Excellence (beat out only by some lame play titled On Bended Knee or something like that). So you know it's good.

Who's in this thing?

For this production, we've cast some of the most talented actors in town:

Bertram Janus ....................... Steven Perkins
Trevor Stanton ....................... Uriah Werner
Jack Mann .............................. Daniel Robbins
Sylvia Alcott ........................... Karann Goetsch
Melanie Monzoni .................... Brooke Wallinger
Tony "the Tiger" Monzoni ....... Dan Kifer
Roger Bancroft ........................ Kenny Knapp
Officer Kimball ........................ David Olson
Officer Schwebnick ................. Vincent Brackett

Director ................................... Nancy Holaday
Writer/Producer ...................... Todd Wallinger

STEVEN PERKINS (Bertram Janus) is a professional film actor, stuntman, and part-time X-Man. He has recently appeared on stage in an original adaptation of Beauty and the Beast, and was seen as Captain Long John Silver in Treasure Island, in conjunction with Black Box Theatre. Steve also teaches stage combat and sword handling skills at USCS, and directed fight choreography for Kill the Critic! He performs yearly at the Colorado Renaissance Festival, taking his act to other festivals across the country as well.

URIAH WERNER (Trevor Stanton) toured the world singing and acting with The Continentals and also toured with TVB (a British band) in Great Britain and Spain. He performed with Door Shakespeare in Wisconsin, The Jeremiah People (a national touring company), directed and acted with the touring company Filling The Gap and went to Lawrence University to study music and theater. He now owns The Loft Music Venue and Theater, a popular venue in Colorado Springs.

DANIEL ROBBINS (Jack Mann) has worked in radio & video production for more than 30 years, and currently works as a radio producer for Focus on the Family.  He also writes and has performed dramas for various church groups in Colorado Springs.  Dan and his wife Kitty, a one-woman tech crew, have raised two daughters who are more at home on the stage than off. He resides with his family in Colorado Springs.

KARANN GOETTSCH (Sylvia Alcott) began her career in L.A. as a singer and dancer, appearing in a variety of musical productions, including Funny Girl and South Pacific. She has performed with the London Philharmonic, and performed weekly at the Avalon Bowl on Catalina Island. After relocating to Colorado Karann continued to perform in musical theatre, taking roles in Camelot and How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying. She was most recently seen in The Butler Did It! also by Todd Wallinger.

BROOKE WALLINGER (Melanie Monzoni) fell in love with the stage at a very young age. She has performed in several shows around Colorado Springs: Gypsy, The Music Man, As Thousands Cheer (Fine Arts Center), The Sitter, Three Faces of Lola (24SEVEN) and others; she was most recently seen in Les Miz. She plans on pursuing musical theater in college. Brooke is ecstatic to be a part of Kill The Critic! with such a wonderful cast and director.

DAN KIFER (Tony Monzoni) is no stranger to the stage, having performed vocal music all over the world. His path has taken many turns, but he always seems to be in the right place at the right time. He has thoroughly enjoyed trodding the boards once again, and will continue to wear a Zoot Suit wherever he goes. Dan is a stylist at Eden Eve Salon in downtown Colorado Springs.

KENNY KNAPP (Roger Bancroft) is not quite as neurotic as his character portrayal might imply. He has enjoyed working on the stage in Colorado Springs, appearing as Albert Einstein in Picasso at the Lapin Agile with the Star Bar Players, and as Pony in Suburbia with Theatreworks, to name just a few. Kenny has cut down on his stage work to focus on spending more time at home while his babies are small, but assures us he will return to the stage when the time is right.

DAVID G. OLSON (Officer Kimball) has been on the stage since 1961, when he appeared in the chorus of West Side Story. His stage career has spanned the globe, including performances from Washington to Korea. He appeared most recently as the composer Handel during the Colorado Springs production of The Messiah. Dave now enjoys travel to visit his wide-spread children and grandchildren.

VINCENT BRACKETT (Officer Schwebnick) is a veteran of the stage, having appeared in over 15 productions locally, as well as in award-winning performances at Walt Disney World in Orlando, FL. His favorite roles include Ebenezer Scrooge, Hamlet, and Charlie from Flowers for Algernon. He is excited to appear onstage with these fine actors, and to work
again with director Nancy Holaday.

NANCY HOLADAY (Director) teaches theatre at USCS, and also produces and directs Black Box Theatre Experience. Her award-winning program has seen 25 productions go on the stage, many of them to benefit community programs such as the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (Beauty and the Beast) and Goodwill Industries in their work with the differently-abled (Flowers for Algernon). Love for theatre and her students drive her to push them to excellence. She is grateful to playwright and producer Todd Wallinger for giving her the opportunity to direct this world premiere performance, and looks forward to future performances.

TODD WALLINGER (Writer, Producer) is an award-winning playwright. His one-act comedies The _urloined Letter and Long Tall Lester are published by Pioneer Drama Service. His full-length comedy The Butler Did It! will be published by Pioneer this spring. Todd is the founder and director of the Drama Lab and will be leading a playwriting workshop at this year's Pikes Peak Writers Conference. From 2008 to 2010, he was the theatre critic for the Colorado Springs Gazette. He is currently the theatre critic for the Colorado Springs Independentand serves with the Colorado Theatre Guild as a judge for their annual Henry Awards.

ORIGINAL IMAGE CREATED BY J. J. FIERRO (WWW.BEHANCE.NET/2JFIERRO).

He resides with his family in Colorado Springs.KARANN GOETTSCH (Sylvia Alcott) began her career in L.A. as a singer and dancer, appearing in a variety of musical productions, including Funny Girl and South Pacific. She has performed with the London Philharmonic, and performed weekly at the Avalon Bowl on Catalina Island. After relocating to Colorado Karann continued to perform in musical theatre, taking roles in Camelot and How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying. She was most recently seen in The Butler Did It! also by Todd Wallinger.BROOKE WALLINGER (Melanie Monzoni) fell in love with the stage at a very young age. She has performed in several shows around Colorado Springs: Gypsy, The Music Man, As Thousands Cheer (Fine Arts Center), The Sitter, Three Faces of Lola (24SEVEN) and others; she was most recently seen in Les Miz. She plans on pursuing musical theater in college. Brooke is ecstatic to be a part of Kill The Critic! with such a wonderful cast and director.DAN KIFER (Tony Monzoni) is no stranger to the stage, having performed vocal music all over the world. His path has taken many turns, but he always seems to be in the right place at the right time. He has thoroughly enjoyed trodding the boards once again, and will continue to wear a Zoot Suit wherever he goes. Dan is a stylist at Eden Eve Salon in downtown Colorado Springs.KENNY KNAPP (Roger Bancroft) is not quite as neurotic as his character portrayal might imply. He has enjoyed working on the stage in Colorado Springs, appearing as Albert Einstein in Picasso at the Lapin Agile with the Star Bar Players, and as Pony in Suburbia with Theatreworks, to name just a few. Kenny has cut down on his stage work to focus on spending more time at home while his babies are small, but assures us he will return to the stage when the time is right.DAVID G. OLSON (Officer Kimball) has been on the stage since 1961, when he appeared in the chorus of West Side Story. His stage career has spanned the globe, including performances from Washington to Korea. He appeared most recently as the composer Handel during the Colorado Springs production of The Messiah. Dave now enjoys travel to visit his wide-spread children and grandchildren.VINCENT BRACKETT (Officer Schwebnick) is a veteran of the stage, having appeared in over 15 productions locally, as well as in award-winning performances at Walt Disney World in Orlando, FL. His favorite roles include Ebenezer Scrooge, Hamlet, and Charlie from Flowers for Algernon. He is excited to appear onstage with these fine actors, and to workagain with director Nancy Holaday.NANCY HOLADAY (Director) teaches theatre at USCS, and also produces and directs Black Box Theatre Experience. Her award-winning program has seen 25 productions go on the stage, many of them to benefit community programs such as the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (Beauty and the Beast) and Goodwill Industries in their work with the differently-abled (Flowers for Algernon). Love for theatre and her students drive her to push them to excellence. She is grateful to playwright and producer Todd Wallinger for giving her the opportunity to direct this world premiere performance, and looks forward to future performances.TODD WALLINGER (Writer, Producer) is an award-winning playwright. His one-act comedies The _urloined Letter and Long Tall Lester are published by Pioneer Drama Service. His full-length comedy The Butler Did It! will be published by Pioneer this spring. Todd is the founder and director of the Drama Lab and will be leading a playwriting workshop at this year's Pikes Peak Writers Conference. From 2008 to 2010, he was the theatre critic for the Colorado Springs Gazette. He is currently the theatre critic for the Colorado Springs Independentand serves with the Colorado Theatre Guild as a judge for their annual Henry Awards.
ORIGINAL IMAGE CREATED BY J. J. FIERRO (WWW.BEHANCE.NET/2JFIERRO).

story:
True False Theatre Presents The 2013 Main Stage:

A SLEEPING HOUND TO WAKE

 

written by Daria Tavana
directed by Dmitry Troyanovsky

 

One dysfunctional Southern family struggles to reunite despite a checkered history of violence, drug abuse, and psychosis. When patriarch Richard finally arrives at Bourbon Street, a strange pimp reveals the secret that could keep this father from his kin forever. A Sleeping Hound to Wake combines dark humor, suspense, and sheer grit to examine the ways in which desire and impulse define human relationships.

 

Performance Information: Check back soon for more info on dates, tickets, and the creative team!

TRUE FALSE THEATRE is an experimental performing arts company that has expanded rapidly since its creation in April 2011. We invent magical, dangerous theatrical experiences aimed at engaging audiences of all backgrounds. Our work exposes and examines the ways in which desire and impulse define human relationships, taking inspiration from the intimate sites in which we perform.


Our Mission: TFT is a group of artists dedicated to creating high-quality dramatic theatre that challenges the imagination and inspires a more conscious and compassionate community. Our goal is to probe modern value systems through entertaining productions of both new and classic socially relevant plays, which uphold a commitment to exciting and empowering New York City.


TFT fosters a partnership with Katie’s Art Project, a non-profit organization whose mission is to bring the joy of art to in-patient wards in Pediatric Hematology Oncology units. We’ve also teamed up with Shaklee, the number one natural nutrition company in the U.S. Our goal with both of these organizations stems from our passion for promoting healthy living and creative fulfillment.

About Our Guest Director: Dmitry Troyanovsky’s directing credits include Melissa Cooper's Antigone Now, Sophie Treadwell’s Machinal, Euripides' The Bacchae, Vassily Sigarev’s Plasticine, Alexander Ostrovsky’s The Forest, Nikolai Erdman’s The Suicide, Frank Wedekind’s Spring Awakening, and Dürrenmatt’s The Visit. He led workshops and developed new theatrical material at institutions such as Baryshnikov Arts Center, American Repertory Theatre Institute, 92Y, The Lee Strasberg Institute, SoHo Rep Summer Camp, St. Petersburg State University (Russia), Fisher Arts Center at Bard College, and Brown University. In addition to theatre, he has created installation and performance art projects such as Herzstuck at the Rose Art Museum at Brandeis University. Dmitry has taught at New York University's Tisch School for the Arts, Bard College, and Marymount Manhattan College. He is an MFA graduate of the American Repertory Theatre Institute for Advanced Theatre Training at Harvard University and Moscow Art Theatre School in Russia. 

Click here to meet Team TFT 

How We Reach Our Audience

In 2011, our debut production of two new plays (Firework For Real and Bedspread) at The Producers Club sold out every night. We launched the Official TFT Blog and continue to communicate with our valued supporters via Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube. The Polygraph Tests, a residency program for emerging writers, hosted free public readings on Jan. 21 and 28 at COLLAB. underSTUDY is a yearlong ensemble-building experiment allowing actors the challenge of reinventing Shakespeare’s Hamlet without the pressure or politics of a production. We are currently collaborating on a four-week advertising campaign with CBSNewYork.com and waiting to hear from the Puffin Foundation with regard to receiving a significant grant.

Project Goals

Our marketing and publicity teams have established an increasing fan base using social media, and we continue to promote our main stage at all company-sponsored events. We’ve also recently decided to produce a monthly newsletter while continuing to build both our mailing and donor lists. The ideal audience for A Sleeping Hound To Wake would be between the ages of 18-35, a demographic adamantly in love with tales of crime and destructive relationships. Some of the most beloved works among this age group are in a similar vein to Sleeping Hound including Pulp Fiction and the award-winning television series Breaking Bad. Our target audience knows there is an incredibly captivating magic that comes with watching someone fleetingly grasp at a sliver of hope only to slowly self-destruct in the process. This is not a "feel-good" kind of production, which means that funding it is going to be quite difficult. A play about a desperate drug dealer sheds light on a corner of the country that some theatre organizations would rather leave unseen.

YOU Can Help

We need to raise $11,00 by July 4th to cover venue fees and all other costs necessary to mount this production. We raised thousands of dollars from private donors and pay-to-enter events last year and plan to increase our fundraising efforts in 2012. When you donate to TFT, every penny gets us closer to meeting our increasing demands.

Your donation directly affects the success of our final product, which will be a truly unique experience for all who attend. In addition to our undying gratitude for being a contributor to our campaign, we have created a list of perks that come with each donation (check them out at the top of this page)! And if you can't spare the change via Internet, check back with us soon for video updates with information about fundraising events and other ways to interact with True False Theatre.

Your support, no matter the form, is priceless. Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, Foursquare- share us, blog us, text us, speak us! The best way to make our campaign a success is to talk about who we are and what we do. Tell your friends! Tell your enemies! Tell everybody!

Visit TrueFalseTheatre.org

story:
Short Summary

Hey world!  Above the Curve Theatre is at it again with another phenomenal musical lined up, Songs for a New World by Jason Robert Brown.   We have raised all the funds for the theatre rental, rights for the show, and everything in between EXCEPT enough money for an accompanist, which this show really needs.

 Here is a little about our company!

Founded May 2006 in Los Angeles, CA, Above the Curve Theatre Company is a women-driven, actor-derived, not-for-profit organization dedicated to empowering female artists and strengthening our community.

We provide a fun and safe environment for artists to cultivate new and current talents. All members are encouraged to write, act, produce and direct.  Our goal is to develop versatile artists capable of creating more dynamic work for women and tackling the most challenging roles.

At the same time, Above the Curve Theatre strives to provide the community with professional productions held to the highest standards of excellence. Through the awesome power of the performing arts, the ensemble hopes to educate and entertain, but it does not stop there – members are also encouraged to give back to our community through group sponsored charity events and outreach programs.


Above the Curve is proudly sponsored by Emerge Arts Projects, Inc, a not-for-profit, 501(c)3 entity.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This show is a big undertaking for us, as it is the most expensive show we have done, and our longest run to date.

  • All of your donation will go to paying for an accompanist for the entire run, as well as a few rehearsals with him or her.  There are 18 performances, so our goal would allow us to pay the accompanist about $56 a night, and I would love to give him/her more, since that is not very much for an entire evening of piano playing.  
  • If we don't reach our goal, whatever money we do get will go towards an accompanist, and some of the actors in the show (who are not getting paid) are willing to shell out some money too.  This is how much they want this show to be successful!!!

The Impact

  • Los Angeles needs good theatre, and we are trying to provide it, so if you want more quality shows in LA, any donation can help!
  • Our company is know for providing a safe and fun environment for actors as well as putting on quality productions, given a limited budget.  Help us take the next step up in the Los Angeles theatre world by making a donation.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help us get the word out to raise money for our campaign, and of course we would love for you to come see our show as well!  Check our website soon for details.  www.abovethecurvetheatre.com
  • If you can't donate, but know someone who might be able to, don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Our History

"I am deeply impressed with the vision and originality of The Tennessee Project! It is everything that a holistic arts project should be: grounded in excellence, collaborative in nature, and focused on community. Bravo." - Albert Schultz, Artistic Director of Soulpepper

In May of 2012 The Tennessee Project, the inaugural smash-hit theatre festival, presented forty seven performances over seven nights, selling out 80% of houses, and playing to more than 2,500 Torontonians. With their extensive media coverage, cross-promotions, and partnerships, the Project is estimated to have reached 2,495,000 Torontonians. The Café Series, featuring free performances around the city, was packed every night. And an article in The Grid (about whether or not Toronto’s theatre scene can stay afloat) cited The Tennessee Project as being “what we want”. 

The Project

Seven theatre companies come together in a massive collaborative effort to stage seven one-acts plays by a featured playwright...

These productions are staged in seven different Toronto neighbourhoods....

Every night for a week, each production rotates to a different neighbourhood, giving each community a spectacular and unique week-long event, and each company a chance to build relationships with audiences for whom they might not otherwise perform. 

Our Vision

"This project descends on Toronto's neighbourhoods and wins the hearts and minds of the people! It creates new patrons and saves the old ones bus fare. It is possible for anybody to return night after night to the venue down the block to see scores of artists occupy corners of Toronto neglected by other festivals.” - Audrey Wiles, audience member of The Tennessee Project

The Project aims to build a tighter sense of community amongst artists and audiences. The rotating format, the brevity of the one-acts, and the localized neighbourhood-based creates an uncomplicated, friendly theatre-going experience for audiences. And the collaborative format allows disparate groups of theatre-makers to share their resources and knowledge, and expand upon their audience base for years to come. 

The Playwright Project officially announces its 2013 line-up on November 26th, 2012. Who will be the featured playwright? In what neighbourhoods will we be appearing? Who will be our seven companies? Keep an ear open. 

A little taste of what The Playwright Project 2013 will feature:

  • 7 of Toronto's hottest theatre companies, with some old friends from last year and some exciting new faces
  • Live post-show music
  • Film screenings 
  • Artist talks 
  • A thrilling new adaptation
  • Huge community outreach with partnerships in each neighbourhood and artists volunteering with local services
  • The wildly popular Cafe Series
  • The Project Mentor Program
  • Surprise performances!

“Congrats to all the troupes and the festival producers... Let’s hope there’s another such festival linking companies and audiences around town.” - Jon Kaplan, NOW Magazine

In the meantime, we need all the support we can get in order to ensure this festival grows into the exciting annual culture event that so many have raved about. 

"Spreading great entertainment across Toronto should be the mandate of any artist producing here. The stages don’t disappear outside the Annex, off Bathurst, or beyond King and John. If [Project Directors] Alex and Daiva had a storage locker on Keele, a dock in Mimico and an internet cafe on Kingston Road they’d give you a festival nobody in their right mind should miss.” - Brenhan McKibben, Red One Theatre Collective

The Project believes in supporting local artists. All box office revenue is given to the artists who work on the shows, which means we depend on a combined income of government grants and the support of local businesses and individuals like you to cover our operating costs. We also believe that our supporters are not just money in the bank, but our partners in this great cultural adventure. 

"A connection was created between the audience and the actors, thus providing our homebound seniors with warm social interactions. I sincerely think that the Project will continue to provide socially beneficial and valued service to marginalized communities by showcasing and bringing live arts to these vulnerable populations.” - Bonnie Yeung, WoodGreen Community Services

Our partners receive:

  • Discussion with Project staff to determine how the Project can help you in return for your support
  • Tickets to performances
  • Invitations to events like our Launch Event, Project Gala and Partner Appreciation Night
  • Opportunities to sit in on rehearsals or grab a beer with the companies
  • A whole host of perks, listed below

We hope you will join us in spreading great art to every corner of the city we love, and helping to make this great metropolis feel a little smaller. 

"An exciting, collaborative and grassroots undertaking if there ever was one." - BlogTO

story:
I have been truly blessed with the ambition to share my talent and the courage to tell my story...

BEHIND FISHING'IN BROOKLYN:

Exactly 16 years ago I lost one the most important people in my life, My Mother, to Ovarian Cancer. A ten year old girl growing up in the Bedstuy section of Brooklyn, NY having the means to survive this tragedy, believe it or not, was nothing to me. Having my fist game just right in school to maintain an ounce of respect, making sure to not walk pass Marcy Projects, jamming behind the Jamaican Float on Labor Day then bobbing and weaving from right to left to avoid nameless bullets/sprayed. Growing up taught me that when someone dies you simply popped open a few bottles of Heinken and pour it over their grave, engaging in libation, celebrating their memory, keeping their soul alive. My mama taught me to never cry, never shed a tear and to never feel sadden by my lost. And for 16 years I kept that promise... I stood in silence... I partied on in her honor... But then... One day... that ten year old girl decided to SPEAK.

I wrote "Fishing'In Brooklyn" well over 6 months ago while sitting in a room on South Oxford St. with a company called Freedom Train Productions. Beginning with just a memory of fishing in Prospect Park Brooklyn with my mother. I remembered everything about those times, her perfume, the crispness of the air, even what she had on. I wanted to hold on to those memories, to trap them inside a story that could never be erased because once spoken they were bond. This story took flight and 16 characters were born out of my 16 years of silence. 

These characters include: My Father, My Grandmother, My Child Hood Girl Crush, My Lover, The Chinese Man who owed the fish store by my home, The Neighborhood Homeless Man, My Fifth Grade Teacher, My Brother, My Sister, The Local Drug Dealer, The Ghanian Boy I met while in Ghana, The Nigerian Girl I met while leaving Ghana, My Childhood Self, My Adult Self, Yemaya (An Orisha Goddess...A Nigerian religious influence) and My Mother.

Someone asked me the other day... "Well what did you get from it". At the time I coudn't answer him...I'd gotten so use to explaining the show, the impudence behind writing it, and what I want to do with it. I never took the time to reflect on what I took from it. And then I got it... "The Chance To Speak... To Sing....and to Scream to several different crowds... I LOVE AND MISS MY MAMA.... but i'ma be all right.

SYNOPSIS OF SHOW: A 60min., Spoken Word, autobiography following ten-year-old Tia-Lite, a young Afro-Latina from Brooklyn, guided by 15 characters, through memories of her late mother and her Afro-Carribbean Roots, in search of her true self. With poetry, dance, and live musical accompaniment, Tia takes the audience through Ghana, Jamaica, & Costa Rica remind them what it feels like to be back in "Los Brazos de su Madre," your mother's arms.


DREAM BIG!!! OR DON'T DREAM AT ALL!!!   HELP SUPPORT THIS PROJECT AND KEEP THIS DREAM ALIVE!                                                                                                                                                        


Much Light,  LaTonia

A ten year old girl growing up in the Bedstuy section of Brooklyn, NY having the means to survive this tragedy, believe it or not, was nothing to me. Having my fist game just right in school to maintain an ounce of respect, making sure to not walk pass Marcy Projects, jamming behind the Jamaican Float on Labor Day then bobbing and weaving from right to left to avoid nameless bullets/sprayed. Growing up taught me that when someone dies you simply popped open a few bottles of Heinken and pour it over their grave, engaging in libation, celebrating their memory, keeping their soul alive. My mama taught me to never cry, never shed a tear and to never feel sadden by my lost. And for 16 years I kept that promise... I stood in silence... I partied on in her honor... But then... One day... that ten year old girl decided to SPEAK.

I wrote "Fishing'In Brooklyn" well over 6 months ago while sitting in a room on South Oxford St. with a company called Freedom Train Productions. Beginning with just a memory of fishing in Prospect Park Brooklyn with my mother. I remembered everything about those times, her perfume, the crispness of the air, even what she had on. I wanted to hold on to those memories, to trap them inside a story that could never be erased because once spoken they were bond. This story took flight and 16 characters were born out of my 16 years of silence. These characters include: My Father, My Grandmother, My Child Hood Girl Crush, My Lover, The Chinese Man who owed the fish store by my home, The Neighborhood Homeless Man, My Fifth Grade Teacher, My Brother, My Sister, The Local Drug Dealer, The Ghanian Boy I met while in Ghana, The Nigerian Girl I met while leaving Ghana, My Childhood Self, My Adult Self, Yemaya (An Orisha Goddess...A Nigerian religious influence) and My Mother.

Someone asked me the other day... "Well what did you get from it". At the time I coudn't answer him...I'd gotten so use to explaining the show, the impudence behind writing it, and what I want to do with it. I never took the time to reflect on what I took from it. And then I got it... "The Chance To Speak... To Sing....and to Scream to several different crowds... I LOVE AND MISS MY MAMA.... but i'ma be all right.
SYNOPSIS OF SHOW: A 60min., Spoken Word, autobiography following ten-year-old Tia-Lite, a young Afro-Latina from Brooklyn, guided by 15 characters, through memories of her late mother and her Afro-Carribbean Roots, in search of her true self. With poetry, dance, and live musical accompaniment, Tia takes the audience through Ghana, Jamaica, & Costa Rica remind them what it feels like to be back in "Los Brazos de su Madre," your mother's arms.DREAM BIG!!! OR DON'T DREAM AT ALL!!!   HELP SUPPORT THIS PROJECT AND KEEP THIS DREAM ALIVE!                                                                                                                                                        Much Light,  LaTonia

story:
YUNG-LI DANCE presents
Modus (World Premiere)

Each year, YUNG-LI DANCE presents an original choreographed performance that is inspired by the world around us and inside us.  This year’s production, entitled Modus, is a bold expression of our inner daily working patterns and motions featuring young emerging New York-based talents.

And so, we are inviting you to be a part of this production through making a donation.  The total production cost is around $12,000 but we are asking for partial support to off-set these costs so we may continue bringing talent to you on stage. With a donation of any amount, you are helping YUNG-LI DANCE and its local New York artists develop and promote our artistic vision.

Donated funds will be used to build the stage, develop audio/visual effects, afford a live musician, and compensate our performers and artist for all the creativities and efforts they are devoting to bring you Modus.  In the few remaining days, you can make our production become perfect.  

Your support of YUNG-LI DANCE will be rewarded with sincere gratitude from the entire cast as well as amazing perks in theater, yoga, food, music and visual art!  The perks really add up the higher you donate, so we encourage friends pitching in together to share!

Thank you very much for contributing to YUNG-LI DANCE. We look forward to seeing you June 1st-3rd at the Baruch Performing Arts Center.    

 

MODUS

"Reality is merely an illusion, albeit a very persistent one.” - Albert Einstein

Layering references of infra-structure, individualism, and patterns - both social and geometric - YUNG-LI DANCE constructs a process of re-discovery through physical movement and the creative adjusting of rational thought. 

Modus Direction by Yung-Li Chen

Performed by Ching-I Chang, Yung-Li Chen, Giovanna Gamna, Wedee Kao, Zuzanna Mrozek, and Eric Williams

 

Costumes Eighteenth, recipient of the 2012 Ecco Domani Fashion Award 

Stage Arrows Up, 2011 Glenfiddich Artist-in-Residence

Visual Art Ben Dierckx 

Original Musical Score Gilbert Galindo

Lighting Yu-Chen (Nick) Hung

Photography Alexandra Vainstein

Graphic Design Gulay Inceoglu

Cinematography Sergei Krasikov


For more information, please visit: www.yunglidance.org

story:
The Gist

Four people are covered in mud. They stand alone on an island with eyes that shift and then with bodies that roll, leap, twitch, swoop, and hide underneath the earth. The dancers are quirky, animalistic, and bizarre. They exist in a place uninhabited by other humans, but you watch them from the comfort of your office chair.

We are graduating from The Ohio State University with BFAs in Dance and are planning our first project as graduates! We are filming a 10-15 minute dance film on Little Tybee Island, an island near Savannah that can only be reached by boat, for one week this May. Three other graduating students from the OSU Department of Dance are joining us to create a piece about how people can relate to and within an isolated environment. After we have created the film, it will be available online for everyone to see whenever they want. We will also submit it to film festivals all over the world, including Dance Camera West (Los Angeles), Frame Works Dance Film Series, San Francisco Dance Film Festival, Festival Internacional Videodanza Chile, Dance and Media Japan, and Cinedans Amsterdam. We are also planning to have a special screening for the Savannah community.

 

The Problem (and Solution)

Even though dancing on an island is free, making a dance film on it is not. We need $2,000 to pay for

  • Transportation costs
  • Costumes
  • Composer wages
  • Videographer wages
  • Dancer wages 

We would love for you to become a part of our collaborative team! For contributing to the project, you will receive copious amounts of thanks that range from a grateful note to the ability to download the final film to being listed as a producer in the film’s credits. You can help make our vision a reality! Check out our perks for all the details.

 

The Impact

As dancer-artists, we feel compelled not only to make thought-provoking, beautiful art, but to also share it with the community. Dance film gives us a great avenue to reach people who would not normally come to a theatre to see contemporary dance because the art is brought right to their computer screens.

Ohio State has one of the best dance departments in the country, and we feel ready to step out with our own fresh voice. We have been creating and performing in works outside the university while still in school, including an art benefit in Chicago, a college dance festival in Brooklyn, The American Dance Festival, dance intensives in New York City, a pop-up art show in Ann Arbor, and (for one of our dancers) in a Broadway musical! We are ready and excited to make our mark on the dance scene, and we want to make that mark as accessible to as many people as possible.

Here is the link to Rebekah’s vimeo page, where you can find two of her dance films and other videos of choreographic work in progress. Bookmark this page to check back for the finished island dance film!

 

https://vimeo.com/61219612

 

The Action

You can help us share dance on screen in several ways. Here’s what you can do:

  • Make a contribution to our campaign
  • Share a link to this page with friends and family who may also be excited about our project
  • Keep checking back to find links to the finished film

 

The People 

Rebekah Edie (choreographer, director and performer) originally from Savannah, GA, is a senior at The Ohio State University where she will graduate in the spring with a BFA in Dance and a minor in Women’s, Gender and Sexuality Studies. She has performed with various choreographers including Bebe Miller, Meghan Durham, Dante Brown, Ohad Fishof and Noa Zuk. She has danced in many landscapes while at Ohio State, including agricultural arenas, climbing walls, libraries and hillsides. Most recently, she performed “Tall Girl, Short Girl,” (choreography Rebekah Edie and Madeline Irmen) at Dancewave’s Kids Café in Brooklyn, NY. Her dance film “tango to no one” was also just shown at THAW 2013 in Chicago, IL. During her junior year, Rebekah received funding from the Undergraduate Research Scholarship, International Experiences Grant, Arts and Humanities Small Grant and Semester Funding Initiative to travel to Burkina Faso, West Africa to study traditional and contemporary West African dance, as well as conduct interpersonal research on identity and border crossing for her senior project research. Rebekah is currently finishing up her senior project, a piece to be performed at ACCAD (Advanced Computing Center for the Arts and Design) that compiles her three research interests in gender theory, choreography and intermediated work.

Madeline Irmen (choreographer, director and performer), originally from Holland, OH, is a senior at The Ohio State University. She will graduate with honors in the spring with a BFA in Dance. During her time at OSU, she has had the pleasure of performing in works by Michael Kelly Bruce, Susan Hadley, Bebe Miller, Noa Zuk and Ohad Fishof, Erik Abbott-Main, Dante Brown, and Erik Speth. She has choreographed for the stage and the screen and has recently co-choreographed and performed “Tall Girl, Short Girl,” at Dancewave’s Kids Café in Brooklyn, NY. Madeline received an Undergraduate Research Scholarship for her Honors Distinction Project, which will be a dance performance utilizing live dance alongside video projections. Her project, “Staring at the Sun,” was choreographed, filmed, and directed in collaboration with Quentin Burley and will be performed at ACCAD (Advanced Computing Center for the Arts and Design) in April. After graduation, Madeline plans to move to New York City to pursue a performance career.

Ellen Maynard (cinematographer) is a dance artist and filmmaker originally from the West coast. Ellen currently lives in Columbus, Ohio, where she will be graduating with distinction from The Ohio State University this spring, with a BFA in dance and a minor in video art. While living in California, Ellen was inspired by artists such as Jean Isaacs, John Malashock, and Christopher Pilafian. During her time at Ohio State, Ellen has performed in original works by Bebe Miller, Lily Skove, Ann Sofie Clemmensen, Esther Baker-Tarpaga, Ohad Fishof, and Noa Zuk. Ellen is specifically interested in weaving dance and film together into a rich sensory experience. Her film, On Such a Day as This, placed in the top 30 videos in the International 60 Seconds Dance Festival 2013. Her most recent project, The Wind is on us Here, Turning, is a film series that spans between the Internet and the Theatre. The Internet films are hosted at www.eshofunifuturenow.com, and the theatre films will premiere at OSU’S ACCAD (Advanced Computing Center for Arts and Design) in April. This project is part of Ellen’s research in dance film at OSU, and was funded by an Undergraduate Research Scholarship. Ellen is excited to keep creating and collaborating with other artists after graduation with projects such as The Original Island Dance Film. After filming on the Island, Ellen will travel to Bates Dance Festival for an internship in videography.

AJ Blankenship (performer) originally from Circleville, OH, recently graduated from The Ohio State University with a BFA in Dance and earned the Magna Cum Laude honors status. During his years in college, Blankenship was a member of the Varsity Cheerleading squad where he performed at the Rose Bowl, the Sugar Bowl, and the Gator Bowl. He has competed three times at the UCA College Cheerleading National Championships where he and his team had top ten finishes. He regularly works as a freelance choreographer for cheerleading and dance team programs. Blankenship was recently a member of the Original Broadway cast and First National Tour of Bring It On: the Musical. He also worked as the Assistant Acrobatics Coach for Matilda: the Musical on Broadway. Blankenship has danced with artists Andy Blankenbuehler, Bebe Miller, Meghan Durham-Wall, Olivier Tarpaga, and Dante Brown. Blankenship has worked with Contemporary artist Doo-Sung Yoo on a piece titled Vistauroborg Version 2.0. Blankenship has created several of his own works and continues to choreograph regularly. Blankenship will be moving to NYC to pursue his career in dance and musical theater.

Quentin Burley, performer

story:
From the folks who brought you 12th Night...

Shakespeare on the Quad Presents 

Much Ado

Saturday, May 5 at Amherst College

Sunday, May 6 at Hampshire College


What: It's going to be a picnic, a party, a free outdoor theatrical event. It's going to have two weddings and a funeral, song and dance, & love and loathing.

When: Saturday, May 5, 4pm & Sunday, May 6, 4pm.

Where: Last year, 12th Night was a one-night-only event on the main quad in Amherst. This year, with nearly half our creative team hailing from Hampshire College, we're adding a second performance on the Hampshire campus. More details on location to come.

Who: Lots and lots of people you know

  • David Baird (Don Pedro)
  • Brooke Bishop (Costumes & Beatrice)
  • Grace Booth (Leonata)
  • Ben Calman (Borachio)
  • Phil Dupont (Music)
  • Michelle Escobar (Don Joan)
  • Marisa Gold (Verges, etc.)
  • Shawna Grajek (Hero)
  • Kathi Kaity (Dogberry)
  • Skye Landgraf (Directing)
  • Mike Lion (Claudio)
  • Jeffrey Moro (Benedick)
  • Leslie Roth (Margaret)
  • Jenney Shamash (Scenery)

Why: As always, we're here to entertain our community, to make accessible enjoyable Shakespeare, and to do what we love to do. And we're putting it together independently, as a team. We're trying to develop our production skills, and turn this shindig into a tradition. 

Click here for a taste of what we're capable of. 12th Night was a great success, and we hope to make Much Ado even greater.

But we can't do it without you. We recognize that the text, the story, and the community are the most important elements of this show. However, even with our low-budget aesthetic, we can't do it for free. We're going to need money for scenery, props, costumes, music, and photography. And it's important to honor and support our company members, and so this year we hope to be able to pay at least a gestural amount to the artists.

Below you will find perks associated with various pledge amounts. We would greatly appreciate your support, whether it's by donating as little as $1, by talking the show up to everyone you know, or by coming out to be entertained. Even if you can't afford to support us with a donation, please spread the word.

Love and Gratitude,

- The Shakespeare on the Quad Team

story:
« La fête à Jean », est un spectacle produit par le Théâtre L’instant, qui a été sélectionné pour la saison théâtrale 2012-2013 à la Salle Fred-Barry du Théâtre Denise-Pelletier. Les représentations auront lieu du 9 au 26 janvier 2013. Et qui dit nouvelle création, dit: recherche de fonds !

Tout a commencé il y a un peu plus de trois ans. À cette époque, nous fréquentions régulièrement un groupe de soutien pour les personnes endeuillées. Chaque membre de la compagnie vivait un deuil. Les rencontres se déroulaient chaque lundi après-midi, au Salon b sur la rue St-Laurent, avec le thérapeute Michel Trozzo. Ces réunions gratuites nommées «Lundi-Causerie» sont une initiative de la maison Alfred Dallaire/MEMORIA. Notre désir commun au Théâtre L’instant était de faire des spectacles avec un impact social, une forme de théâtre documentaire. Nous avons donc organisé des ateliers d’écriture avec les participants ce groupe afin que notre jeune auteur, Pier-Luc Lasalle,  puisse s’inspirer des témoignages de chacun. Et c’est ainsi que « La fête à Jean » a commencé sa longue gestation.

Notre intention, notre motivation première : donner la parole aux endeuillés. Cette histoire parle d’un thème  important, car c’est une réalité qui touche chacun d’entre nous,  mais bien souvent, nous préférons fuir la question. Le Théâtre L’instant a eu envie de rendre hommage au courage de ceux que nous avons côtoyés dans le groupe de soutien les lundis après-midi sur la rue St-Laurent. Ils sont devenus 9 personnages qui vont vivre sur scène, sous vos yeux,  leur tristesse, les non-dits, les malaises et la douleur reliée à leur perte, mais aussi de grands moments de joie et de puissante libération.

Aidez-nous à produire cette pièce de théâtre afin que « La fête à Jean » puisse transmettre le vécu, la réalité face au deuil et témoigner de la vie de  ceux qui restent.

 

Avec toute notre gratitude

L’équipe du Théâtre L’instant

 

Synopsis de la pièce

 

C’est l’anniversaire de Jean. Pour l’occasion, on a organisé une fête. Familles et amis sont donc réunis pour célébrer. Mais cet anniversaire risque d’être le dernier de Jean. Car il est malade. Il va mourir. Le diagnostic est irrévocable. Malgré tout, on chante, on danse. La musique nous entraîne, l’alcool coule à flots, la nourriture est abondante, et le rire de Jean résonne. On l’entend peut-être pour la dernière fois…

La mort prochaine de Jean ravive, chez certains, des deuils vécus, récents ou anciens. Que ce soit le départ d’un conjoint, d’un parent, d’un enfant, d’un frère… Alors que la fête bat son plein, les spectateurs ont accès aux souvenirs heureux des uns, à la douleur encore vive des autres. Des voix s’élèvent pour raconter un deuil, pour dire tout ce qu’on ne dit pas, tout ce qu’on ne veut pas entendre. Parce que fête ou pas,  il faut, plus souvent qu’autrement, garder le sourire. 

 

Mise en scène : André-Marie Coudou

Distribution : Bernard Carez, Étienne Courville, Michel Daviault,  Nathalie Gascon, Denis Gravereaux, Jonathan Morier, Diane Ouimet, Marie-Pierre Poirier et Sylvianne Rivest-Beauséjour.

Concepteurs : Scyndia de Barros, Jeanne Fortin, Benoit Grégoire, Alexandre Tougas et Ian Yaworski.

Texte : Pier-Luc Lasalle en collaboration avec Marie-Pierre Poirier et les endeuillés des "lundi-causerie" de chez Alfred Dallaire/MEMORIA

 Conseil d'administration : André-Marie Coudou, Michèle Duguay, Célia Laguitton, Ludovic Le Draoullec, Antoine Tronquoy et Marie-Pierre Poirier
story_txt:
« La fête à Jean », est un spectacle produit par le Théâtre L’instant, qui a été sélectionné pour la saison théâtrale 2012-2013 à la Salle Fred-Barry du Théâtre Denise-Pelletier. Les représentations auront lieu du 9 au 26 janvier 2013. Et qui dit nouvelle création, dit: recherche de fonds !
Tout a commencé il y a un peu plus de trois ans. À cette époque, nous fréquentions régulièrement un groupe de soutien pour les personnes endeuillées. Chaque membre de la compagnie vivait un deuil. Les rencontres se déroulaient chaque lundi après-midi, au Salon b sur la rue St-Laurent, avec le thérapeute Michel Trozzo. Ces réunions gratuites nommées «Lundi-Causerie» sont une initiative de la maison Alfred Dallaire/MEMORIA. Notre désir commun au Théâtre L’instant était de faire des spectacles avec un impact social, une forme de théâtre documentaire. Nous avons donc organisé des ateliers d’écriture avec les participants ce groupe afin que notre jeune auteur, Pier-Luc Lasalle,  puisse s’inspirer des témoignages de chacun. Et c’est ainsi que « La fête à Jean » a commencé sa longue gestation.
Notre intention, notre motivation première : donner la parole aux endeuillés. Cette histoire parle d’un thème  important, car c’est une réalité qui touche chacun d’entre nous,  mais bien souvent, nous préférons fuir la question. Le Théâtre L’instant a eu envie de rendre hommage au courage de ceux que nous avons côtoyés dans le groupe de soutien les lundis après-midi sur la rue St-Laurent. Ils sont devenus 9 personnages qui vont vivre sur scène, sous vos yeux,  leur tristesse, les non-dits, les malaises et la douleur reliée à leur perte, mais aussi de grands moments de joie et de puissante libération.
Aidez-nous à produire cette pièce de théâtre afin que « La fête à Jean » puisse transmettre le vécu, la réalité face au deuil et témoigner de la vie de  ceux qui restent.
 
Avec toute notre gratitude
L’équipe du Théâtre L’instant
 
Synopsis de la pièce
 
C’est l’anniversaire de Jean. Pour l’occasion, on a organisé une fête. Familles et amis sont donc réunis pour célébrer. Mais cet anniversaire risque d’être le dernier de Jean. Car il est malade. Il va mourir. Le diagnostic est irrévocable. Malgré tout, on chante, on danse. La musique nous entraîne, l’alcool coule à flots, la nourriture est abondante, et le rire de Jean résonne. On l’entend peut-être pour la dernière fois…
La mort prochaine de Jean ravive, chez certains, des deuils vécus, récents ou anciens. Que ce soit le départ d’un conjoint, d’un parent, d’un enfant, d’un frère… Alors que la fête bat son plein, les spectateurs ont accès aux souvenirs heureux des uns, à la douleur encore vive des autres. Des voix s’élèvent pour raconter un deuil, pour dire tout ce qu’on ne dit pas, tout ce qu’on ne veut pas entendre. Parce que fête ou pas,  il faut, plus souvent qu’autrement, garder le sourire. 
 
Mise en scène : André-Marie Coudou
Distribution : Bernard Carez, Étienne Courville, Michel Daviault,  Nathalie Gascon, Denis Gravereaux, Jonathan Morier, Diane Ouimet, Marie-Pierre Poirier et Sylvianne Rivest-Beauséjour.
Concepteurs : Scyndia de Barros, Jeanne Fortin, Benoit Grégoire, Alexandre Tougas et Ian Yaworski.
Texte : Pier-Luc Lasalle en collaboration avec Marie-Pierre Poirier et les endeuillés des "lundi-causerie" de chez Alfred Dallaire/MEMORIA
 Conseil d'administration : André-Marie Coudou, Michèle Duguay, Célia Laguitton, Ludovic Le Draoullec, Antoine Tronquoy et Marie-Pierre Poirier

story:
One of the three young choreographers below who were recommended by World Dance Alliance - Americas (WDA-A) will be selected to attend the International Young Choreography Projects (IYCP) in Kaohsiung, Taiwan!

We are calling out to all lovers of dance, WDA-A membership, and friends and family of the nominated finalists to help the selected finalist achieve their dream of traveling to Taiwan and participating in this once in a lifetime opportunity!

The young WDA-A choreographer selected to participate by the IYCP will receive housing, local transportation, access to dancers and studio space, publicity, production and administrative assistance, and an honorarium. However, the airfare is not covered.

The airfare is not cheap.  The three finalists have all agreed in good faith to support one another by collaborating in this fundraising drive to help offset the expensive round-trip airfare cost to get the selected young choreographer to Taiwan. Your support will help one of them achieve their dreams. Any little amount donated will help!

Now let me introduce you to the finalists!

Caitlyn Casson is an emerging dancer/choreographer with a passion for contemporary movement and a desire to develop herself as a global artist via internationally diverse, artistic endeavors. She recently graduated from the University of South Florida, Summa Cum Laude with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in modern dance performance and a minor is Psychology. While at USF, she had the immense pleasure of working with, and performing repertoire by distinguished artists Bill T. Jones, Doug Varone and Talley Beatty. She was also able to study extensively with USF professors Michael Foley, John Parks, Paula Nunez, Andrew Carroll, Jeanne Travers and Lynn Wimmer. She has spent time in Australia, New Zealand, Paris and Israel, dancing, choreographing and investigating her art form. Most recently, she performed in Edinburgh, Scotland as part of the 2012 Edinburgh International Fringe Festival. She is currently based in the Philadelphia area working as a freelance artist and yoga instructor.

J. Amber Kao, a native of Kansas City, MO, recently graduated from the University of Michigan with a Master of Fine Arts degree in dance performance. As a choreographer, improviser, and dance artists she has presented work and collaborated with artists in Italy, Portugal, New York, and various other states within the USA. Recently, she presented her interdisciplinary research between music and dance at CORD (The Congress on Research in Dance) and at the 2nd International Sound and Gesture Forum in Lisbon, Portugal. Ms. Kao has participated at numerous dance festivals including the American Dance Festival, ProDanza Italia, and Bates Dance Festival. Ms. Kao began her artistic studies as a pianist, and graduated with highest honors from the University of Michigan, under the tutelage of Dr. Logan Skelton. Throughout her undergraduate training, she also studied violin performance with Aaron Berofsky. She has performed in master classes and given solo performances on both piano and violin in Italy, New York, Michigan, Missouri and South Carolina. Ms. Kao has a strong interest in teaching and outreach, and is on faculty at the Faber Piano Institute. She directs her own private music studio where she teaches private and group lessons as well as master classes. Ms. Kao has a strong interest in interdisciplinary collaboration across all art genres, and at present, uses her background as a musician and dancer to explore points of intersection between these disciplines.

Jul Kostelancik is a Seattle based choreographer, performer, researcher, adventurer, and innovator. She investigates movement aesthetics from a philosophical inquiry to explore the depths of human relationships and how we, as humans, evolve. Jul graduated Magna Cum Laude with a BFA in Modern Dance from Texas Christian University. While at TCU, she performed works choreographed by Carrie Hanson, Robert Battle, Christian von Howard, Susan Douglas Roberts, among others. Jul earned numerous academic and artistic grants and scholarships including the TCU Nordan Fine Arts Award, and the TCU Scholarship for Academic Excellence, among others. Jul is currently a company member of Lingo Productions, under the fearless direction of KT Niehoff. Jul’s recent choreography, “time...of an excerpt,” and, “Aesthetics in Motion,” earned her recognition with an “Emerging Choreographer Award” and named her a Paul and Judy Andrews Scholar, respectively. Jul has been invited to present work at numerous festivals throughout the United States. She continues to develop ideas, conceptualize movement, and generate choreography as a current Artist in Residence at 10 degrees Art Space.

The tentative dates for the 2013 event are June 30-July 21. Participants will create a new work for public performance. The concerts will be held at Tsoying High School on campus, in the main theater, on July 20th and 21st.  The IYCP is supported by the National Culture and Arts Foundation, the Bureau Culture Affairs Kaohsiung City Government, and the Chin-Lin Foundation for Culture and Arts in Taiwan.

THE THREE FINALIST, WDA-A, & IYCP THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!


The above video was shared by Eddie Lin, a participant in the 2011 IYCP.
