story:
What is Team Pointless?

Team Pointless is a super secret society. Team Pointless is an exclusive, luxurious social club. Team Pointless is your new raison d'être. Team Pointless is the future.

But mostly, TEAM POINTLESS is Pointless Theatre's brand new membership program; it's a chance for you to join a community of unique individuals who are dedicated to supporting the artistic mission of your favorite DC puppet theatre company in a truly deep and sustainable way. With six levels of membership, starting at only $50, you can become a founding team member and receive wonderful rewards ranging from a sweet button (to show off your Pointless pride!), to a free Pointless T-shirt, to tickets to opening night of this season's shows, to a tea party with our lovely and talented co-Artistic Directors.

And no matter which level you choose, you will be endowed with the great satisfaction of knowing that your tax-deductible contribution will go towards helping Pointless do what it does best-- bringing bold, visceral and affordable puppet spectacles to the DC Metropolitan Area.

Your Membership Buys...

$35 - A gorgeous gallon of paint!

$50 - Buys all the materials for a single puppet in Sleeping Beauty: A Puppet Ballet

$100 - Covers the full operating cost of a workshop process for a new Pointless show

$200 - Pays the rent for our rehearsal space for Cab Calloway's Minnie the Moocher

$300 - Pays the stipend of one of our amazing performers

$600 - Buys all the costumes for Cab Calloway's Minnie the Moocher

$1000 - Covers the cost of materials needed for the scenery of Sleeping Beauty: A Puppet Ballet

$4000 - Pays the stipends of our 7-piece Jazz Band in Cab Calloway's Minnie the Moocher

$10,000 - Covers all expenses of Sleeping Beauty: A Puppet Ballet

$35,000 - Pays the salary of a full-time Pointless staff member

More On Levels and Rewards

Cheerleader - $10

Show your support for Pointless and Team Pointless Members and earn yourself a shout out on Facebook!

Silly - $50+

  • Team Pointless button
  • Public acknowledgment on our annual donor roll
  • Monthly Team Pointless email updates
  • Support for Pointless in a deep, sustainable way

Wacky - $100+

All rewards at the Silly level, plus--

  • Food or drink coupons
  • See shows with Pointless
  • Advanced ticket sales

Crazy - $250+

All rewards at the Wacky level, plus--

  • Premium seating for Pointless shows
  • Signed Pointless poster/program
  • Invitations to exclusive events
  • Discounts on merchandise

Absurd - $500+

All rewards at the Crazy level, plus--

  • Invitations to open rehearsals
  • Free Pointless T-Shirt
  • Personalized Pointless artwork
  • Tickets for you and a guest to one Pointless show

Berserk - $1000+

All rewards at the Absurd level, plus--

  • Backstage tour of a Pointless Show
  • Tickets for you and a guest to both season shows
  • Tea with the Artistic Directors
  • Invitations to VIP receptions

Pointless - $5000+

All rewards at the Berserk level, plus--

  • Candlelight supper with Pointless Theatre
  • Tickets for you and a guest to any night of any Pointless show

(tickets and premium seating subject to availability)

--- All memberships are valid from 10/1/2013-09/30/2014 ---

More Ways to Support Pointless

  • Share this campaign all over your facebook, twitter, tumblr, and letter to your Granny.
  • Come see our shows! Cab Calloway's Minnie the Moocher opens January 3rd, 2014 and Sleeping Beauty: A Puppet Ballet will be presented as part of the Mead Theatre Lab Program in April, 2014.
  • Send us a present! Check out our wish list to see which specific items we're hoping to acquire this season.
About Pointless Theatre

Pointless Theatre is dedicated to creating bold, visceral and affordable spectacles that gleefully smash the boundaries between puppetry theatre dance music and the visual arts. Through our work we excite a passion for adventurous art in the nation's capital and nurture a diverse, active and inspired audience.

Send us a present! Check out our wish list to see which specific items we're hoping to acquire this season.

Through our work we excite a passion for adventurous art in the nation's capital and nurture a diverse, active and inspired audience.

story:
WE REACHED OUR NUMBER ONE GOAL: WE'LL BE IN NEW YORK WITH "Neighbors"!!! ---> http://www.inscenany.com/festival-2014/events-2014/neighbors

VAI ALLA VERSIONE ITALIANA DELLA CAMPAGNA--->Neighbors_Campagna Italiana on Vimeo

---> guarda la versione sottotitolata in Italiano // watch the version with Italian subtitles: https://vimeo.com/89072634

ABOUT “NEIGHBORS” // A PROPOSITO DI "NEIGHBORS"

We like to describe it as a journey into urban adversities, absurd situations and delicate solitudes, experienced by two italian immigrants in New York City. Petra and Leonardo, these are their names, discover themselves in NYC, as neighbors. They decide to open their doors to one another and get a closer look into each other's lives. They are opposite in terms of way of living, but they have something very important in common: they are both diasporic souls, products of a generation with no sure values, jobs and sentimental relationships. And they are both in NYC.

Through this anti romantic comedy, you follow their brilliant and often funny dialogues, sharing their perspectives on sex, relationships and work. //

Ci piace descrivere “Neighbors” come un viaggio verso avventure urbane, situazioni assurde e intime solitudini, vissute da due immigrati italiani a New York. Petra e Leonardo, questi sono i nomi dei protagonisti, si incontrano come vicini a New York. Entrambi decidono di aprire le loro porte e di sbirciare nella vita dell'altro. Sono agli antipodi in quanto a stile di vita, ma hanno qualcosa di molto importante in comune: sono entrambi animi in fuga, prodotti di una generazione senza una sicura stabilità rispetto a valori, lavori e  amori. E poi sono entrambi a NYC...

Nel corso di questa commedia anti-romantica, seguirete il loro scambi, spesso brillanti e divertenti, affezionandovi alla loro prospettiva sul sesso, sulle relazioni d'amore e sui lavori.


BEHIND “NEIGHBORS”

Many great love stories are born from friendships, but is this the case? Or, to put it in a better way, is a romantic relationship what Petra and Leo really need now? Or is it a sense of family? What are these two character looking for in each other?

It's very difficult to find the answer. You'll have to see the show to understand the nature of their relationship... Our point is to make you reflect about friendship, love and family. And about the thousands different ways a honest relationship could go! There is a delicate and fine line between all these different ways. With “Neighbors” we tell their story, that tries to be personal and universal at the same time . //

Svariate importanti storie d'amore sono nate in seguito ad un rapporto di amicizia: ma in questo caso? O meglio, Petra e Leonardo hanno davvero bisogno di una relazione d'amore in questo momento? O forse è di un senso di famiglia? Cosa cercano questi personaggi l'uno nell'altro?

E' davvero difficile trovare un risposta. Dovete vedere lo spettacolo, per capire la natura di questo rapporto...Quello che cerchiamo di fare, è far riflettere sull'amicizia, l'amore e la famiglia. E sulle migliaia di strade che un rapporto tra due persone può imboccare. Esiste un delicato confine tra tutte queste possibili strade. Con “Neighbors” raccontiamo il loro percorso, che aspira ad essere, allo stesso tempo, personale ed universale.

HOW DID THE PROJECT START? // ORIGINI DEL PROGETTO

The show naturally has been developed in parallel to our real diasporic life.

In 2012 the actors and playwrights, Irene Turri and Francesco Meola, moved to New York, where they experienced a lot of adventures - the source of inspiration of the show. In 2013 they met the director Ilaria Ambrogi who said:

"this play spoke of us, of all of us. Even in all our different lifestyles or habits, it speaks of us in a profound way: of our sense of family and of our lack of it. Of our struggle in being able to commit or love in a mature way, and our infinite capacity for love. It speaks about our generation, especially of us who live overseas."

So she decided to direct the play, becoming the third parent of this project.

After many and many drafts, and after months and months of rehearsal in the little Ilaria's place in NYC, they involved a whole crew of very talented artists and friends, whose collaborations were fundamental to formalize the project.

So, step by step, they created “Neighbors” and a little and lovely family behind it.

In an overall perspective, these different paths could not help to cross each other.  We are inevitably connected since we share the same goals, dreams, struggles and feelings as emigrated young talents. //

Il progetto è nato in parallelo alle nostre vite migranti. Nel 2012 gli attori e autori del testo, Irene Turri e Francesco Meola, si sono spostati a New York dove hanno vissuto una caterva di avventure, vera fonte di ispirazione dello spettacolo. Nel 2013 hanno incontrato la regista Ilaria Ambrogi che disse:

“Questo spettacolo parla di noi, di tutti noi. Nonostante i nostri diversi stili di vita e abitudini, lo spettacolo ci rispecchia nel profondo: nel nostro senso di famiglia e nella sua assenza. Del nostro sforzo di impegnarci e amare in maniera matura, e della infinità predisposizione all'amore. Parla della nostra generazione, in particolar modo di chi vive al di là dell'oceano.” (La citazione è stata veramente registrata in un giorno afoso di luglio, su uno dei tavolini verdi di Union Square, verso le 5.30 PM)

Così ha deciso di dirigere questo progetto, divenendo a pieno titolo il suo terzo papà/mamma.

Dopo svariate versioni e svariati mesi di prove all'interno del piccolo appartamento di Ilaria a New York, i tre si sono avvalsi di un gruppo di talentuosi artisti e amici, la cui collaborazione si è rivelata fondamentale per dare forma compiuta al progetto.

Passo dopo passo, hanno creato “Neighbors”, dietro a cui è cresciuta una piccola ma amorevole famiglia.

In una prospettiva più ampia, i loro percorsi non potevano non incrociarsi. Siamo inevitabilmente legati, in quanto condividiamo obiettivi, sogni, battaglie e emozioni da talenti emigrati / cervelli in fuga.


WHY  TO DONATE? // PERCHE' DONARE?

The money you donate allows us to make true and possible this project we initiated almost 2 years ago. We strongly believe in our show: hilarious, personal and emotional. And the audience can really sympathize with Petra and Leonado. Talking about their life abroad, we have a chance to give a voice to many young italians and foreigners who live abroad. We believe that everyone could be one day an immigrant, like Petra and Leonardo, or feel the same sense of solitude, family, desire of happiness.

To conclude, “Neighbors” is a show born between two continents, our goal is to spread it as much as we can. //

Il denaro che donerete ci permetterà di realizzare un progetto che abbiamo iniziato oramai quasi due anni fa. Crediamo profondamente in questo spettacolo: spassoso, personale ed emotivo. E il pubblico potrà davvero simpatizzare con Petra e Leonardo. Inoltre, parlando della vita all'estero, abbiamo l'opportunità di dare voce ai giovani italiani e stranieri che vivono all'estero. Riteniamo che, un giorno, chiunque potrebbe emigrare o provare lo stesso senso di solitudine, di esigenza di famiglia e desiderio di felicità.

Infine, “Neighbors”  è uno spettacolo nato fra due continenti: la nostra speranza è intercontinentale. Speriamo di diffonderlo il più possibile. 


WHAT ARE OUR COSTS?

In April and May 2014 the show will be performed in Italy (Padoa, Milan and Rome). After that first italian tour, our final destination will be performing “Neighbors” in NYC during season 2014/2015. Of course the show will be in Italian in Italy and in English in U.S. So, we have calculated 5000 dollars to give birth to Neighbors”. We know it's a big amount of money and we are ambitious, but it's not simple to create a show between two continents without a rich production to cover all the expenses. And for this reason we really need your help!

Costs that you are contributing toward include:

  • a part of the flight from NY to Italy (and of course to come back!)

  • the set design, the costumes, the space to rehearse (Ilaria's place is so cool, but a bit tiny)

  • the people who are working on this project: set designer, musicians, light designer, cinematographer, camera operator, graphic designer. At least, if it is possible, the director and the actors.

  • the transportation between the different cities (by car and train)

  • the urban transportation and the normal expenses of a tournee.

  • the rights for the music and for the play.

  • And we hope to find in every theatre a couch, the fundamental set design of our show, without which we cannot perform...so we are optimistic, but actually we are not sure about that possibility!

A LOT OF PERKS FOR YOU! //

In aprile e maggio 2014, lo spettacolo verrà portato in scena in Italia (Padova, Milano e Roma). Dopo questo primo tour italiano, la nostra destinazione finale sarà  New York, nel corso della stagione 2014/2015. Per questo lo spettacolo verrà recitato in italiano in Italia e in inglese in America. Perciò, abbiamo stimato 5000 dollari per dar vita al nostro spettacolo. Siamo consapevoli che si tratta di una somma ingente e che il progetto è molto ambizioso: non è affatto semplice creare uno spettacolo tra due continenti, senza una ricca produzione alle spalle che copra le spese. Proprio per questo motivo abbiamo bisogno del vostro aiuto!

I costi a cui state contribuendo includono:

  • una parte del viaggio d'areo da NY all'Italia (e ovviamente il seguente ritorno)
  • la scenografia, i costumi, lo spazio dove poter provare (la casa di Ilaria è davvero cool ma un po' troppo piccola)
  • Le persone che stanno lavorando dietro a questo progetto: la scenografa, i musicisti, il light designer, la regista video, il primo operatore video, la graphic designer, Infine, qualora si riesca, la regista e gli attori.
  • I viaggi tra le varie città (via treno e via macchina)
  • I mezzi di trasporto in città e le normali spese di tournée 
  • I diritti per le musiche e per il testo
  • Inoltre, per ogni città e teatro in cui andremo, speriamo di trovare un divano da usare: per noi è davvero importante, perchè è l'elemento essenziale della nostra scenografia, senza cui lo spettacolo non si può fare. Siamo ottimisti, ma non completamente sicuri che questa eventualità si realizzi.

Inoltre...

...UN SACCO DI FANTASTICI EXTRA BENEFICI PER TE!


OTHERS WAYS YOU CAN HELP\GET INVOLVED

Were you asking yourself if there are other ways to help “Neighbors” if you can't contribute to the campaign?

Please share this campaign on your Facebook and Twitter accounts, and spread the word to friends and family personally or through email if you believe in what we are doing.

Your support goes a long way when you spread it to your circle!

THANK YOU! //

ALTRI MODI (STRAGRADITI) PER AIUTARCI O PARTECIPARE ALLA DIFFUSIONE

Vi sarete forse chiesti se ci sono altri modi per aiutare “Neighbors”, non potendo contribuire alla campagna economicamente?

Per favore, condividete la nostra campagna sul vostro profilo Facebook e sul vostro account Twitter. Spargete la notizia ad amici e parenti personalmente o tramite una mail, se credete in ciò che stiamo facendo. 

Il vostro supporto sarà enormemente maggiore se la notizia verrà diffusa nella vostra cerchia di conoscenze!


POST SCRIPTUM: WHO WE ARE

Ilaria Ambrogi is a New York based Italian actress and director. In Rome, after her training at Teatro Azione, she starred in different theater productions including "Peter Pan" at Teatro Vascello. In 2007 she wrote and performed her first one-woman show, "The Echo", a political denunciation on violence against women, at Teatro dell'Orologio, in Rome. In New York she trained with Susan Batson and worked in numerous theater and film productions (including her one-woman show "Superstars" , directed by Susan Batson). She is now part of the YoungKIT (Kairos Italy Theater), a theater company directed by Laura Caparrotti.

Irene Turri was born in Verona, Italy, and graduated in Acting at the Accademia dei Filodrammatici, Milan.  After training with various internationally renowed teachers and directors, Irene collected a vast working experience in the Italian theater circuit. She also worked at the Avignon Theatre Festival in Romeo Castellucci's production of Dante's "Paradiso". Since her arrival in New York, Irene has appeared in two short movies for NYFA, a nationwide TV commercial and two fashion-videos for SVA. Also she loves to be the black swan of Stand-up Comedy as the only Italian stand-up comedienne on the NYC comedy scene. She is now a proud member of the International company YoungKIT, directed by Laura Caparrotti.

Francesco Meola was born in Milan. He has one degree in Italian Literature and one in Acting at the Accademia dei Filodrammatici. In NYC he specialized at the Lee Strasberg Institute. He played shakesperian roles like Romeo and Bassanio, and he worked in more than other 20 plays as “Lucifer Effect”, “Fires” and recently in “The Decameron”. He took part in several shortmovies, commercials and shows for kids. He is also a writer (scuolabarnabooth.wordpress.com). He has two companies: Oyes and YoungKIT. He believes in bridges, not in walls.

"NEIGHBORS": THE CREW 

Director - Ilaria Ambrogi 

Actor and Playwrights - Irene Turri and Francesco Meola 

Music Composer - Paolo Tomaselli

The Band - Paolo Tomaselli (guitar), Alessio Romano (Drums), Jared Henderson(Bass)

Set Designer - Luana Baglì 

Graphic Designer - Elena Mazzi

Video Cinematographer - Elena Cappanera

First Camera Operator - Angelo Vasta

Photographer - Emilio Vavarella

Light Designer (Milan) - Daniele Crasti 

English Translation Reviewer - Carlotta Brentan
story_txt:
WE REACHED OUR NUMBER ONE GOAL: WE'LL BE IN NEW YORK WITH "Neighbors"!!! ---> http://www.inscenany.com/festival-2014/events-2014/neighborsVAI ALLA VERSIONE ITALIANA DELLA CAMPAGNA--->Neighbors_Campagna Italiana on Vimeo---> guarda la versione sottotitolata in Italiano // watch the version with Italian subtitles: https://vimeo.com/89072634ABOUT “NEIGHBORS” // A PROPOSITO DI "NEIGHBORS"We like to describe it as a journey into urban adversities, absurd situations and delicate solitudes, experienced by two italian immigrants in New York City. Petra and Leonardo, these are their names, discover themselves in NYC, as neighbors. They decide to open their doors to one another and get a closer look into each other's lives. They are opposite in terms of way of living, but they have something very important in common: they are both diasporic souls, products of a generation with no sure values, jobs and sentimental relationships. And they are both in NYC.Through this anti romantic comedy, you follow their brilliant and often funny dialogues, sharing their perspectives on sex, relationships and work. //Ci piace descrivere “Neighbors” come un viaggio verso avventure urbane, situazioni assurde e intime solitudini, vissute da due immigrati italiani a New York. Petra e Leonardo, questi sono i nomi dei protagonisti, si incontrano come vicini a New York. Entrambi decidono di aprire le loro porte e di sbirciare nella vita dell'altro. Sono agli antipodi in quanto a stile di vita, ma hanno qualcosa di molto importante in comune: sono entrambi animi in fuga, prodotti di una generazione senza una sicura stabilità rispetto a valori, lavori e  amori. E poi sono entrambi a NYC...
Nel corso di questa commedia anti-romantica, seguirete il loro scambi, spesso brillanti e divertenti, affezionandovi alla loro prospettiva sul sesso, sulle relazioni d'amore e sui lavori.BEHIND “NEIGHBORS”Many great love stories are born from friendships, but is this the case? Or, to put it in a better way, is a romantic relationship what Petra and Leo really need now? Or is it a sense of family? What are these two character looking for in each other?It's very difficult to find the answer. You'll have to see the show to understand the nature of their relationship... Our point is to make you reflect about friendship, love and family. And about the thousands different ways a honest relationship could go! There is a delicate and fine line between all these different ways. With “Neighbors” we tell their story, that tries to be personal and universal at the same time . //Svariate importanti storie d'amore sono nate in seguito ad un rapporto di amicizia: ma in questo caso? O meglio, Petra e Leonardo hanno davvero bisogno di una relazione d'amore in questo momento? O forse è di un senso di famiglia? Cosa cercano questi personaggi l'uno nell'altro?
E' davvero difficile trovare un risposta. Dovete vedere lo spettacolo, per capire la natura di questo rapporto...Quello che cerchiamo di fare, è far riflettere sull'amicizia, l'amore e la famiglia. E sulle migliaia di strade che un rapporto tra due persone può imboccare. Esiste un delicato confine tra tutte queste possibili strade. Con “Neighbors” raccontiamo il loro percorso, che aspira ad essere, allo stesso tempo, personale ed universale.HOW DID THE PROJECT START? // ORIGINI DEL PROGETTOThe show naturally has been developed in parallel to our real diasporic life.In 2012 the actors and playwrights, Irene Turri and Francesco Meola, moved to New York, where they experienced a lot of adventures - the source of inspiration of the show. In 2013 they met the director Ilaria Ambrogi who said:"this play spoke of us, of all of us. Even in all our different lifestyles or habits, it speaks of us in a profound way: of our sense of family and of our lack of it. Of our struggle in being able to commit or love in a mature way, and our infinite capacity for love. It speaks about our generation, especially of us who live overseas."So she decided to direct the play, becoming the third parent of this project.After many and many drafts, and after months and months of rehearsal in the little Ilaria's place in NYC, they involved a whole crew of very talented artists and friends, whose collaborations were fundamental to formalize the project.So, step by step, they created “Neighbors” and a little and lovely family behind it.In an overall perspective, these different paths could not help to cross each other.  We are inevitably connected since we share the same goals, dreams, struggles and feelings as emigrated young talents. //Il progetto è nato in parallelo alle nostre vite migranti. Nel 2012 gli attori e autori del testo, Irene Turri e Francesco Meola, si sono spostati a New York dove hanno vissuto una caterva di avventure, vera fonte di ispirazione dello spettacolo. Nel 2013 hanno incontrato la regista Ilaria Ambrogi che disse:
“Questo spettacolo parla di noi, di tutti noi. Nonostante i nostri diversi stili di vita e abitudini, lo spettacolo ci rispecchia nel profondo: nel nostro senso di famiglia e nella sua assenza. Del nostro sforzo di impegnarci e amare in maniera matura, e della infinità predisposizione all'amore. Parla della nostra generazione, in particolar modo di chi vive al di là dell'oceano.” (La citazione è stata veramente registrata in un giorno afoso di luglio, su uno dei tavolini verdi di Union Square, verso le 5.30 PM)
Così ha deciso di dirigere questo progetto, divenendo a pieno titolo il suo terzo papà/mamma.
Dopo svariate versioni e svariati mesi di prove all'interno del piccolo appartamento di Ilaria a New York, i tre si sono avvalsi di un gruppo di talentuosi artisti e amici, la cui collaborazione si è rivelata fondamentale per dare forma compiuta al progetto.
Passo dopo passo, hanno creato “Neighbors”, dietro a cui è cresciuta una piccola ma amorevole famiglia.
In una prospettiva più ampia, i loro percorsi non potevano non incrociarsi. Siamo inevitabilmente legati, in quanto condividiamo obiettivi, sogni, battaglie e emozioni da talenti emigrati / cervelli in fuga.WHY  TO DONATE? // PERCHE' DONARE?The money you donate allows us to make true and possible this project we initiated almost 2 years ago. We strongly believe in our show: hilarious, personal and emotional. And the audience can really sympathize with Petra and Leonado. Talking about their life abroad, we have a chance to give a voice to many young italians and foreigners who live abroad. We believe that everyone could be one day an immigrant, like Petra and Leonardo, or feel the same sense of solitude, family, desire of happiness.To conclude, “Neighbors” is a show born between two continents, our goal is to spread it as much as we can. //Il denaro che donerete ci permetterà di realizzare un progetto che abbiamo iniziato oramai quasi due anni fa. Crediamo profondamente in questo spettacolo: spassoso, personale ed emotivo. E il pubblico potrà davvero simpatizzare con Petra e Leonardo. Inoltre, parlando della vita all'estero, abbiamo l'opportunità di dare voce ai giovani italiani e stranieri che vivono all'estero. Riteniamo che, un giorno, chiunque potrebbe emigrare o provare lo stesso senso di solitudine, di esigenza di famiglia e desiderio di felicità.
Infine, “Neighbors”  è uno spettacolo nato fra due continenti: la nostra speranza è intercontinentale. Speriamo di diffonderlo il più possibile. WHAT ARE OUR COSTS?In April and May 2014 the show will be performed in Italy (Padoa, Milan and Rome). After that first italian tour, our final destination will be performing “Neighbors” in NYC during season 2014/2015. Of course the show will be in Italian in Italy and in English in U.S. So, we have calculated 5000 dollars to give birth to Neighbors”. We know it's a big amount of money and we are ambitious, but it's not simple to create a show between two continents without a rich production to cover all the expenses. And for this reason we really need your help!Costs that you are contributing toward include:
a part of the flight from NY to Italy (and of course to come back!)
the set design, the costumes, the space to rehearse (Ilaria's place is so cool, but a bit tiny)
the people who are working on this project: set designer, musicians, light designer, cinematographer, camera operator, graphic designer. At least, if it is possible, the director and the actors.
the transportation between the different cities (by car and train)
the urban transportation and the normal expenses of a tournee.
the rights for the music and for the play.
And we hope to find in every theatre a couch, the fundamental set design of our show, without which we cannot perform...so we are optimistic, but actually we are not sure about that possibility!
A LOT OF PERKS FOR YOU! //In aprile e maggio 2014, lo spettacolo verrà portato in scena in Italia (Padova, Milano e Roma). Dopo questo primo tour italiano, la nostra destinazione finale sarà  New York, nel corso della stagione 2014/2015. Per questo lo spettacolo verrà recitato in italiano in Italia e in inglese in America. Perciò, abbiamo stimato 5000 dollari per dar vita al nostro spettacolo. Siamo consapevoli che si tratta di una somma ingente e che il progetto è molto ambizioso: non è affatto semplice creare uno spettacolo tra due continenti, senza una ricca produzione alle spalle che copra le spese. una parte del viaggio d'areo da NY all'Italia (e ovviamente il seguente ritorno)
la scenografia, i costumi, lo spazio dove poter provare (la casa di Ilaria è davvero cool ma un po' troppo piccola)
Le persone che stanno lavorando dietro a questo progetto: la scenografa, i musicisti, il light designer, la regista video, il primo operatore video, la graphic designer, Infine, qualora si riesca, la regista e gli attori.

I mezzi di trasporto in città e le normali spese di tournée 
I diritti per le musiche e per il testo
Inoltre, per ogni città e teatro in cui andremo, speriamo di trovare un divano da usare: per noi è davvero importante, perchè è l'elemento essenziale della nostra scenografia, senza cui lo spettacolo non si può fare. Siamo ottimisti, ma non completamente sicuri che questa eventualità si realizzi.
Inoltre...
...UN SACCO DI FANTASTICI EXTRA BENEFICI PER TE!OTHERS WAYS YOU CAN HELP\GET INVOLVEDWere you asking yourself if there are other ways to help “Neighbors” if you can't contribute to the campaign?Please share this campaign on your Facebook and Twitter accounts, and spread the word to friends and family personally or through email if you believe in what we are doing.Your support goes a long way when you spread it to your circle!THANK YOU! //ALTRI MODI (STRAGRADITI) PER AIUTARCI O PARTECIPARE ALLA DIFFUSIONE

story:
Contemporary Inter-Tribal Workshop Laboratory is a project created within the Coopdanza initiative “Eagle/Condor/Swap/Program”aiming to experiment and search languages and tools to better reach Indian and non-Indian new generations. Also we are exploring the exchange between contemporary and Pow Wow dances, History, Mythology, Music, the meaning of Regalia design and the reality of being urban Indians.

How does this dance relates to the Two Spirit Community?

As two spirits we humbly sacrifice for our people in numerous ways much like rainbow crow did for the two legged, four legged, and winged ones.  This specific bird does not physically show a difference between male or female so choreography for this dance can be a mix of both genders.  Today these birds have negative stigmas attached to them much like our two spirit community has experienced amongst people.  This dance is one way in which we can restore honor to our two spirits.  Today the crow hop is performed by almost every dance category at powwows and so it can be used to bridge the gap between the two-spirit and non-two spirit communities. 

In our native culture we identify ourselves through our (warrior spirit) regalia image.  The designs we wear have stories sometimes a vision or dream (identity through design and medicines warrior or protection from enemies) and are significant for many reasons which these are important to the storyline.

The story of Rainbow Crow is one of humility.  For this birds sacrifice we give thanks to our relative the crow.  As indigenous people our resilience to respect nature and its entirety is found within our DNA.  We are protectors of earth and all its interconnected creatures as our belief is we are all related.

The message of the story contributes to the community at large for people who struggle to identity with their Indigenous cultures because of all the stereotyped associated with "Indigenous." And to those who are powerless in their position, whichever circumstances they're coming from.

Modern civilization discriminates people for being Indian, for being gay, for being brown, for being ugly, for being fat or poor and specially for disagreeing. Here is a great opportunity to teach respect, encourage tolerance, to fight discrimination and learn to appreciate everyone!


We are raising funds to cover the costs of the showing of the work in progress the last week of November:
  • Rehearsal Space: 3 months
  • Story-Telling and Lyrics Creation and Production
  • Regalia and Costumes: Design and Production
  • Dancers, Writers and Choreographers Stipends
  • Marketing and Audience Development
  • 3D/Photography/Videography Production

Contemporary Inter-Tribal Workshop Laboratory is a total exchange and creative process of 6 months. The final work will be shown at the beginning of spring around March 2015.

story:
My name's Harry Watermeier -- I'm an actor and theatre practitioner based here in Philly. I wanted to tell you a little bit about a project I'm currently working on -- a pretty thrilling devised piece entitled Escape Mephistopheles.

WHAT IS ESCAPE MEPHISTOPHELES? 
I'm currently collaborating with a tremendous group of theatre artists to re-imagine Christopher Marlowe's Doctor Faustus as a highly physical action/horror adventure. We've infused the Faustus story -- which explores the gigantic and perpetually relevant concepts of pride, death, power, religion, ceremony, beauty and the afterlife -- with the synth-driven propulsion and energy of a genre film.

By fusing Marlowe's staggering text with our unique areas of expertise as theatre practitioners, then filtering that strange amalgam through the aesthetic influences currently kicking around in our brains, we're sure to conjure a Faustus that is rousing, playful, and wholly unique.

CAST/CREW
Escape Mephistopheles boasts the cast and crew of the well received 2014 Fringe Festival production of Fando y Lis. Here's what we're doing this time around:

Emily Schuman - Actor/Devisor
Caleb Murphy -  Actor/Devisor
Harry Watermeier - Actor/Devisor
Leslie Miller - Actor/Devisor
Dane Eissler - Designer
Fred Brown - Composer
Drew Evans - Composer

HOW MUCH CA$H IS THIS GOING TO TAKE?
The break down of our funding needs is fairly simple. We're currently asking for $1,650.00.

Funds will be distributed to the following areas:

$1,000.00 = Cost of rehearsal and performance space rental.
$450.00 = Artist Salary
$200.00 = Props/Set

CHECK OUT THOSE PERKS!
If you're interested in throwing some cash our way, please take a look at our Perks. We're offering a number of unique and exciting prizes to our donors, that range from sending you a high five over your Facebook page, to making you a home cooked meal. A note about the Perk Titles: We've been watching a lot of John Carpenter movies these days -- which may hint at the kind of creative and aesthetic vaults we're currently looting -- and we're allowing his influence to contribute to the design of this campaign. We've named each perk after some of our favorite characters created by John Carpenter.

CHECK OUT OUR SHOW!

Escape Mephistopheles

Wednesday, May 13th at 7:30pm
Thursday, May 14th at 7:30pm
Friday, May 15th at 7:30pm & 9:00pm

Vox Populi (AUX SPACE)
319 North 11th Street
3rd Floor
Philadelphia, PA 19107

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP! 

Please help us get the word out by sharing this information with your friends and family! Like our page on Facebook, email it out, post about us on twitter; every little bit counts, so thank you!

Facebook Event Page Link https://www.facebook.com/events/864509563605350/

We really appreciate your time, attention, and consideration, and we can't wait to see you at the show.

CAST/CREWEscape Mephistopheles boasts the cast and crew of the well received 2014 Fringe Festival production of Fando y Lis. Here's what we're doing this time around: Emily Schuman - Actor/DevisorCaleb Murphy -  Actor/DevisorHarry Watermeier - Actor/Devisor Leslie Miller - Actor/DevisorDane Eissler - Designer Fred Brown - Composer Drew Evans - Composer HOW MUCH CA$H IS THIS GOING TO TAKE? The break down of our funding needs is fairly simple. We're currently asking for $1,650.00. Funds will be distributed to the following areas: $1,000.00 = Cost of rehearsal and performance space rental. $450.00 = Artist Salary$200.00 = Props/Set CHECK OUT THOSE PERKS! If you're interested in throwing some cash our way, please take a look at our Perks. We're offering a number of unique and exciting prizes to our donors, that range from sending you a high five over your Facebook page, to making you a home cooked meal. A note about the Perk Titles: We've been watching a lot of John Carpenter movies these days -- which may hint at the kind of creative and aesthetic vaults we're currently looting -- and we're allowing his influence to contribute to the design of this campaign. We've named each perk after some of our favorite characters created by John Carpenter. CHECK OUT OUR SHOW! Escape MephistophelesWednesday, May 13th at 7:30pm Thursday, May 14th at 7:30pm Friday, May 15th at 7:30pm & 9:00pm Vox Populi (AUX SPACE) 319 North 11th Street 3rd Floor Philadelphia, PA 19107 OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP! 
Please help us get the word out by sharing this information with your
 friends and family! Like our page on Facebook, email it out, post about
 us on twitter; every little bit counts, so thank you!
Facebook Event Page Link https://www.facebook.com/events/864509563605350/We really appreciate your time, attention, and consideration, and we can't wait to see you at the show.

story:
Exit Pursued by a Bear is looking to present it's 4th season of Free Shakespeare in the Park here on the Central Coast in Solvang and Pismo Beach. The funds raised through this campaign will go directly to securing the performance venues and making some repairs and improvements to our set. We are very passionate about this project and are grateful for any contributions we receive to help it reach fruition once again. Remember that no donation is too small and every little bit helps.

Also, if you cannot donate but would like to volunteer your time in any way towards this endeavor please let us know, and don't forget to like us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/exitpursuedbyabeartheatre.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Jon Christie. I grew up in Dallas, Texas and plunged into the theatre community in my early college years. At the age of 22 I wrote my first play, "Dream."

Since that time I have self-produced five of my original works in the Dallas area, and one original play in the Los Angeles area.

Now you might be thinking, "Well if you've produced on your own before, why do you need my help?" Well, now that I live in Los Angeles, the cost of producing theatre has gone up considerably. Also, I don't want to short-change this production. In order for this play to be taken seriously by critics and my surrounding theatre community, I want to pull out all the stops! A beautifully constructed set, a mesmerizing light show, and dazzling costume pieces will all dramatically enhance the theatre-going experience. And with your help, we can give "Happy No Year" the royal treatment!

What We Need & What You Get

I am raising $7500 so I can afford costumes, set materials, stage props, marketing, and the financial goliath that is the theatre venue.

This campagin will go beyond our production this 2014 holiday season - I plan to use the momentum to catapult us into the LA Fringe Festival next summer to continue keeping this play in the public eye! And who knows? Maybe we can even get a New York premiere with your help!

And don't worry, you won't be coming out of this empty handed should you decide to contribute! There are a number of unique perks and cool swag that can all be yours! Happy No Year mugs and T-Shirts, free tickets to the fully staged play in November & December, and even official producer credit are just a few examples of prizes we are giving out to those who donate! Be one of our April Fool supporters!

The Impact

"Happy No Year" is not just another one of my passion projects. This particular concept has the potential to be a staple in theatre communities all over the country. Community theatre is hungry for better quality Christmas/holiday plays, and everyone appreciates a good murder mystery. Put the two together and you have an unbeatable combination. And I want to ensure this play gets the opportunity to become that community staple.

The last play I produced in Los Angeles, "The Exotic Flavors of Bradley Copperfield," was also a by-product of funding received through Indiegogo supporters; and thanks to their generosity I was able to produce the play at The Complex off Santa Monica Blvd in Hollywood. We can do even more for "Happy No Year" with your contribution!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you simply cannot afford a $5 or $10 donation, don't worry! You can still help us out in a MAJOR way by forwarding this link to your friends! Help get the word out to as many people as possible! If you can't support us financially, at least support us socially!  Facebook, Twitter, Email Blast, the possibilities are endless!

Thank you for taking time out of your day to view this campaign. Have a wonderful day!

story:
Floyd Collins

Book by Tina Landau

Music and Lyrics by Adam Guettel

Additional Lyrics by Tina Landau

October 16 - October 19 in the Massman Theatre at USC

Our Company

Musical Theatre Repertory at the University of Southern California was established in 2005 and is dedicated to enriching students’ lives through the production of quality musical theatre. Our goal is to provide students with the opportunity to participate in musical theatre pieces supplementary to those produced by USC. Find us online at www.uscmtr.com for general info about the company, ticketing details, upcoming events, production stills, and even a few production videos! Thank you for supporting the arts and we can't wait to see you at our upcoming shows!

The Story

Floyd Collins is the true story of a cave explorer named Floyd who becomes trapped during one of his expeditions.  This musical follows Floyd and his family and friends as they come to terms with this catastrophic event.  Set in 1925 Kentucky, this show utilizes rustic, folk-like music in order to bring the audience into the world of the southern countryside.  


Our Production

One aspect of this script that we are exploring is the idea of hope and faithfulness.   From the moment Floyd first becomes trapped in the cave, he struggles to stay calm.  He clearly understands the gravity of the situation and and it becomes difficult for him to remain hopeful.  Other characters such as Floyd's brother Homer, Floyd's sister Nellie, his father, a neighboring kid, and even a news reporter named Miller struggle to maintain hope as well.  Despite their personal struggle to maintain hope, those close to Floyd also work to help Floyd keep his hopes up in an effort to remain faithful to him.  

As the story goes on, Floyd battles with fears of death and loneliness and even starts hallucinating about his escape. The play takes many moments to flash back to the earlier days of Floyd’s life with his brother Homer. These contrasting scenes show the hope and aspirations Floyd had for his life and serve to distract Floyd from his current situation. Everyone tries to keep Floyd occupied in an effort to help him stay hopeful. One of the most moving parts of this musical is the ability of everyone to put aside their own fears in order to maintain hope for Floyd’s escape. In trying situations, people sometimes have to shove emotions aside to keep the flame burning in someone else. Anyone can give in to despair or fear, but it takes a greater strength in order to keep fighting.  By focusing on the relationships between Floyd and the people outside of the cave in rehearsal, we hope to bring this theme of hopefulness to light for the audience.  

    Cast

    Floyd Collins: Kalev Rudolph
    Homer Collins: Patrick Wallace
    Nellie Collins: Arielle Fishman
    Miss Jane: Kimberlee Holland
    Lee Collins: Kevin Paley
    Skeets Miller: Austin Hammer
    Jewell Estes: Judd Yort
    Bee Doyle: Ezie Nguyen
    Ed Bishop: Chris Wodniak
    H.T. Carmichael: Parker Huseby
    Reporters: Clint Blakely, Henry Boyd, Nathan Heldman
    Cliff Roney: Massimo Napoli
    Dr. Hazlett: Aubrey Rhodes

    Production Team

    Director: Victoria Pearlman
    Music Director: Anthony Lucca
    Choreographer: Sarah Fanella
    Scenographer: G. Austin Allen
    Costume Designer: Marly Hall
    Sound Designer: Danielle Kisner
    Assistant Director: Ryan McRee
    Stage Manager: Lea Branyan
    Assistant Stage Manager: Caitlin Kilgore
    Associate Scenographer: Justus Bradshaw
    Lighting Associate: Liam Sterbinsky
    Assistant Costume Designer: Katie Hood
    Assistant Sound Designer: Jacob Magnin
    Producers: Alice Pollitt and Jackson Strike
    Technical Director: Justus Bradshaw
    Properties Master: Christina Lelon
    Poster Design: Liz Pearlman


      What We Need

      MTR is run exclusively by USC students and we receive no outside support from faculty.  Because our company is entirely student-run, every one of us puts in an enormous amount of time and effort in order to bring our productions to life. That being said, our financial resources are limited and we need help raising money in order for this production to reach its full potential.  We mainly need help making the technical aspects of the show as fulfilling as they can be.  Funds we raise will be used for lighting, set, props, sound, and costumes.  These design elements are vital not only in helping our production reach its full potential but also in providing design students with valuable production opportunities.  

      Other Ways You Can Help

      We hope to exceed $1,200 so please help us surpass our goal!

      Whether you can offer financial support or not, please join us in the telling of this story October 16th through 19th in the Massman Theatre. We look forward to seeing you. 

      You can also support us simply by spreading the word. Please share this page and find us on Facebook.

      We are always interested in getting other students involved in MTR. If you have any interest in joining our team, working on one of our shows, or getting some more information, shoot us an email at uscmtr@gmail.com.

      Also check out our website at www.uscmtr.com

      Thank you for supporting Musical Theatre Repertory!

      We are also very thankful for the support of the USC Undergraduate Student Government.

Other Ways You Can Help We hope to exceed $1,200 so please help us surpass our goal!

Whether you can offer financial support or not, please join us in the telling of this story October 16th through 19th in the Massman Theatre. We look forward to seeing you. 
You can also support us simply by spreading the word. Please share this page and find us on Facebook.
We are always interested in getting other students involved in MTR. If you have any interest in joining our team, working on one of our shows, or getting some more information, shoot us an email at uscmtr@gmail.com.
Also check out our website at www.uscmtr.com
Thank you for supporting Musical Theatre Repertory!
We are also very thankful for the support of the USC Undergraduate Student Government.

story:
We are Rhum and Clay, a touring theatre company that presents playful, physical work to a broad audience.

Thanks for watching this short video explaining why we need your help.

A Strange Wild Song is our second show as Rhum and Clay and we will be touring with it in the spring of 2013.

The show is about three abandoned children in a bombed-out French village during World War II. They encounter a lost American soldier and they form a friendship. In the present day, the soldier’s camera is discovered by an amateur archaeological society and with the soldier’s grandson, they attempt to discover exactly what happened. There’s lots of humour, silent comedy and general silliness, with some touching, sad bits too.

The show is performed by Julian Spooner, Matt Wells, Daniel Wilcox and Chris Harrisson. There’s also a live musical accompaniment by Laila Woozeer. Set design is by Alberta Jones, with technical operations on tour by Rob Stenson and Aella Jordan-Edge. We are produced by Sarah Wilson.

We first performed the production at Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2012 and it was a big success; we got some great reviews and frequently sold out during the run. We also did a residency with the show at the Bike Shed Theatre in Exeter last November, which was great and meant we could show our work to more audiences. Now we want to share A Strange Wild Song with audiences across the country. We’ll be performing in Bath, London, rural Devon and Cornwall, finishing up in Liverpool. We’ll also be performing a one-off of our previous show Shutterland in Hay-on-Wye.

All the dates for our tour are on our website: www.rhumandclay.com

What We Need & What You Get

The money from this project will go to van and car hire for the month we’re touring which means we’ll be able to get from A to B with all our set and show audiences a show we know they’ll love. There’s a lot of set and musical instruments to move around as we tour the show that’s why we need to hire a van and a car. We’ll be driving for a total of around 28 hours during the tour, sometimes going out to very rural areas that are difficult to reach. Touring a show is an expensive undertaking and there are countless things we have to pay for before we even get on the road. We already done a great deal of fundraising to cover these costs but we need some extra help to get there.

If you donate to this campaign, you'll receive a reward from us to say thank you. These range from a thank you on our website to free tickets and postcards from the tour to posters designed by talented illustrator Sandra Dieckmann.

If we don't reach the full goal, the money will still go towards the van and car hire, as even a small amount will help us get on the road.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for taking the time to watch this video and read this description. We are passioante about the theatre we make and want to share it with as many people as we possibly can, including some areas with less easy access to theatre. This will make a huge difference to the work we're doing and your support is greatly appreciated.

Rhum and Clay Theatre Company

story:
After two successful musicals at Wesleyan University, the team comes back together for their last hurrah. With Kayla's artistic eye, Simon's musical prowess, and Lily's headstrong direction, the people who brought you "The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee" and "Spring Awakening" are joining together one last time to put up their most ambitious musical yet - Avenue Q!  But this time, we need your help as the team expands to include actors, crew, pit, and... puppets!

Avenue Q is a raunchy musical comedy (complete with puppet sex, Gary Coleman, and a song called "Everyone's a Little Bit Racist") that follows a recent college graduate, named Princeton, as he finds his way through post-grad life. The main characters, including Princeton, are played by Sesame Street-style puppets! These puppets give the show its life, its humor, and its charm. But, like everything in life, they come with a price. So we're asking you - old fans, new fans, broadway hopefuls, tone-deaf observers, parents, friends, pets - to join our team and help bring these puppets to life by donating to the Avenue Q Puppet Gifts fund. Your donations will not go unnoticed - see the rewards section to the right to find out how we (and the puppets) will express our gratitude for whichever size donation you are able to give, as you help to further Wesleyan's vibrant theater community! 

Avenue Q will go up at Wesleyan University's Beckham Hall in Fayerweather on November 21st-23rd at 8pm. Admission is free!

If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to email Lily at slmartin@wesleyan.edu

Follow these links to see photos from our past two productions!

Spring Awakening - http://www.2ndstage.org/spring-awakening.html

The Spelling Bee - http://www.2ndstage.org/the-25th-annual-putnam-county-spelling-bee.html

story:
Short Summary

         Ouroboros Shadow Pictures was founded in 2013 by Alisa Javits and Adam Lipsky. Alisa is responsible for making the sculptural shadow art that is the creative material of the piece as well as the fabrication of all structural materials used. Adam is a musician and composer. He is responsible for the musical and sound elements of the show. Together they co-write and create the subjects and material of the pieces.

          Co-creators of the current piece "Vasilisa" include Max Judelson, Marlie Couto and Courtney Mazeika. Max is a musician and a composer. He and Adam have worked closely together for years. Marlie and Courtney are both dancers & choreographers. They have worked together extensively and bring their intimate knowledge of each others styles to the group.  All five performers have  previously participated in successful touring groups. 

           Performing at these FRINGE festivals will mark a substantial leap forward in the success of this project. This opportunity has pushed us to refine and expand our methods and structures. This is our first full length production. We have a larger screen, better equipment and the capacity to have more people involved in the collaborative process.

          By donating to this campaign you are helping this unique multi-media art ensemble to flourish.  The accomplishment of these new goals creates more  opportunities for growth including potential for more large scale performances, residencies and grants. With your help we will be able to continue the creative growth of this group.


Expenses

These are the expenses we need your help for:

      $500 - 1,800 mile round trip to British Columbia in our Van

      $750 - food stipend expense at $15/day x five performers for 10 days

      $500 - entry fee Victoria FRINGE festival

      $500 - entry fee Santa Cruz FRINGE festival

      $500 - van repair and maintenance 

      $125 - lodging expenses in Victoria for all five performers

      $1,000 - supplementary income for the performers $200/ person

      $1,000 - material investments in equipment and infrastructure 

      $300 - Indiegogo Fee's

With our gifts we hope to share the experience of being at the show. We hope to see you at one of the shows, but if you are unable to attend we will be filming. 

If we do not reach our entire goal, the money will be prioritized for travel, room and board expenses and whatever is left will go to the performers. We are hopeful that we will be able to do this right and accommodate everybody properly. 


Other Ways You Can Help

* If you know anyone in Santa Cruz or Victoria, please spread the word.

* If you know of any like-spirited groups, venues or organizations we would love to contact them.

They have worked together extensively and bring their intimate knowledge of each others styles to the group.  All five performers have  previously participated in successful touring groups.            Performing at these FRINGE festivals will mark a substantial leap forward in the success of this project. This opportunity has pushed us to refine and expand our methods and structures. This is our first full length production. We have a larger screen, better equipment and the capacity to have more people involved in the collaborative process.          By donating to this campaign you are helping this unique multi-media art ensemble to flourish.  The accomplishment of these new goals creates more  opportunities for growth including potential for more large scale performances, residencies and grants. With your help we will be able to continue the creative growth of this group.ExpensesThese are the expenses we need your help for:      $500 - 1,800 mile round trip to British Columbia in our Van      $750 - food stipend expense at $15/day x five performers for 10 days      $500 - entry fee Victoria FRINGE festival      $500 - entry fee Santa Cruz FRINGE festival      $500 - van repair and maintenance       $125 - lodging expenses in Victoria for all five performers      $1,000 - supplementary income for the performers $200/ person      $1,000 - material investments in equipment and infrastructure       $300 - Indiegogo Fee'sWith our gifts we hope to share the experience of being at the show. We hope to see you at one of the shows, but if you are unable to attend we will be filming. If we do not reach our entire goal, the money will be prioritized for travel, room and board expenses and whatever is left will go to the performers. We are hopeful that we will be able to do this right and accommodate everybody properly. Other Ways You Can Help* If you know anyone in Santa Cruz or Victoria, please spread the word.* If you know of any like-spirited groups, venues or organizations we would love to contact them.

story:
"We have a history of sorts." - The Pride, p. 76

Mortall Coile Theatre Company is the brainchild of Jesse R. Gephart, an actor/director/producer in Raleigh, NC. The first production was the acclaimed Nocturne by Adam Rapp in 2013.  

The Pride by Alexi Kaye Campbell marks the second production for the company and we could not be more excited to bring together this amazingly talented group of friends who haven't been on stage together since 2009.  

This show also re-connects Gephart and Ryan Brock; they first met in 2006, when they played Jamie and Ste in a production of Beautiful Thing by Jonathan Harvey. They went on to co-star in several productions, though they may best be remembered for playing Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold in columbinus by Stephen Karam & PJ Paparelli in 2007. Later, in 2012,  they were George and Lennie in Of Mice & Men, which Jesse also directed. The duo have garnered collective praise from both critics and audiences alike.


Theatre's Expensive, but You Can Be Rewarded!

We're not going to sugar coat it: we need $5,000.

Why that much? Because, quite simply, theatre is expensive.  Here are some of the things on which we will be spending our raised funds: 

  • Performance & Rental Space
  • Royalties
  • Set & Lights
  • Props
  • Costumes
  • Sound
  • Marketing/Publicity
We will use every penny donated to fulfill our budgets and make this the best possible show we can, in every aspect. Know that any extra funds left over after the show closes will be put in reserve and used for future Mortall Coile productions.
Why Should You Give? Because we need you! This project cannot happen without your help. We're also offering some really fun rewards for our donors. Here's a taste:
  • High fives
  • Discounted tickets
  • Listings in our Program and/or poster
  • Signed memorabilia 
  • Meet-and-greets
  • Invitations to rehearsals
  • AND MORE!
Every donor level comes with its own awesome set of rewards. Also included: the satisfaction of knowing you helped our dream become reality, as well as our unending gratitude.

Why THE PRIDE?

Jesse saw the off-Broadway production of this show in 2010 and it left a real impression on him. It's a show about love and betrayal; beyond that, it's a show about the history we grow out of. It's about how we take that history and use it - for good, and for bad - in our current lives.

The UK tour bills the show as: "Philip, Oliver and Sylvia exist in a complex love triangle which spans over half a century, living and loving simultaneously in 1958 and the present against a background of changing attitudes towards homosexuality. 

Past and present worlds grind together and melt apart, yet the future and its promise of sexual liberation remains ever elusive, as societal repression gives way to self-deception. 

The Pride is Alexi Kaye Campbell's hilarious and heart-felt landmark play about courage, compassion and the fear of loneliness in life’s journey towards self-discovery."

At the end of it all, the show strives to shed some light on this question: "What is the point of this stupid, painful life if not to be honest?  If not to stand up for what one is in the core of one's being?" (Campbell, The Pride, p. 50).


Risks & Challenges

With every endeavor, there is the possibility for failure. We all hope this doesn't happen. We will work tirelessly to ensure that we clear every hurdle that may arise. Your donations will help us overcome many of the obstacles we already see on our horizon.

Should we encounter unknown snags, we will band together and work for the best solution. We will ask for help when needed, and we will always act in the best interest of the production, its designers and cast, as well as those who funded us.


How Else Can You Help?

If you're unable to contribute monetarily, we understand. We just thank you for taking the time to check out our campaign. Please know that no contribution is too small! We will gladly accept any donation you are able to give.

If you feel inclined to help us spread the word via email, social media, or just telling your friends. Encourage them to check us out and to give if they can.  Every little bit helps!

story:
Our Story

We are a group of passionate young New York artists with a tongue-in-cheek political viewpoint of the world.  For info about each of us, click our photos at the bottom of the page.  We're trying to build something by and for the little people, who don't have a lot of money but have a lot of heart.

"The Alchemist" is a play by Ben Jonson, a man who went drinking with Shakespeare.  The play is still hilarious, and the satire still relevant, because greed doesn't change.  Nobody is scapegoated in the story; everyone is human and culpable, and you can't help loving them for it.  So here's our vision:

A full production of the play in Central Park and Battery Park (the financial district) in New York City.  Think buffoon, think clown, think street peddlers and magic.  The play is for the rich, the poor, the tourists, the locals - everyone and anyone who happens to pass by.  Inventive, accessible classical theater for all!

The Impact

Besides hearing and seeing one of the most hysterical and poetically perfect plays ever (top that, Shakespeare!), we're drawing a line between 400 year-old London and last year's Wall Street.  Jonson himself wrote that, "this pen did never aim to grieve, but better men."  We want to give everyone a hilarious, fun afternoon in the park.  We also want to make them think - to see the cycle that greed creates.  And to wonder if they've ever thought they could get something for nothing.


Unfortunately, "Nothing will come of nothing" as Ben Jonson's friend used to say (perhaps while debating the bar tab).  Which is where you come in. Contributing to The Alchemist is a way for you to vote for the kind of art you want to see produced.  Most productions rely upon big organizations, corporate sponsors or government aid.  We're trying to build from the ground up - make something for you, supported by you.  We're already working hard, but we need your help.

What We Need & What You Get

We've slashed costs across the board - all we're looking for is to put clothes on characters' backs, pay for insurance to protect performers, give the artists subway money so that they don't lose money by donating their time.  Last and not least, we need to spread the word so an audience will come and make the show worthwhile!

$10 Pays for two actors to ride the subway to and from rehearsal

$25 Covers the printing cost of scripts

$120 Takes care of marketing - fliers, ads, etc

$250 Pays for accident insurance to protect the artists and volunteer producers

$500 Sponsors travel costs for half the cast

$1000 Lets us build the wonderful props and costumes for the show (we've cut everything else - no set, no lights) - think buffoon bellies, stilts, clown shoes and tops hats!  It's what will make this show spring to life.
Other Ways You Can Help

Here's what we REALLY need you to do: 

1. Donate - whatever you can, no amount is too large (or too small!).  All donations are tax deductible through Fractured Atlas, a not-for-profit organization that is fiscally sponsoring us.

2. Get 5 friends to match your donation.  That's how we're really going to make this a community supported piece.  Help us break out of the circle of people we know personally and make this a show made by everyone!

3. Spread the word about the performances!  The most important piece is having an audience, and you can spread the word - tell your friends, post on your facebook, blog, and twitter accounts.

4. Come see us play!  We can't make theater without you!

Thank you thank you from the bottom of our hearts.  Please support us in making innovative, engaging, socially aware art.

Visit our website and facebook page, and come see us play in September - our chief goal is to see you there, laughing away...

story:
To bring the joy and artistry of dance to the nation's capital and the world's stage through the presentation of the best in classical and contemporary ballet; to provide the highest caliber of dance training through a preeminent school of ballet; and to serve and involve the entire community through extensive dance education and outreach programs.


TWB@THEARC

Nearly 15 years ago, The Washington Ballet expanded its education operations to serve southeast Washington, D.C. at the Town Hall Education Arts Recreation Campus (THEARC), known as TWB@THEARC, to reach underserved areas of the Washington DC community. TWB@THEARC offers community-based education programs, ballet training through The Washington School of Ballet (TWSB), and hosts TWB's community engagement programs of DanceDC and the EXCEL! Scholarship program. To ensure access for all, TWB offers tuition on a sliding scale based on household income and family size.   

l

DanceDC & Excel! Scholarship Programs

DanceDC is an interdisciplinary program that provides 7 in-school residencies to second and third graders of DC Public Schools (DCPS), combining ballet with a core curriculum subjects in compliance with DCPS standards and the National Standards for Dance Education.  TWB's DanceDC Programs reach over 600 students a year and concludes with culminating performances at the end of each residency.

Each year TWB nominates passionate and talented students from DanceDC participating schools to continue their dance training at The Washington School of Ballet for one year through the EXCEL! Scholarship. 

25 students currently benefit from EXCEL! Scholarship funding, however with sufficient support from donors through this campaign, an additional 8 students from TWB's DanceDC partner schools would benefit.


Donor Impact:

TWB@THEARC continues to strive and serve thousands of children and young adults through out the underserved communities in Washington, D.C. With sufficient funds, TWB@THEARC has the space to welcome 8 additional DanceDC students next season as EXCEL! Scholars.  
You're contribution would provide the following:
  • Funding for a DanceDC student, who may not otherwise have the means to afford extensive training, to join TWSB on a full scholarship for one year 
  • Performance opportunities at THEARC, which holds the only professional theater located in Southeast Washington D.C.
  • Attending a performance of Septime Webre's: The Nutcracker in downtown Washington, D.C.
  • New costumes, uniforms, dance shoes, tights and other proper attire to attend TWB@THEARC

** All contributions go directly to support the training and development of students at TWB@THEARC in the program.  For your generosity, TWB will send you a variety of exclusive tokens of appreciation for your donation.


    TWB@THEARC's Impact:

    TWB has served over 70,000 students and spends more than $1.4 Million on its community engagement and education efforts.  Opened in 2005, TWB@THEARC's satellite campus of TWSB bustles with the energy and excitement of youth, adults and seniors who study ballet, jazz modern and African dance in two state-of-the-art studios.
     

                                            


      Other Ways You Can Help

      Whether or not you are making a monetary contribution, you can play an important role  in helping TWB achieve their goal.  A great way to help is to share links to this campaign page with your networks. An email to friends with a link to this campaign is especially helpful. You can also share the link via Facebook, Twitter and other Social Media.

story:
What is Fireflower?

Fireflower is an original musical comedy, written & directed by Marty Brueggemann (an award-winning songwriter & composer of film/game music) that brings a classic video game adventure to life in a unique show for all ages.  
We have been selected to perform our debut at the 2014 MN Fringe Festival.
Fireflower is an ambitious production and your financial support makes the scope and quality of our show possible.

    What do you need from me?

    So far we have been financing the production out of our own pockets, but we risk hitting a spending wall that would truly compromise the production.

    Our fundraising goal is $1800, which goes toward  

    • Fees for our rehearsal space
    • Materials for our props and costumes
    • Fees/expenses for our performance venue
    • Cost for print advertising & flyers
    • Web development, Photography & Videography

    What would I get?

    We're so very excited to offer some wonderful Fireflower perks & goodies:

    • The complete Fireflower Original Cast Recording (digital download & CD)
    • Making-of documentary (digital download & DVD)
    • The Fireflower songbook (complete score in sheet music)
    • Props from the production (for keeps!)
    • Signed posters from the cast & crew

      Calling all Heroes

      There isn't much time left until our August premiere. Every contribution - no matter the size - helps our cause. Even if you're unable to donate, help us spread the word:

      • Share this page with friends and family
      • Post, tag and tweet about us (#FireFlower)
      • Bring your friends and family to any (or all) of our five performances.
      • Contact us about ways to volunteer for the production.

      Performances:

        U of M Rarig Center Proscenium  ·  330 21st Ave S  ·  Minneapolis, MN 
        • Saturday, Aug 2 - 1pm
        • Sunday, Aug 3 - 10pm
        • Monday, Aug 4 - 8:30pm
        • Thursday, Aug 7 - 8:30pm
        • Sunday, Aug 10 - 2:30pm
        Tickets are now on sale at the Minnesota Fringe Festival website: http://www.fringefestival.org/2014/show/?id=2654 

        We can't wait to see you there!

story:
Remember when you were in the school play?  Remember how you felt with the lights in your eyes and the butterflies in your stomach?  Can you hear the thunderous applause?  Then maybe later on you joined a college group and had some unforgettable experiences working hard towards a performance, what a thrill, right?  Sure, that helped you.  It gave you confidence and maturity and you made friends that have lasted a lifetime. 

Sadly, today’s youngsters will not have that experience.  They will not know what it feels like to belong to a group of people that share a common goal of pulling off the spectacular feat that is live theatre.  Our education and civic budgets are cut to the bare minimum with no room for extras such as theatre programs.  School plays are not being produced, music and art are being slashed from the curriculum.  An entire generation of our kids are not being introduced to theatre arts, music or culture of any kind.  And we at the Glove Performing Arts Center, think that is tragic.  

But, with your help we can do something about it!  We have, right here in Fulton County, New York, a fully functional Theatre just oozing with history and culture.  The theatre will turn 100 in 2014!  As you can imagine, it takes resources to keep these old doors open. We get no funding from the state or local governments, they are stretched to the limit just providing for the basic needs of our community, ranked among the poorest in New York State.  We have been fortunate with some small grants and trusts but nothing like what it takes to keep going.  This grand space could be a solid economic driver for our area but first we need to shine it up and dress it for a big debut!  We have an all-volunteer staff ready to do the job, expecting nothing in return but to enjoy quality entertainment and have the place bursting with kids who we know will be the performers and patrons of tomorrow. 

Please remember your experience being introduced to the performing arts and how much it means to you now and give to help the Glove stay open for the next generation.

Gloversville is a struggling upstate NY community. Population 15,656, Median Income $30,741 Unemployment 10.6%. Yes we are the home of the Ice Cream Wars. The Glove Performing Arts Center building will be 100 years next year. We at the Glove Performing Arts Center are trying to rehabilitate this old theatre, keep it open and try to give the local people shows at a price they can afford.

The Glove is going “green” this July. The Glove Performing Arts Center needs your help with funding for our ambitious production of Shrek the Musical.  Shrek: The Musical follows the adventure of everyone’s favorite ogre and his talkative donkey in his daring rescue of a fiery red headed princess, for a sleazy “short” tempered lord wannabe king in order to obtain the deed to his swamp.  The swamp with has been intruded by evicted fairy tale creatures looking for their happy ending.  This musical is fully comedy, drama, romance, and just downright entertainment. The production is complete with an extremely talented group of local actors.  This energized musical is full of magical characters, evil villains, and a story line that will make you laugh, cry, belch, flatulate, and whatever bodily function you can think of.  Your contribution will help with the heavy costuming, complex make-up designs, and ambitious scenery.  The Glove has recently begun bringing highly praised productions to our community including Wizard of Oz and Hand in Glove’s recent productions of Annie and Into the Woods.  Shrek is bound to be a spectacular production. We just need your help to make our dream a reality. Please help us support community theatre and help us bring Shrek to Gloversville this July and discover the Glove!

 

Shrek The Musical


July 19,20,25,26,27 at 8 PM and July 21 at 2 PM

Director - Barb Fisher Rivera
Musical Director - Jolie Halsey
Choreographer - Mikaela Holmes
Technical Director - Marc Norton
Stage Manager - Robert Murray
Asst.Stage Manager and Lighting - Mark Joseph Peek
Sound Engineer- Chad Andrews
Costume Designer- Caitlin Andrzejewski


Cast
Shrek - Marc Christopher
Fiona - Caralivia Levanti.
Donkey - Roderick Halsey.
Lord Farquaad - Austin Kadle.
Dragon/Blue Bird Voice - Kay Koch.
Teen Fiona/Godmother - Kelsey Norton.
Young Fiona/Ensemble - Gwenyth Rivera.

story_txt:
Remember when you were in the school play?  Remember how you felt with the lights in your eyes and the butterflies in your stomach?  Can you hear the thunderous applause?  Then maybe later on you joined a college group and had some unforgettable experiences working hard towards a performance, what a thrill, right?  Sure, that helped you.  It gave you confidence and maturity and you made friends that have lasted a lifetime. 
Sadly, today’s youngsters will not have that experience.  They will not know what it feels like to belong to a group of people that share a common goal of pulling off the spectacular feat that is live theatre.  Our education and civic budgets are cut to the bare minimum with no room for extras such as theatre programs.  School plays are not being produced, music and art are being slashed from the curriculum.  An entire generation of our kids are not being introduced to theatre arts, music or culture of any kind.  And we at the Glove Performing Arts Center, think that is tragic.  
But, with your help we can do something about it!  We have, right here in Fulton County, New York, a fully functional Theatre just oozing with history and culture.  The theatre will turn 100 in 2014!  As you can imagine, it takes resources to keep these old doors open. We get no funding from the state or local governments, they are stretched to the limit just providing for the basic needs of our community, ranked among the poorest in New York State.  We have been fortunate with some small grants and trusts but nothing like what it takes to keep going.  This grand space could be a solid economic driver for our area but first we need to shine it up and dress it for a big debut!  We have an all-volunteer staff ready to do the job, expecting nothing in return but to enjoy quality entertainment and have the place bursting with kids who we know will be the performers and patrons of tomorrow. 
Please remember your experience being introduced to the performing arts and how much it means to you now and give to help the Glove stay open for the next generation.
Gloversville is a struggling upstate NY community. Population 15,656, Median Income $30,741 Unemployment 10.6%. Yes we are the home of the Ice Cream Wars. The Glove Performing Arts Center building will be 100 years next year. We at the Glove Performing Arts Center are trying to rehabilitate this old theatre, keep it open and try to give the local people shows at a price they can afford.
The Glove is going “green” this July. The Glove Performing Arts Center needs your help with funding for our ambitious production of Shrek the Musical.  Shrek: The Musical follows the adventure of everyone’s favorite ogre and his talkative donkey in his daring rescue of a fiery red headed princess, for a sleazy “short” tempered lord wannabe king in order to obtain the deed to his swamp.  The swamp with has been intruded by evicted fairy tale creatures looking for their happy ending.  This musical is fully comedy, drama, romance, and just downright entertainment. The production is complete with an extremely talented group of local actors.  This energized musical is full of magical characters, evil villains, and a story line that will make you laugh, cry, belch, flatulate, and whatever bodily function you can think of.  Your contribution will help with the heavy costuming, complex make-up designs, and ambitious scenery.  The Glove has recently begun bringing highly praised productions to our community including Wizard of Oz and Hand in Glove’s recent productions of Annie and Into the Woods.  Shrek is bound to be a spectacular production. We just need your help to make our dream a reality. Please help us support community theatre and help us bring Shrek to Gloversville this July and discover the Glove!
 
Shrek The Musical
July 19,20,25,26,27 at 8 PM and July 21 at 2 PM
Director - Barb Fisher Rivera Musical Director - Jolie HalseyChoreographer - Mikaela HolmesTechnical Director - Marc NortonStage Manager - Robert MurrayAsst.Stage Manager and Lighting - Mark Joseph PeekSound Engineer- Chad AndrewsCostume Designer- Caitlin Andrzejewski
CastShrek - Marc ChristopherFiona - Caralivia Levanti.Donkey - Roderick Halsey.Lord Farquaad - Austin Kadle.Dragon/Blue Bird Voice - Kay Koch.Teen Fiona/Godmother - Kelsey Norton.Young Fiona/Ensemble - Gwenyth Rivera.Pinocchio - Sonny Duross.Gingy/Sugarplum Fairy - Jennifer Fisher.Papa OgreStraw - Kevin SprungMama Ogre/Mama Bear - Nichole Burkus.Little Shrek/Dwarf/Ensemble - Erin Morrison.Thelonius - Marc N.Wolf/Captain - Cody Webber.Pied Piper/Sticks/Bishop - Alec Rivera.Shoemaker's Elf/Blind Mouse - Mackenzie Morrison.Ugly Duckling- Ana-Marie MaldonadoBaby Bear/Blind Mouse - Jennifer Horne.Peter Pan/Blind Mouse - Ashley Polidore.Bricks/Ensemble - Rebecca Gardner.Wicked Witch/Ensemble - Genevieve Aldi.Papa Bear/Ensemble - Jeff Zepperi.Call 518-773-8255 Ext 25 or email boxoffice@glovetheatre.org for ticket info

story:
About the Del Valle Theater Awards

I'm Bill Schafer, a friend of Tony's, publisher of Las Vegas Night Beat and Las Vegas resident for 43 years.

Each August Tony published his "Tony Awards" giving praise to the best in Las Vegas' community theater. This project is to continue providing "Tony Awards" in remembrance of Anthony Del Valle.

I’m working with Paul Atreides who was president of Las Vegas Little Theatre for many years. We're raising funds to design and distribute annual awards in order to promote excellence in Southern Nevada's community theater. 

While we appreciate your donations large and small, if you donate $100 or more, we’ll give you a Del Valle Theater Awards t-shirt. If you’re an early donor, you can pick it up at the Celebration of Life at Las Vegas Little Theatre on Saturday, June 15 at 3 p.m.

By the way, Tony liked theatER rather than theatRE.
