story:
About The Company

Thrust Stage is a student theatre company in association with Durham University and Durham Student Theatre. Since forming in 2012, the company have enjoyed a meteoric rise with a range of productions receiving widespread admiration, five star reviews and a clutch of awards. A bold staging of Tennessee Williams’ A Streetcar Named Desire won major accolades including ‘Best Play' at the Durham Student Theatre Awards 2013. More recent shows have included Tennessee Williams' The Glass Menagerie and an all-female production of William Shakespeare's Henry V. A production of Jez Butterworth's Jerusalem in November 2013 received five awards at the Durham Student Theatre Awards 2014, including 'Best Design' and 'Best Play'. 

"...Jerusalem is without a doubt the most impressive piece of theatre I've seen in my three years at Durham" First Night Review, 29/11/13

"...nothing short of magical" The National Student, 29/11/13

Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2013

At last year's festival, Thrust Stage performed Shakespeare's Macbeth at the intimate venue of theSpace on the Mile. The show received three four-star reviews and was hailed as "...as captivating as Shakespeare gets" Ed Fringe Review, and "an excellent performance...dynamic and presented with subtlety" Edinburgh Spotlight. The company hope to build on this previous success at the Fringe with a piece of original writing from student writers Matt Dann and Lewis Meade. 

About The Show

'The Babysitters' is a rip-roaring black comedy about friendship in a world of violence and crime. Tommy and Dave, babysitters for a violent crime-boss, wile away the hours playing Cluedo, eating Chinese food, and wondering what's going to happen to the man tied up in the cupboard. Their job is simple: lie low, keep watch, and await instructions. But when their orders finally come through, boredom turns to mayhem as the pair are plunged into a hilarious, blood-fuelled nightmare with disastrous consequences.  
The show was first entered as part of the Durham Drama Festival 2013, where it won three awards including 'Best Play', 'Best Actor' and 'Best Supporting Actor'. The show was then performed again in February 2014 and won 'Best Comedy' at the Durham Student Theatre Awards 2014. The production is set to be performed at this year's Edinburgh Fringe Festival at the main space in C Cubed, in the re-launched 400-year old courtyard house Riddle’s Court. 
"...the undeniable masterpiece of the festival" The Bubble, 08/03/13 ★★★★★
"...slick and professional...truly a joy to watch" Durham Theatre Review, 06/02/14 ★★★★★

Donating

Due to the financial challenges that come with staging a show at the Edinburgh Fringe, especially for a student theatre company such as ours, we are asking for a total of £800. This money will be invaluable to the success of the show and will be divided into the following areas:

Props:

The production contains lots of handheld props that are used in conjunction with the violent aspects of the show. These include a blowtorch, screwdrivers, pliers and fake knives. All the violence is light-hearted in nature, however we aim to make everything as realistic as possible which gradually becomes more of a financial challenge. The show also contains various consumable items, such as smarties, spring rolls and lots of tea. Providing these across 17 performances and rehearsals also proves costly. 

Visual Effects:

Within the show we get through a lot of fake blood. With publicising the show everyday on the Royal Mile and with every performance, we expect to use approximately 5-7 litres of the stuff! Part of the money would go towards ensuring we have enough blood to last us through the festival, so that our shows and stunts are both realistic and entertaining.

Fringe Publicity:

Any successful production at the Fringe places a large emphasis on publicising the show on the Royal Mile and around Edinburgh. As a result, the number of flyers and posters required is always very high. A portion of the money would go towards ensuring we have sufficient numbers of both in order to maintain a high presence at the festival. We are also hoping to purchase a two metre roller banner that will be both eye catching on the Royal Mile and help to draw people into our publicity stunts. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to donate through this page there are so many other ways that you can help. We would really appreciate if you could tell your friends and family and link them through to this page. To keep up-to-date with the company and the show at the Fringe you can go to our website (www.thruststage.co.uk) and follow us on Facebook and Twitter (@Thrust_Stage). We would also love to see as many people in our audiences as possible. If you're visiting the festival between 31 July and 16 August, we'd love to see you at the show and to hear your thoughts after. To book tickets please visit (https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/theatre/babysitters). 

We thank you for taking time out of your day to read through this page. If you have any questions regarding the show, the company or this page, don't hesitate to contact us at: thruststage@gmail.com

story:
Here's What's Up

Body Waves, a queer black dance acrobatics crew in Oakland, needs your support in raising $800 for mats and rehearsal time by April 16th! We are working hard to create choreography and learn bold, new stunts, partner balances and tricks for our upcoming performances. The biggest obstacles we face right now are lack of safe equipment and space. 

What We Need & What You Get

The break down is simple:

  • Mats - $300 for two 4-panel mats
  • Rehearsal - $500 for up to 25 hours of rehearsal time in a studio 

If you donate: 

  • $5, you get a thank you shoutout!
  • $20, you get free admission to a community acrobatics class taught by Body Waves crew!
  • $50, you get a video shoutout, a signed Body Waves poster, and free admission to a community acrobatics class taught by Body Waves crew!
  • $100, Ana, Ant and India of Body Waves will take YOU out on a date!

The Impact

How does Body Waves give to our community? We perform and inspire, teach community classes, and strengthen the network of artists in the Bay Area. Our work is a gift to ourselves and our community. We are queer, Black artists dedicated to creating work and experiences that are healing, most beautiful to us and that expand the public imagination of what's possible.

What's the impact of your support?

  • Mats and rehearsal space will help us create a more safe and sustainable practice. 
  • You will enable us to continue to support spaces like the Living Room Project and SOL Collective, which serve as valuable community assets.
  • We will expand our work as artists and its reach beyond Oakland.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not you make a financial contribution, you can help:

  • Spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr.
  • Email your networks.
  • Use the tools to share!

That's all folks, donate now!

story:
What's this all about?

We're the Old Mill Drama Patrons, supporting the Patriot Players Theater Company, the drama troupe at Old Mill Senior High. PPTC's theme for this year is "Fairy Tales" and the spring show will be the stage musical version of "The Wizard of Oz". Your support will help us buy or create set materials, special effects and costumes, cover royalty and script costs, and potentially help repair or replace some our nearly 40-year-old stage lighting equipment.

Breaking it down

We're supporting an incredibly talented group of young people who deliver amazing performances by providing the tools they need to put on the best show possible. Our goal is to raise $5000 to cover some of the expenses for the show such as royalties and script fees in advance, to help cope with the rising cost of building materials for set construction, and to cover the other necessities of putting on a high-quality theatrical production. If we meet our funding goal, our stretch goals will permit us to fund additional things like awesome special effects.

Every dollar we raise will go towards the production or to fulfilling contributor perks - which we've deliberately kept small to maximize the dollars that will go to the production.

Even if we don't reach our minimum goal, every dollar we raise will help us better support these phenomenal young performers.

When is all this happening?

Our campaign is set to run through December 15th. The funds raised should be available from Indiegogo around the end of December, and we'll begin putting the money to work in as soon as we can. The performances will be:

  • Friday, April 4th, 7 PM
  • Saturday, April 5th, 7 PM
  • Sunday, April 6th, 2 PM
  • Friday, April 11th, 7 PM
  • Saturday, April 12th, noon
  • Saturday, April 12, 7 PM

What contributors get:

We've deliberately built this campaign to maximize the support for the show, but we still want our bigger contributors to have some concrete tokens of our thanks. Starting at the $25 level, contributors will be listed by name (or anonymously if they wish) on the Yellow Brick Road. At the $50 level we begin including tickets to one of the performances. At higher levels, we'll include show posters and t-shirts.

What are your stretch goals?

The director and crew have some great ideas and we'll announce those as we get closer to our goal.

But what if I can't contribute?

There's still ways you can help! Spread the word by linking our campaign on your Facebook or other social media feed, or by e-mailing it. 

Can I use PayPal to contribute?

Yes! You'll have the choice of using PayPal or a credit card when you contribute. (Funds contributed via PayPal will show up as going to Michelle Appel.)

Can I contribute directly?

Absolutely! If you'd like to make a direct contribution to the Old Mill Drama Patrons or to PPTC, contact us directly.

Is my contribution tax-deductable?

No, we're afraid not - we'd have to go through the process to register as a 501(c)3 non-profit organization to make that possible.

story:
About The Show

Amanduh steps out of the internet and onto the stage for her first ever LIVE show. With 5 whole subscribers and almost 212 total video views, this internationally famous celebrity sensation had one of her videos played once in a bar in Guam and another of her videos featured on El Huffington Post (Huffington Post in Spain).

Amanduh's show provides a deep and thoughtful insight into her life story.  It features actual talents from Anita Goodmann, the one and only artStar Charlatan, JenRenee Paulson from Amanduh's hit video "Lightth Out" and rounding out the cast is: Craig Trolli, Rodney Shrader, Aaron Allshouse and Elizabeth Powell.  With special guest performaces from some of your favorite PlayTime Time characters including:  Sparkle Leigh, Butch Alice and Gladys the Radish.  This amazing experience will be something you will soon want to forget.

The show is co-directed by Gary Zinter and Terri Weagant with sound design and a custom soundtrack by Jesse McNeese.  See, it's almost like it's a professional show!

It's a fun time for everyone 21 and over that you can only expect from Amanduh.  Come see Amanduh live on stage at Rebar July 5th and 6th.


A Personal Message From Amanduh

Thank you for taking the time to look at my fund raithing page.  I really like money becauthe I never had any before tho it'll be fun to thpend it on fabricth and cardboard and magic.  Who knowth?  Maybe I can make all of your dreamth come true with thith show, even the bad oneth!

Hugth and kiththeth,

Amanduh


What We Need & What You Get

  • This is an almost no-budget show.  The goal of this campaign is simply to offset the cost of costumes and set design.
  • By pledging to the campaign you can receive perks such as:  A call out on Amanduh's Facebook page, An autographed picture of Amanduh, your own personal haiku video, an appearance in an upcoming Amanduh video and front row VIP seating at her show.
  • The goal is small but even if we don't reach it, all money will be used to make the set look as low-budget awesome as it can be and maybe throw in a costume or two.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute you can still help:

  • Share the IndieGoGo page with your friends
  • Follow Amanduh on Facebook:  Facebook.com/theamanduh
  • Subscribe to Amanduh's YouTube page:  Youtube.com/zewkin
  • Give a random stranger a hug and pat on the butt and tell them Amanduh made you do it; when asked who Amanduh is, run away and laugh maniacally.
  • Smile

story:
Short Summary

Hi! My name is Amica Hunter, and I am a 21 year old female clown and circus performer living in the San Francisco Bay Area. I have been an artist all my life - painting, sculpting, acting, and storytelling, but above all, clowning is my passion. There is nothing quite like connecting with a live audience and providing meaningful and entertaining ways of showing people how to laugh at ourselves. After training acrobatics, stilt walking, unicycle, and aerials arts while in school in Portland, OR, I left the university to pursue performance full time at the Circus Center in San Francisco. It was the best decision I've ever made. Now I want to further my professional training so that I can turn my calling into a career that supports me. 

After touring street theater festivals in Europe this summer with my company A Little Bit Off, it was time to take the next step, so I applied to Ecole Philippe Gaulier - a physical theater school in Etampes, France. Ecole Philippe Gaulier has a 35 year legacy of unique, quality instruction, and has produced many successful performers and comedians from around the world, like Sacha Baron Cohen for example. Attending this school will strengthen me as a physical comedian, give me invaluable experience, and allow me to make strong professional connections. The school offers a two year program that begins in October 2014 covering all of the subjects that I want to study. I have been accepted to the program. I'm on my way to getting my student visa. Only one crucial factor is missing. TUITION!

I need to raise approximately $9,448 just to cover my first year’s tuition, plus $500-$700 for Indiegogo's fees. I have been working hard to save up for housing and other living expenses for my stay in France, but tuition for the first year of school is due in full on the first day of classes. I need your help!

What I Need 

Ecole Philippe Gaulier costs 6,900 Euros per year. That is about 9,500 US dollars for the first year program. No scholarships or government aid are offered for covering the cost, but considering the quality of instruction, variety of classes, and hours per day, it is a remarkably reasonable price for a professional theatrical education. Unfortunately, it isn’t something I can afford on my own. If I meet my funding goal Indiegogo will extract about $700 in fees, which is why I set my goal for $10,000. I am relying on my own savings for housing, food, and transportation while in Etampes, so every dollar raised here will go straight to paying for tuition.

For this campaign, I am only focusing on rounding up enough money to attend the first year of the program. I set my goal $552 higher to account for the $700 of fees that Indiegogo will collect if I meet it. 

If, with your help, I am able to exceed my goal of $10,000, I will set aside the extra funds to go towards paying my second year’s tuition at Ecole Philippe Gaulier.

If I fall short of the goal, the money I do make (minus a 9% collection by Indiegogo) will still be put directly into my tuition fund, and I will have to come up with other ways to fulfill the amount. I am determined to make this work!

What You Get

Woohoo! Perks! Goodies!

Not only will your contributions give you a warm fuzzy feeling, $10 and up donators will receive a special hand written thank you card from me to you. Donations starting at $25 will include an original drawing. In addition to the card and original sketch, higher level contributions will get you one of the following:

  • A unique, hand-sculpted clown figurine
  • A hand-sewn circus ruffle collar
  • An original home made latex clown nose
  • A custom personalized video act
  • A live in-person (or skyped) performance

The Impact

The incredible thing about live performance in this increasingly virtual world of ours is not just the energy you feel both on stage and in the audience, it’s not just the absence of a “pause,” “rewind,” or “delete” button. Live performance offers the precious opportunity for real exchanges. It gives us a chance to really look closely at each other and make impressions. That is what clowning is all about - being WITH the audience. 

My passion for creating bizarre, quirky, and endearing physical comedy performance is fueled by a belief that connecting people through shared laughter and curiosity is important work. It is a vital way to foster awareness and growth in communities, and a wonderful opportunity to suspend one’s grim adulthood, and reawaken the imagination. I thrive on the experience of relating to and delighting an audience even if it is through very obscure means. Clowning for me is bringing relief to the tension of the world, and it is my dream is to find new and better ways of accomplishing this task.

I have learned that the best way for me to learn, improve, and push myself is through instruction. I have done a lot of research and put a lot of intention into my performance education thus far, and I know that Ecole Philippe Gaulier is the next step I should take to reach my goals. While the financial aspects are daunting (and let’s be real, the uprooting and the language barrier are scary too), I know that this is the most important and beneficial thing I can do to become a better performer for YOU and for the WORLD to watch and enjoy.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to contribute in dollars or euros, I totally understand. But that doesn't mean I can't use your support! 

I would be so grateful if you would pass this project along to your friends, colleagues, and family. Just a copy and paste the link in an email or your favorite social media outlets. A positive endorsement would be superb too! I can use all the help I can get, and getting the word out there to as many people as possible before time runs out is crucial.

Also, as far as social media outreach things go, I would be thrilled and honored if you took the time to "like" my page and my company's page on Facebook. Also be sure to follow A Little Bit Off on Twitter.

Thanks! Gracias! Merci!

story:
Help launch the Hazard Rep by supporting our inaugural productions of Sam Shepard's TRUE WEST and FOOL FOR LOVE.

With your support, these two “Comedies of Menace” will be presented in rotating rep featuring company members Jim Anderson, Greg Carere, Tracy Lynn Farber & Ryan Feyk in Midtown Manhattan this spring.

As you will see from the suggested giving levels, producing high quality live theater involves costs both large and small. So a donation of any size will allow you to play a key role in making our first season possible!

Our audiences will viscerally experience the naked force, unsettling chaos, and darkly cunning brilliance of these American masterpieces, whether they are Shepard veterans or meeting his work for the very first time.

What makes these productions truly unique is that each actor in the company has had the rare opportunity to devote a solid year of extensive study, exploration, and rehearsal to these characters.

This festival is a year in the making, and you can help us bring it to life!

story:
how it all started.

Rewind. Last year. We graduated from college with theatre degrees. Fast forward. This year. We (Bekah and Meredith) both found ourselves swamped in our day jobs, frustrated with our lack of personal creative outlets. The solution: challenge ourselves and reignite our creative juices by producing a show that would transform us as artists and people.

That show? "reasons to be pretty" by Neil LaBute. His shows are raw, visceral, and force the audience and actors to face the harsher side of human nature. From a production standpoint, it allows us to focus on the characters and relationships instead of the "bigger the better" idea that sometimes plagues theatre. We are incredibly passionate about theatre, and especially this piece. We want to give you, our audience, the best possible experience.


That's where you come in.  Shows (especially one this awesome) cost money to produce. We are theatre artists, so we are accustomed to working on a tight budget. Therefore, we're grateful for any amount you give us, and will use it in an economical, productive way. We aren't aiming for extravagance, we just want to give the piece justice.

what we need and what you get.

Here's what your contributions will be going towards:

- Licensing Rights for the show

-Production Materials (Lighting gels, props, paint, lumber, costumes- etc)

-Marketing (posters, programs, flyers, ads in local publications)

-Rented pieces/materials

-We also would love to give financial support to our production team. They are all very talented professionals that are giving of their time and creativity. We want to ensure that they are taken care of and aren't losing money while they are taking care of us.


Read all about the perks------------------->

No matter what, we will strive for high quality on a low budget. 


other ways you can help.

If you can't contribute financially, don't feel bad! We still care about you! You can help us out TREMENDOUSLY by spreading the word. It's been proven that the best form of advertising is word of mouth. Seriously. Google it.

story:
Short Summary

Senior Showcase is a tradition at MCVTS School of the Arts where the theatre company, Novus Productions, is passed down from generation to graduating generation. The current generation of young artists are a bit of a "quirky" group,and as our first big step into the theatrical professional world, we want to make a loud entrance into the artistic community. We want to make this show as fun as possible for our audience!  HOWEVER, that requires MONEY! So we have turned to YOU (the interwebs) for help! Our show consists of:

SHAKESPEARE (swag)

LITTLE KID SCIENTISTS

PHOTOGRAPHY 

SPOKEN WORD

AND

SO. MUCH. MORE!

So help us out financially, and we promise that we will put on the best show that we possibly can.

What We Need

Let's break it down now:

  • Our goal is $500. This money will go to nearly every aspect of our show, and most importantly, we want the money so we can fund future shows! Think of the future!
  • In return for your magnanimous donation, we will install a hierarchy of awesome.

The Impact

  • Our project will be wonderful with your help: for we are young artists that are exploring what we can do with theatre. Aid the artists that add to the conversation. Contribute so that we can make a debut. 
  • We have had so many amazing shows in the past that you have helped out with (Senior Showcase 2013, The Tempest, etc). Let's make another great show together. 
  • Your help is much appreciated. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I know some of you just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean that you can’t help:

  • MAKE NOISE!!!!! TELL EVERYONE!! YOUR MOTHER! YOUR BROTHER! YOUR AUNTS COUSIN! EVERYONE!
  • SHARE OUR PAGE! Maybe you can't help out but maybe your mother, brother, or aunt's cousin can!

story:
“Our deepest fear is
not that we are inadequate.
Our deepest fear is that we
are powerful beyond measure.”
~ Marianne Williamson

    My name is Jee Lam and I am 22 years old. I currently dance with a pre-professional contemporary training company, Lamondance, under the direction of Monica Proenca, Lara Barclay, and Davi Rodrigues.

    I have been accepted into the Alonzo King LINES Ballet Training Program, beginning September 2013, in San Francisco.  LBTP is a two year training program aimed at professional and pre-professional dancers.  Admission to the program is through audition only, and as the maximum enrollment is 36 students, there is a high faculty-to-student ratio.  Dancers train approximately 35 hours per week, with classes in a variety of styles including ballet, modern, pointe, improvisation, choreography, and LINES repertoire.

    Attending the Alonzo King LINES Ballet Training Program would give me the challenge, the experience, the finesse that I need to take my dancing to where I want it to be.  I feel that I would graduate from this program a professional dancer, in the sense of technique, and in the sense of confidence, maturity, and overall ability.

___________________________________________

Fundraising goal: $15 000

What will the funds raised go towards?

Tuition: $9 000/year

Pointe shoes: $2 500/year {approx. 2 pairs a month}

Living expenses: $11 000 {rent/food}

Health Insurance: $2 000

Miscellaneous {cleaning supplies/toilet paper/toothpaste/etc.}: $1000

 Total: $22 500

What am I doing to help myself financially right now?

     I currently serve at a restaurant, between 3-5 shifts per week, depending on my rehearsal schedule and the availability at the restaurant. I try and pick up as many shifts as I can from other servers.  I live off of my tips for rent and groceries, and pay cheques go towards Lamondance and other general living expenses. If there is anything left over, it goes into my savings account for next year. I also occasionally teach salsa in high schools; this money goes directly towards next year as well.

     I live pretty frugally; groceries usually come to about $60 a week, mostly because I make giant pots of lentil soup that last me two weeks and work out to about $1 a day..... I am getting tired of lentil soup :P {Kidding, I eat very healthily; a fully balanced diet, chocolate included (:  Lentils do indeed play a large part in my diet due to their cheap cost, but it isn't the only thing I eat!}

     I am hoping to raise $15 000. I realize this may be a bit of long shot, but what is the harm in trying?  

___________________________________________

     Every dollar helps me get closer to my goal, but if you aren’t able to help out, that is quite all right! I understand. There are many ways you can help other than through monetary means -- I accept all well wishes and hugs! As well, sharing my Indiegogo page on Facebook, Twitter, email, any other type of social media, and through word of mouth would be incredibly helpful. You shall find some helpful ‘share’ buttons at the top of this page.

___________________________________________

     When I was 18, I moved to Dresden, Germany to attend Palucca Schule - Hochschule für Tanz, under the direction of Jason Beechey. I came away from that year with improved technique, strength, and insight in to my dancing, but with a lot of internal frustration with dance as well. I moved back home and announced I had quit dancing forever. Then I started salsa dancing.    

     Salsa dancing was incredible for me. I had always loved dancing, but this was the first time I truly felt free to allow myself to enjoy dance for what it truly is: a release and escape from the limitations one puts on oneself; a freedom initiated from within a piece of music and/or emotion which allows us to connect with our souls and those around us. With time, I realized I could apply the exact same intent to my contemporary and ballet dancing as I did in salsa; so I came back.

     Since returning to my contemporary and ballet roots, I have completed a season with Lamondance, am currently in my second, and have taught and choreographed at a local dance school. I have also taken acting classes, filmed a few TV commercials and a short film. I work in a restaurant, allow myself to date, socialize... in short, I have allowed myself to experience life outside of the studio.

     I used to think being a dancer was all about perfect technique, eating-breathing-sleeping dance. However, I now realize just how important experiencing other things in life is, and just how much it broadens one's dancing ability. Without ever falling in love with someone, kissing someone, feeling that connection with another being, how can one truly show love to one's audience? How can one portray internal angst, or pure happiness, or a mélange of emotions, without ever having experienced them?  How can one allow oneself to be free onstage if one hasn’t allowed oneself to be free in real life?  With gaining maturity in my life, I have gained maturity within my dancing. Dancing has a different texture to me now; it feels different, and it feels good.

___________________________________________

And a little bit more...

     When I first started teaching ballet, I felt hesitant; I hadn’t taken on a proper teaching job like this before, and now I had 60 students in my care, 9 hours a week.  I felt like there was a lot of responsibility attached to it.  I was teaching these young girls how to use their muscles, how to apply quality to their movement... teaching dance encompasses a whole lot more than simply explaining pliés and pirouettes.  I soon found I could, in fact, teach these students though.  Corrections were picked up quickly, and the use of imagery seemed to be extremely helpful when explaining certain techniques and steps.  When I would question the younger students about certain elements I had taught them the week before, it wasn’t surprising to have them holler my pointers back at me at an ear-splitting volume... they had definitely remembered what I had told them!  Watching the girls progress over the year was so satisfying... little changes slowly implemented themselves into bigger changes.  Just as importantly, the students that were rebellious and less responsive than their classmates at the beginning of the year were completely different and that much more excited about dancing.  I was sad when the year was over, but the cards and emails I have received {and continue to receive!} mean so much.

     I started teaching salsa in high schools this year.  I have taught students from grades 8-12, with as many as 90 under my instruction at once.  It’s quite fascinating actually.... I start the class off with footwork, standing at the front of the room with all the students in rows behind me.  Generally there will be a group of unruly students, usually boys but not always!, who congregate at the end of one of the lines.  For the first few minutes of the class, they goof off with their friends and make fun of the movement.  Yet by the end of the class, they have the footwork and partnering patterns down, and  are quiet and attentive; focused.  There might still be a little bit of goofing off happening, but for the most part, they’ve been hooked by the dancing.  This has happened to me numerous times, at different schools.  I’m not the only one that notices either.  I have had several teachers come up to me at the end of the class and comment on how well behaved and focused the students were.  It just goes to show how powerful dancing can be!

Dancing has a different texture to me now; it feels different, and it feels good.
___________________________________________
And a little bit more...     When I first started teaching ballet, I felt hesitant; I hadn’t taken on a proper teaching job like this before, and now I had 60 students in my care, 9 hours a week.  I felt like there was a lot of responsibility attached to it.  I was teaching these young girls how to use their muscles, how to apply quality to their movement... teaching dance encompasses a whole lot more than simply explaining pliés and pirouettes.  I soon found I could, in fact, teach these students though.  Corrections were picked up quickly, and the use of imagery seemed to be extremely helpful when explaining certain techniques and steps.  When I would question the younger students about certain elements I had taught them the week before, it wasn’t surprising to have them holler my pointers back at me at an ear-splitting volume... they had definitely remembered what I had told them!  Watching the girls progress over the year was so satisfying... little changes slowly implemented themselves into bigger changes.  Just as importantly, the students that were rebellious and less responsive than their classmates at the beginning of the year were completely different and that much more excited about dancing.  I was sad when the year was over, but the cards and emails I have received {and continue to receive!} mean so much.     I started teaching salsa in high schools this year.  I have taught students from grades 8-12, with as many as 90 under my instruction at once.  It’s quite fascinating actually.... I start the class off with footwork, standing at the front of the room with all the students in rows behind me.  Generally there will be a group of unruly students, usually boys but not always!, who congregate at the end of one of the lines.  For the first few minutes of the class, they goof off with their friends and make fun of the movement.  Yet by the end of the class, they have the footwork and partnering patterns down, and  are quiet and attentive; focused.  There might still be a little bit of goofing off happening, but for the most part, they’ve been hooked by the dancing.  This has happened to me numerous times, at different schools.  I’m not the only one that notices either.  I have had several teachers come up to me at the end of the class and comment on how well behaved and focused the students were.  It just goes to show how powerful dancing can be!

story:
REPORT FROM THE WAREHOUSE:

It’s been a big year for Orange. Real big. We’re a little dizzy. (In a good way.)

Back in January, we won an Art Tank grant from the Arizona Commission on the Arts to launch our new Digital Performance Lab program.  In April, we started renovating our new long-term home, a warehouse right off of Grand Ave in downtown Phoenix, and just recently we were honored with the 2014 Phoenix New Times Big Brain Award for Performing Art. 

But oh, oh, that’s just the beginning. In July, we’ll premiere the full production of Blood Wedding, our acclaimed radical re-imagining of Federico García Lorca’s classic tragedy. We’ve been working on this piece for a year and performed workshop versions to packed houses in late 2013, earning mention in the New Times’ “10 Best Plays” of the year. After many weeks of rehearse-translate-rehearse-perform-adjust-perform-revise-perform again, we’re finally ready to put on the finishing touches and show off the shiny new full production July 17-27 at the Lyceum Theatre at Arizona State University. As always, all tickets will be pay-what-you-can, because we think no one should be prevented from seeing art just because of a lack of cash.

BUTWAITTHERE’SMORE. The even bigger news? We’re hitting the road. In August, we pack it all up and take Blood Wedding to North American Cultural Laboratory in Highland Lake, New York. We’ve been plucked from among applicants from across the whole US of A to take part in NACL’s Deep Space Performance Residency, where we’ll spend a week rehearsing and performing  Blood Wedding as part of their season of experimental performance. This is Orange’s first out-of-state tour date and a great big deal. 

We’re incredibly excited to take this piece to ASU and then all the way across the country and show it to new audiences, spreading the word that damn cool work can and does come from Phoenix. 

You know what that means, though. It means we need your help. We have some expenses to cover for the premiere at ASU, but touring will bring with it all new costs, like transportation for our actors, set, costumes, and media equipment. To make it happen, we’re launching our most ambitious fundraising goal ever right here, right now.

SO… 

If you like our work, please pitch in. 

If you think Arizona deserves a world-class arts scene and a national reputation for something other than batshitcrazy politics, please pitch in. 

If you’re a human being, please pitch in. 

This is crowdfunding, and every little bit helps, whether it’s $5 or $500. (And of course, there are perks beyond the good karma… Check 'em out on the right of this page.)

No dollars? No problem. Share this campaign with your friends and family and tell ‘em about our stuff. Come see the show in AZ or NY and bring a friend. Help us keep doing what we do.

Many, many thanks.

-Carrie, Joya, Katrina, Matt, Steve, Tucker, and William

web: orangetheatre.org

story:
Who are we?  We Happy Few was founded by Hannah Todd and Raven Bonniwell in early 2012. Our mission is to present stripped down, small cast, ensemble productions with a group of talented artists, providing unique perspectives on classic texts.

Since 2012, we have staged three successful Shakespeare productions:  Hamlet in July 2012, The Tempest in May 2013, and Romeo & Juliet in July 2013. 

What's up next?  This summer, we're branching out from Shakespeare and into the mind of John Webster with The Duchess of Malfi.  We're excited to welcome Paul Reisman into the Few to direct the project.  The Duchess of Malfi will follow WHF's signature ensemble style, keeping the cast size to a mere eight actors who will play twenty odd characters in a 90-minute cutting of the script. 

What else makes this production fresh?  Director Reisman writes, "While today’s audiences may not be as familiar with this title, the themes of the play are eerily relatable. We are shown a social structure in crisis, rife with corrupt politicians, backroom meetings, and Big Brother lurking at every turn. We are shown institutional failure of the government, the church, and the individual. And trapped at the center of the maelstrom is the enigmatic Duchess. A vital, yet overlooked figure in the classical canon."

Hang on to your hats DC! The Duchess of Malfi is going to be an intense ride!

Why do we need your money?  We plan to produce The Duchess of Malfi in the Capital Fringe Festival (July 2014) as a Find Your Own Venue production in the Source Black Box. This is where we need your help. We need money... money for space rentals, insurance, marketing materials and application fees.  We are committed to dividing up 100% of the box office proceeds among the artists involved (being an artist is hard work and we’d like to keep ours from starving), so it's important that we're fully funded without help of ticket sales. Any amount helps, no matter how small.  If 100 people donate $5 we suddenly have $500!

What do you get? Besides the pride that you'll take home for helping an emerging theatre company get off the ground, we have some nifty sponsor rewards for helping us out.  And bonus:  We Happy Few Productions is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of We Happy Few Productions must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 

Wanna follow us around the web?
To keep up with this exciting project on the world wide web, check out our shiny new website at www.wehapyfewdc.moonfruit.com, find us on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/WeHappyFewProductions) or follow us on Twitter (@wehappyfewdc). If email’s more your speed, feel free to drop us a line at wehappyfewproductions@gmail.com.

We couldn't have done this without these Few folks:

Many special thanks to the special people who shared their unique talents in the making of this video.

In order of appearance:  William Vaughan, the Spector Family, Chris Genebach, Keith Hock, Kiernan McGowan, Kerry McGee, Nathan James Bennett, Paul Reisman, and Lillie.

story:
About The Founder

 

Hello There! Wendy Raquel Robinson here.

Many of you know me as Regina "Piggy" Grier from the Steve Harvey Show, or as Tasha Mack from BET's long running hit The Game, or even as Cruella DeVille from Disney's Descendants. Although I have been blessed to portray many characters in television and film, I consider my greatest accomplishment to date is being the co-founder of my performing arts school, Amazing Grace Conservatory, a place where EVERYONE is family!

About Amazing Grace Conservatory

  

Amazing Grace Conservatory (AGC) is a home away from home for youth and young adults between the ages of 5 and 18. We are a non profit 501(c)3 organization and dedicated to our mission: to train and develop emerging artists and at risk youth in the performing arts by offering a well-rounded and culturally enriching educational program in an environment that is nurturing for their personal, artistic, and professional growth. 

We offer 3 Semesters of training: Fall, Spring, and Summer and every semester concludes with a culminating performance. Our performances are held at the Nate Holden Performing Arts Center in Los Angeles, which is within a 2 mile radius from our school. We like to keep everything in proximity for the convenience of our students, their families, and friends.

Amazing Grace Conservatory has worked hard over the past 20 years to maintain artistic excellence and we are proud of our stellar alumni that include: Elle Varner, Aldis Hodge, Rhyon Nicole Brown, RaVaughn Brown, Lauren London, Thomas Hobson, Issa Rae and many more. Amazing Grace Conservatory is continuously changing the world and our community, one child at a time. 

PINO (A Pinocchio Story)

Our winter production "PINO," is a play based on the Pinocchio story. It follows the life of a boy, Pino, who wants fame, fortune, and status. Once Pino reaches that point in his life, his journey unfolds and he realizes that "fame" is not all that it is cracked up to be. His friends, family, and reputation slowly but surely begins to fade away. Once Pino realizes that he is only a puppet in that world, he quickly tries to depart from it, but he won't be able to do it alone. 

What We Need From You.

With our winter production "Pino," vastly approaching, we are seeking your help in offsetting the cost of the theater rental for our performance at the Nate Holden Theater. The performance(s) will be held on Sunday December 13, 2015 at 3:00pm and 7:00pm.

We are in need of $20,000 to cover the cost of the theater which includes the stage, box office, dressing rooms, reception area, and technical crew. This will also aid in purchasing  props, costumes, food, audio and camera crew/equipment, and promotional content for the production. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot provide a monetary contribution, that is ABSOLUTELY okay. A simple sharing of the campaign would be greatly appreciated. 

Stay AMAZING!

story:
The wild amount of “unseen” talent and good will that has been witnessed to exist all about the earth this year is something that shan't be stricken out of a mind too easily.

I want to experiment with the merit and with the boundaries of collaboration and collective enterprise- and personal power. 

I want to do great things, and I want you to do them with me. 

If I may be so bold, I’m planning to launch a collective-funding campaign to do what I came here to do in the first place- 

to kick up some dust, full-tilt.  
To attempt a creation of my own, after a year or so of doing naught but living out the trajectory of one who experiences what I’ve been allowed to experience. 


I'm Max. 

Since I was very small, I've had a romanticized vision of the entertainment industry, of Hollywood, and of the future of the artistic community in which I hoped to learn and grow. Carnegie Hall, cavernous soundstages and bright arc lights, of joyous, sweeping orchestral scores. More stars than the night. 

The world we live in now is much "busier", for better or worse, than that of the Golden Age. "Social media" is no longer limited to the cover of PhotoPlay, or page six of the New York Times. "Reality" is no longer limited to sepia-tone, no longer bound to itself; the storm has spun. 

Let's get to Oz. 


PRE-PRODUCTION.

Here are my hopes. 


It shall be said that, if we pass our goal in this endeavor, the proceeding funds will be directed towards further performance dates, perhaps internationally! 
That will mean meeting many more of you and producing greater and greater work. 



working title- "COLLECTIVE" 


"With a vision of transcending gender restrictions through the passion of performance, the show is to be performed live vocally, stripping away a layer of dissimulation often experienced at 'Drag' shows. The musical selections leap from genre to genre, all chosen for their role in driving Max and those close to him, forming a 'Collective' of inspiration.  

The production will indeed open a dialogue of commentary, encourage audience interaction and be scattered with guest appearances by other local artists, stimulated to share their stories of creative influence."

And now, YOU shall have a chance to be a real-life big-shot entertainment producer. 
David O. Selznick's got nothin' on you. 


"What We Need & What You Get"

My initial goal is to raise $3,000. "Gracious!", you may exclaim, "that's a sizable chunk of money!" I shall explain.  

  • “Collective” is to be mounted by Max and The Max Collective, a cooperative group of artists and “fans” (friends), as a dynamic collaborative effort unique in its inspired synergy.  
  • In a similar vein to Andy Warhol’s Factory, and the creative exchange and perpetuation therein, our goal is to fabricate a “socialist” artistic experience. Art for and by all. Art party. 
Performance Space- I don't care much for the thought of high ticket prices. Lots of people think it's chill to charge $60 - $100 a ticket for impersonal experiences. 

Right now we plan to do our initial show at the Bryant Lake Bowl, in early 2016 in Minneapolis, MN. http://www.bryantlakebowl.com 

BLB has a great profit-sharing mentality, and therefore we will be pleased to be able to have real low ticket prices. No rental costs means a more affordable time! 


 $3,000 will cover

  • Rehearsal Space Rental- a minor expense.
  • Rehearsal accompanist and live pianist during performances. Additionally, instrumental tracks are to be produced to simulate a sizable ensemble. Just think, with enough resources, we could properly compensate a full studio orchestra! Dreeeaming is free. 
  • Costume, Set, Prop, and Technical costs. This isn't Broadway, but there will be sorcery! 
  • Small stipends for those heavily involved- Time is money and Art takes Time.
  • LIVE Recording- Regardless of the outcome of this campaign, I will myself be orchestrating a Live recording of the proceedings, as my first tentative record.

    Working with local Minneapolis students and award-winning faculty from http://www.ipr.edu on many technological aspects of the show is also something I'm looking forward to. Keepin it local. 
More resources means more magic but if you have special creative ideas those can also be submitted as resources. Ideas are worth lots in a workshop state. 


In addition to "perks" (like the most coveted hat, below) I will be keeping tabs on the escalation of the campaign, and releasing some special little surprises along the way. 
We'll need to keep you all updated of course. 



The Impact-

WE'LL SEE. 

Risks & Challenges-

Regardless of outcome, there will be a live recording made and released to probably everyone. I've got to sing. 


I've never ever ever attempted anything close to this, alone or otherwise. That being said, I really take pride in what I do and this will be sure to be a production of merit. 

  • Worst comes to worst, it will be a very bare-bones cabaret show performed to an audience of relatives and locals. That's the only risk I suppose. 
  • Worst comes to very worst I'll put on the show in the alley behind my apartment with tinfoil for hair


"and then finally if you had any courage, you had to do something about it, or you never would've had a career."

X

story:
Help support Boston-based modern dance!

This spring, Boston-based modern dance company Grant Jacoby & Dancers will be presenting their third annual concert! The performances will be on Friday April 22nd and Saturday April 23rd at 8 PM at Green Street Studios in Cambridge, MA. It will include three new works choreographed by Grant Jacoby, as well as pieces by guest artists Brayton Dance and Brookline Academy of Dance

Founded in October 2013, Grant Jacoby & Dancers is run by artistic director Grant Jacoby, and features an ensemble of six immensely talented performers. Grounded in human emotion and tactile inspiration and research, Grant Jacoby & Dancers blends the worlds of modern/post-modern dance, jazz, ballet, and musical theater to weave compelling stage stories. 

Aside from Green Street Studios, the company has also presented work throughout New England, New York City, and France, including La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club, Triskelion Arts, The Dance Complex (Boston Globe Critics Pick 2014 & 2015), Les Champs Melisey, Artbeat, Dance for World Community, AS220, Connecticut College, Third Life Studios, RAW Boston (2014 Performer of the Year), and The International Festival of Arts & Ideas, as well as residencies at The Dragon's Egg, The Dance Complex, and Green Street Studios.

Where your support goes

Any and all of your support will help go towards...

  • Compensating the artists! This includes the choreographers, technical designer, and most importantly the performers, who have been working tirelessly in weekly rehearsals since summer 2015.
  • Paying for the studio space for the performances, as well as for rehearsal rental.
  • Paying for photo and video documentation of the performance.
  • Promotional materials including posters, flyers, and business cards.
  • Future projects! Grant Jacoby & Dancers has exciting upcoming opportunities, so any extra funds will go towards insuring that other projects in the future can be possible.

If we do not make our entire goal, all of the money will still go to good use in compensating the resident and guest artists for all of their hard work so far. 

Every penny counts! In a world where the arts is unfortunately underfunded, any contribution you can make is vital in ensuring that this performance goes smoothly, and that there will be plenty more in years to come.

Other ways you can help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Spread the word! If you know anyone else who would be interested in our mission and willing to donate, or just to come to the show...let them know! We always want to reach new audiences.
  • Share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or other social media outlets.
  • Come to our performance! Even if you can't donate now, we would love to see you in the audience, cheering on our talented and hard-working dancers.

We hope that you will be a part in making this performance a success! We can't thank you enough for your support.
story_txt:
Help support Boston-based modern dance! 
This spring, Boston-based modern dance company Grant Jacoby & Dancers will be presenting their third annual concert! The performances will be on Friday April 22nd and Saturday April 23rd at 8 PM at Green Street Studios in Cambridge, MA. It will include three new works choreographed by Grant Jacoby, as well as pieces by guest artists Brayton Dance and Brookline Academy of Dance
Founded in October 2013, Grant Jacoby & Dancers is run by artistic director Grant Jacoby, and features an ensemble of six immensely talented performers. Grounded in human emotion and tactile inspiration and research, Grant Jacoby & Dancers blends the worlds of modern/post-modern dance, jazz, ballet, and musical theater to weave compelling stage stories. 
Aside from Green Street Studios, the company has also presented work throughout New England, New York City, and France, including La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club, Triskelion Arts, The Dance Complex (Boston Globe Critics Pick 2014 & 2015), Les Champs Melisey, Artbeat, Dance for World Community, AS220, Connecticut College, Third Life Studios, RAW Boston (2014 Performer of the Year), and The International Festival of Arts & Ideas, as well as residencies at The Dragon's Egg, The Dance Complex, and Green Street Studios.
   
Where your support goes
Any and all of your support will help go towards...


Compensating the artists! This includes the choreographers, technical designer, and most importantly the performers, who have been working tirelessly in weekly rehearsals since summer 2015.
Paying for the studio space for the performances, as well as for rehearsal rental.
Paying for photo and video documentation of the performance.

Promotional materials including posters, flyers, and business cards.

Future projects! Grant Jacoby & Dancers has exciting upcoming opportunities, so any extra funds will go towards insuring that other projects in the future can be possible.

If we do not make our entire goal, all of the money will still go to good use in compensating the resident and guest artists for all of their hard work so far. 
Every penny counts! In a world where the arts is unfortunately underfunded, any contribution you can make is vital in ensuring that this performance goes smoothly, and that there will be plenty more in years to come.
Other ways you can helpSome people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:
Spread the word! If you know anyone else who would be interested in our mission and willing to donate, or just to come to the show...let them know! We always want to reach new audiences.
Share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or other social media outlets.
Come to our performance! Even if you can't donate now, we would love to see you in the audience, cheering on our talented and hard-working dancers.
We hope that you will be a part in making this performance a success! We can't thank you enough for your support.

story:
"High atop a railroad trestle that spans a bone dry creek, two teenagers plan to race across the bridge against an oncoming locomotive. At first their scheme adds excitement to life in a small factory town during the Great Depression, then sensual experience awakens dangerous passions in an era of stifled ambitions. With theatrical flourish and lyrical finesse, Naomi Wallace delves into a world where people struggle to change lives that bear down upon them." -Broadway Play Publishing Inc.

The Trestle at Pope Lick Creek is a senior project production at SUNY Purchase College. Victoria Kulak (Director) and Dan Lemp (Sound Design) wanted to create a production of substance revolving around the themes of coming of age, sexual awakening,  family hardships, and so much more. The Great Depression was such a significant time in America that has remained permanently in not only our memories, but also our thoughts and fears. What does a family do to put food on the table when no one can find a job? How does someone overcome the loss of a close friend and potential love when they are the one who is being blamed for it? These are all of the themes that are tremendous factors to the great depression and echo into the present.

The people involved in this production have high hopes and dreams involving the building of an immensely beautiful trestle onstage, and renting period accurate costumes. These are only a few aspects of the show that we hope to accomplish. However, with any production, there comes a massive amount of expenses. These expenses include, but aren't limited to: historically accurate props, wood to build the trestle, makeup, production equipment, printing money, and even the rights to the play itself! Every little bit of money counts and we are so incredibly thankful for your support and encouragement.

Showdates: (Performances will be held in the Humanities Theatre at Purchase College. Free Admission!) 

Thursday Dec 10th @ 7:30 pm

Friday Dec 11th @ 7:30 pm

Saturday Dec 12th @ 7:30 pm

CAST:

Dalton: Ty Corbin

Pace: Gretchen Hannah Burke

Gin: Ginny Edinger

Dray: Myles Clohessy

Chas: Vince Lane


PRODUCTION TEAM:

Director: Victoria Kulak

Stage Manager: Alyssa Keller

Sound Designer: Dan Lemp

Set Designer: Lora Press

Lighting Designer: Becky Nussbaum

Costume Designer: Claire Buckley

Dramaturg: Alvaro Jambrina

story:
About Us and Our Project

We are a married actor-couple, together for 15 years and counting.  Over seven years ago, we got the idea to create our own theater piece about the greatest theatrical actor-couple of all time, “The Lunts,” Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne.  That started us on an incredible journey of research (including a private tour at their Wisconsin home, Ten Chimneys), writing and re-writing, and finally a script: LUNT AND FONTANNE: The Celestials of Broadway.  After getting a fabulous director, Owen Thompson, and gifted production team on board, we had a short workshop run of the play at a small theater in New York City, in May 2015.

This is a dream project for us, so we want to continue with this play... get it out there, to theater festivals, regional theaters, colleges... and that will cost some money.  We already have a great start in 2016, with invitations to bring the show to a theater in San Antonio, Texas and a slot in the 20th New York International Fringe Festival!  Other theaters have expressed interest, but the more we perform and create buzz, the more bookings will materialize.  The 2015 performances already cost us a few bucks, so we’re counting on theater lovers (and theater history lovers) to help us continue producing this new and exciting play.

Help us bring The Lunts back on stage!

Being in the business for over twenty years, we know how to do this, but making theater costs money, and the box office only covers a portion of the expenses... we need to pay our team (director, stage manager, etc.) as well as designers, costumes, props, set pieces, rehearsal studio fees, and a professional publicist to get the word out to audiences, critics and the media about the show.

Check out the fun perks we are offering donors to the cause: everything from official show Fridge Magnets and signed 1930s Lunt "Taming of the Shrew" posters, to our own Mark Edward Lang offering up a celebrity impression of your choice (anyone from Laurence Olivier to Marlon Brando to a world-class Captain Kirk).  And all donations are tax deductible! (see below)

Make a Difference...

Last May we sold out our entire New York run of the show, with great response from the audiences.  We also chose not to invite critics the first time around, and it’s very important that our next New York run shows off the play in the best possible way... your donations will help make this happen.

We’re revved up and ready to bring this project to the next level: from the New York Fringe to Philadelphia, Edinburgh and beyond!   Yes, it’s a great vehicle for us as actors (so there are selfish motives here), but it’s also a way to keep alive the legacy of two of the most famous stage actors of their time... two performers whose work has been almost completely forgotten by modern audiences... as they chose to act on stage and not on film.  

We cover their incredible true story from their meeting in the 1920s, through fame and stardom in the 1930s (as they go to Hollywood and try their hand at film acting), followed by their difficult decision to go to London in the midst of WWII bombing, and feeling passe as the new generation of actors, playwrights and directors gained prominence in the 1950s.  But at it’s core is the strength of an unbreakable marriage: a partnership that stood through all of the highs and lows, the adversity and arguments, and came through stronger than ever.

LUNT AND FONTANNE: THE CELESTIALS OF BROADWAY is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of LUNT AND FONTANNE: THE CELESTIALS OF BROADWAY must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Or, help us spread the word! 

And yes, we understand that not everyone can give (or give a lot)... we’re ACTORS! But if you’re not able to contribute monetarily, we’d be grateful if you could do a couple of things: help us get the word out about the show (luntandfontanne.com), share this campaign with your theater loving friends on Facebook or email, and most importantly send us your positive energy– good thoughts and prayers for a bright future with LUNT AND FONTANNE: The Celestials of Broadway. 

We THANK YOU so much for your time and consideration!
Team Lunt
Alison J. Murphy & Mark Edward Lang
Owen Thompson, Director
Patrick Hyland. Company Manager
TBE Theatrical
New York City

story:
PARTS UNKNOWN

Hello! My name is David Reilly. I'm a comedian and writer based in Dublin, Ireland. I've written a play, my first, and it is going to be on in February as part of the Scene + Heard festival in Dublin's Smock Alley Theatre. The piece is called Parts Unknown and here's the blurb:

The sons of a wrestling legend clash over his legacy and the Good Friday referendum. The debut play from comedian Davey Reilly, starring Dermot Ward (Game of Thrones) and Pete O’Hanlon (Rocketman).

 

THE TEAM

Director: David Reilly -  

Producer: Shawna Scott - 

Cast:

  • Dermot Ward - 
  • Pete O'Hanlon -

 

PUT THE FUN IN FUNDING

Parts Unknown is a huge labour of love for myself and the team. With your generous contribution and support, you will be helping towards the costs of rehearsal spaces, marketing & promotion, lighting & sound design, props & transport, etc. If this run of Parts Unknown is successful, it will potentially allow us to develop it into a full length play, but to do that we need help from our community.

There are various tiers for you to choose from, each with their own perks.

You can keep up with the production on Instagram by following us @ArtIsHard, the theatre company I've set up for this, and future productions.

IF YOU CAN'T CONTRIBUTE

Not everyone is in a position to be able to donate, and I wouldn't want anyone's donation to put them at a disadvantage financially. Telling your pals and sharing the link on social media is a great way to help as well, and is no less appreciated.

Thank you, 

David

story:
The Show

Unassuming Mormon, Connor Jorgensen, becomes the center of national media frenzy when his tweets about a Mormon presidential candidate go viral. Inspired by comments the candidate allegedly made in a church meeting, Connor spreads his presidential pick’s views on “the gays, gangsters and bleeding hearts”, leading ambitious reporter Lydia Strout to his door.

As Lydia tries to find the man hiding behind the orthodox Mormon facade, and Connor navigates the unfamiliar world of Tweets, news feeds, and blogs, both are forced to confront the choice between living by facts or walking by faith.

At its core, #MormonInChief is about young people trying to figure out what they can believe in as they navigate a world full of technology, social media, news outlets, and faith. #MormonInChief addresses highly topical issues in a fresh, humorous, and often touching way.

Written by Matthew Greene, directed by Austin Regan, and performed by the very talented Jesse Liebman, Nicole Rodenburg, and Karis Danish, #MormonInChief will be performed at the New York International Fringe Festival from August 10-26, 2012. FringeNYC is one of the top 5 attended cultural events in NYC, and we are honored and excited to be part of such an amazing festival. But we need your help in order to make it happen!

What We Need & What You Get

FringeNYC is an incredible organization and it provides each of its productions with a historic downtown theater space, lighting and sound equipment, wonderful volunteer support, and personalized publicity. However, there are a few things that FringeNYC does not pick up the tab for, including...

  • Rehearsal Studio Fees
  • Set materials
  • Projection rental
  • Props and Costumes
  • Actors' Equity Stipends
  • Designer Fees
  • Transportation Expenses

We need a little extra help covering these costs to bring to life the vision of our playwright, director, and amazing designers! Every bit helps towards renting a high quality projector, or building a door, or paying an actor's subway fare to rehearsal. 

Our Amazing Team

Michael Holt, our fearless producer, is a producer, general manager and theater marketing consultant in NYC. After graduating with a Bachelor of Science in Business Management Marketing from Brigham Young University, he began working as a marketing associate for Hale Center Theater in Orem, Utah. Upon moving to NYC, Michael began collaborating with Lisa Dozier (Lisa Dozier Productions) on National Alliance for Musical Theater's Festival of New Musicals. He has been an assistant and associate general manager at LDP on off-off works including Leave the Balcony Open (3LD) and Spring Alive! (Dixon Place). Current projects include A Letter to Harvey Milk (NYMF) and Swing State (NYMF). Michael has been on staff at Stuart Thompson Productions, where he worked on the Tony Award winning Death of a Salesman, as well as last season's hit, The Book of Mormon. He's ecstatic to be able to bring the extraordinarily well written #MormonInChief to the stage.

Matthew Greene is our talented playwright who grew up in California, graduated from Brigham Young University with a BA in Theater, and now lives in NYC. His plays have been produced all over the US. Although he and Michael both attended BYU at the same time, they didn't meet until they were both living in NYC, and started collaborating together. Matthew wrote #MormonInChief as he personally grappled with many of the themes from the play. Like many of his other plays, #MormonInChief deals with how young people address the issue of faith in their lives.  He's very excited to make his NYC premiere at FringeNYC.

Our director, Austin Regan is extremely excited to be working on the piece. His recent work includes It Started With A Dream at the 92nd St. Y; Bromance In Concert at 92Y Tribeca; Hey, You Know What...? at the Julia Miles Theater and the Zipper Factory; and The Who's Tommy at the Boston Conservatory, where he also served on the faculty of the theater department. As Associate and Assistant Director, Austin has worked on Broadway (On A Clear Day...; American Idiot; Everyday Rapture), national tours, regional premieres, and at the Metropolitan Opera.

Together we've put together an amazing team of actors and designers, which you can learn about at our website, http://www.mormoninchiefplay.com

What Happens After Fringe

FringeNYC has been a launching pad for writers, actors, directors, and designers for the past 16 years, including the hit musical Urinetown, which made its premiere at Fringe in 2000 and became a Broadway sensation. We hope that Fringe will be a launching pad for our entire team, and allow doors to be opened for us all. YOU can be a part of making that possible by donating to our campaign. And when we have opportunities presented to us because of your support, you can trust that we will recognize YOU for making it possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you're in the NYC area from August 10-26, 2012, BUY TICKETS and come see our show! We'll be performing in the Kraine Theater (exact dates TBA), and tickets will be limited, so make sure to buy them when they go on sale July 20th.
  • Follow us on Twitter @MormonInChief and Like us on Facebook
  • Tell your friends about our show!

Follow us on Twitter @MormonInChief and Like us on Facebook

story:
UPDATE 8/25/11: Thanks to your generosity and support, we have surpassed our goal! Soo…NEW GOAL! We’ve had 65 extraordinary superstars donate; let’s make it 75 before September 1st. Any extra money we raise goes to creating infrastructure to help make Conspire a sustainable organization. Thank you!!


_______________


Conspire Theatre seeks to raise $3,000 by September 1st to enable us to expand our long-running program for incarcerated women into Maximum Security at the Travis County Jail. You can help us by making a gift today!

Our Story

In June of 2009, Katherine Craft started a theatre workshop for incarcerated women at the Travis County Correctional Complex in Del Valle, Texas.  To her surprise and delight, they loved it and for the next two years Katherine and the women, with the help of several other Austin artists, reflected on their lives, challenges, hopes, dreams and disappointments through the mediums of theatre and creative writing.

Michelle Dahlenburg came on board as a co-facilitator and program developer in July of 2011, and with their powers combined, Katherine and Michelle have a plan to grow the organization, expand programming and eventually offer services to women in the free world as well in multiple jails and prisons in central Texas. 

The Impact

Quoted from a letter of support by the Social Services Program Coordinator at the Travis County Correctional Complex:

Gender specific programs for incarcerated women are important because there is a growing recognition that women typically enter the system from different pathways than men...they come into the program trying to figure out how to end a substance dependence that has kept them in jail and away from their children.


The therapy addressing this substance abuse and post-traumatic stress is very difficult for them.  To give the women a way to express themselves in healthier and more positives ways, Conspire Theatre began their first group here in June of 2009. Conspire Theatre staff facilitates through a relaxed team building style that encourages self-discovery, creativity, and teamwork.

Perhaps most important, is the fact that the women are exposed to a bigger world of literature, theatre and music that they have never had the opportunity to experience. No matter what their education level, the women are inspired to learn.

Quotes from the women in our class:
“This is a wonderful class – it makes us forget that we are in stripes.  We actually feel free again.”
“Thank you… I will never forget you guys.”
“I believe this class has been a wonderful exercise and stress reliever.”
“You all were a blessing to me despite of me being in jail.”

What We Need & What You Get

Our needs are simple: facilitators, class supplies and gas.  The amount we're raising is just the beginning - but it will help us get started.   

We need great facilitators who know how to blend theatre and social work, and how to operate successfully in a stressful jail environment.  Supplies aren't much but they are important - colorful folders, pencils, markers, paper, flip charts and printing costs for our next chap book of women's writings.  The price of gas keeps going up and in central Texas, the jails and prisons are a good drive away from Austin.  WE do carpool but the cars can't run on love alone. 

How we'll spend your money:
  • 75% on facilitators' stipend through December
  • 10% on program supplies, which includes another chapbook self-published by the end of 2011
  • 10% for our sponsoring organization, which supports us in a number of ways and makes your contribution tax-deductible.
  • 5% on gas

We have a whole smorgasbord of incentives over to the right, and you also get the knowledge that you are supporting come cutting edge programming that can help redefine our criminal justice system.  (Plus it's tax-deductible - have I mentioned that yet?)

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!  Start a conspiracy!  So much of what we do is hidden, it can be hard to get people to understand the whys and hows.  Send this campaign to your friends and their friends, and to everyone else you know.  Share it on Facebook.  Post it on Twitter.  Take it over to the cool kids at Google +, y'all.  Get out your internet bullhorn and make it known! 

Conspire Theatre is a sponsored project of the Austin Creative Alliance, a 501(c)3 organization, which makes your donations tax-deductible.  We may contact you for your mailing address to ensure that you receive proper notification of the tax-deductible status of your donation.  All incentives will be disbursed AFTER the campaign ends on September 1st.  We are currently operating under a grant from the City of Austin Cultural Contracts.
story_txt:
UPDATE 8/25/11: Thanks to your generosity and support, we have surpassed our goal! Soo…NEW GOAL! We’ve had 65 extraordinary superstars donate; 
let’s make it 75 before September 1st. Any extra money we raise goes to 
creating infrastructure to help make Conspire a sustainable 
organization. Thank you!!


_______________
Conspire Theatre seeks to raise $3,000 by September 1st to enable us to 
expand our long-running program for incarcerated women into Maximum Security at the Travis County Jail. You 
can help us by making a gift today!
Our Story

In June of 2009, Katherine Craft started a theatre workshop for incarcerated women at the Travis County Correctional Complex in Del Valle, Texas.  To her surprise and delight, they loved it and for the next two years Katherine and the women, with the help of several other Austin artists, reflected on their lives, challenges, hopes, dreams and disappointments through the mediums of theatre and creative writing.Michelle Dahlenburg came on board as a co-facilitator and program developer in July of 2011, and with their powers combined, Katherine and Michelle have a plan to grow the organization, expand programming and eventually offer services to women in the free world as well in multiple jails and prisons in central Texas.  
The Impact

Quoted from a letter of support by the Social Services Program Coordinator at the Travis County Correctional Complex: 
Gender specific programs for incarcerated women are important because 
there is a growing recognition that women typically enter the system 
from different pathways than men...they come into the program trying to figure
 out how to end a substance dependence that has kept them in jail and 
away from their children.

The
 therapy addressing this substance abuse and post-traumatic stress is 
very difficult for them.  To give the women a way to 
express themselves in healthier and more positives ways, Conspire 
Theatre began their first group here in June of 2009. Conspire Theatre 
staff facilitates through a relaxed team building style that encourages 
self-discovery, creativity, and teamwork.Perhaps most important, is the fact that the women are exposed to a bigger
 world of literature, theatre and music that they have never had the 
opportunity to experience. No matter what their education level, the 
women are inspired to learn. 
Quotes from the women in our class:
“This is a wonderful class – it makes us forget that we are in stripes.  We actually feel free again.” “Thank you… I will never forget you guys.”“I believe this class has been a wonderful exercise and stress reliever.”“You all were a blessing to me despite of me being in jail.”

What We Need & What You Get
Our needs are simple: facilitators, class supplies and gas.  The amount we're raising is just the beginning - but it will help us get started.    We need great facilitators who know how to blend theatre and social work, and how to operate successfully in a stressful jail environment.  Supplies aren't much but they are important - colorful folders, pencils, markers, paper, flip charts and printing costs for our next chap book of women's writings.  The price of gas keeps going up and in central Texas, the jails and prisons are a good drive away from Austin.  WE do carpool but the cars can't run on love alone.  How we'll spend your money:
75% on facilitators' stipend through December
10% on program supplies, which includes another chapbook self-published by the end of 2011
10% for our sponsoring organization, which supports us in a number of ways and makes your contribution tax-deductible. 

5% on gas

We have a whole smorgasbord of incentives over to the right, and you also get the knowledge that you are supporting come cutting edge programming that can help redefine our criminal justice system.  (Plus it's tax-deductible - have I mentioned that yet?) 
Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!  Start a conspiracy!  So much of what we do is 
hidden, it can be hard to get people to understand the whys and hows.  
Send this campaign to your friends and their friends, and to everyone 
else you know.  Share it on Facebook.  Post it on Twitter.  Take it over

story:
What's Coming Up

This October at the Drilling Company Theatre, we will be presenting the world premiere of Ken Ferrigni's cyber-thriller, Mangella, the story of a low-rent computer hacker, his needy computer, his dementia-ridden father, and a time-traveling prostitute who is just trying to make it to tomorrow.  This play is a dark, disturbing, hilarious look at deep human relationships and the fantasies created by our connectivity to the ever expanding virtual world.

The Impact

We believe that the sharing of creativity leads to a healthier, happier, stronger, more compassionate society.


By cultivating an environment that encourages artists from all fields to challenge their skills and talents we build a haven for innovative growth and achievement.  By focusing on work that is new or forgotten we provide entertaining, exciting, and engaging productions.  By composing events that explore the performer/audience relationship we constantly endeavor to build theatrical experiences which encourage the growth of social unity.


Talent and hard work are just part of the production process.  It takes a good deal of money to produce theater in New York.  We need your help.  Your donation will help complete the following tasks which are vital tools for the success of our upcoming season:


- hiring a press agent

- paying for rehearsal and performance space

- adding a projector and wireless microphones to our technological arsenal

- paying our creative contributors for their dedication, professionalism and creativity


A very small amount of our yearly budget comes from ticket sales and our monthly original series Our Bar.  Most of our costs are covered by contributions, small or large, from individuals who are excited by the notion that theater can bring people together in a way that improves our society.  This campaign offers you an easy, rewarding, exciting way to help us make theater happen.     


Donate now.  Spread the word.  Become part of the project.  


***As a bonus perk, if you donate by Friday, September 23, you will receive an mp3 of your very own song, written and recorded especially for you by the members of Project: Theater.  Just make sure to answer these four questions in the message portion (Step 4):


1. What is your full name?

2. What is your favorite food?

3. What is your favorite animal?

4. What is your favorite place?


For more information, visit us at www.projecttheater.org.


Project: Theater is a registered 501(c)3 not-for-profit corporation and a proud member of ART/NY and Materials for the Arts.  All donations to Project: Theater are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
