story:
The New Theatre Project

Season 3: Reinvention

After two successful seasons, three homes, ten productions, and tons of readings of new work, The New Theatre Project is proud to offer its third season of wildly inventive theatre to Ypsilanti. Producing an entire season of world premieres with a focus on ensemble work and collaborative development, TNTP strives to challenge ourselves artistically and provide professional performance and design opportunities for new and young artists. 

 

What you're funding:

Renovation of the basement

To house the new Basement Studio Theater to showcase new work all season long completely free of charge to the public. Stagings and readings of never before seen plays get their tryout in one of the creepiest and coolest basements in Ypsi. The Basement Studio will also house an interactive theater experience in October and the New Work Series throughout the year. All shows in the Basement will be pay-what-you-can. 

Educational series

We are adding an educational mission to our goals in Season 3. We recognize the unparralled ability for the theatre to create positive differences in the lives of young people. TNTP will read and stage world premieres of work by high school students and will launch a series of classes in the summer of 2013 in the areas of playwrighting, directing, acting, and devised performance. 

Performer and designer salaries 

We pride ourselves on having some of the highest quality young professional performers in Southeast Michigan. Some funds for this campaign will go towards the artists creating work for TNTP. Can't do it without all these beautiful people. 

And our continued committment to new work development. 


Sneak preview of Season 3: Reinvention

Woyzeck

AN INTERACTIVE THEATRICAL HAUNTED HOUSE

by Georg Büchner in an adaptation by Audra Lord, directed by Brian Carbine

in a co-production with Threefold Productions and the Brendalinda Performance Collective

October 2012

“Slowly, take it slowly. One thing after another one.”

An extremely prolific young playwright dies without completing one of his greatest masterpieces. Woyzeck—a terrifying play about the disastrous effects of human jealousy—lies incomplete, fragmented, and waiting for any artist crazy enough to take it on. TNTP joins forces with Threefold Productions and the Brendalinda Performance Collection to transform the piece into an interactive haunted house where the audience decides how to best complete Büchner’s play.

 

TBA

WORLD PREMIERE COMEDY

directed by TNTP’s new Associate Artistic Director Emilie Samuelsen

January 2013

 

Edward II

WORLD PREMIERE CLASSICAL ADAPTATION

based on the play by Christopher Marlowe in an adaptation by Jason Sebacher, directed by Keith Paul Medelis

March 2013

“Is it not queer that he is thus bewitched?”

Before Shakespeare, Marlowe writes an epic tragedy about a young and naïve king and his obsession with his once banished lover. A deeply erotic and shocking tale of a homosexual love affair that destroys two men and the fate of an entire nation. TNTP produces the classical play in a wildly reimagined way for a contemporary audience.

 

The American Crowbar Case

INDIE-ROCK MUSICAL

featuring the music of Match by Match with a book by Jason Sebacher, directed by Keith Paul Medelis

April 2013

“All we’ve got is one another.”

A revival and reworking of one of TNTP’s most successful collaborations—a true reinvention of ourselves. In 1846, Phineas Gage suffers an accident that drives a three-foot iron rod through his skull. He recovers miraculously and entirely in almost no time but is described in the only brief news article about his case as “no longer Gage.” The American Crowbar Case, based on the concept album from Ann Arbor-based musicians Match by Match, imagines the life of Gage and the effects of the accident on his new wife Constance and a mysterious stranger known only as Missy. A story about the consuming power of love and its remarkable ability to transform in an instant. 

 

Wolf Cry Wolf

WORLD PREMIERE DRAMA

by Kevin Kautzman, directed by Keith Paul Medelis

July 2013

“People make believe with each other. It’s how we get through the night.”

When Steph returns home to North Dakota for the first time in years and surprises her estranged childhood friend Jane, they descend into their memories and relive the summer Jane told Steph her deepest secret: she knows how turn into a wolf. Wolf Cry Wolf looks at the fine line between memory and imagination and at the lies we tell to survive our shadows. A beautiful new play from the playwright of last season’s comedy If You Start a Fire [Be Prepared to Burn].

 

What you'll get:

Check out all da perks! We're giving away tons of free tickets for any of our shows. You'll also get a mention in all of our programs for Season 3: Reinvention.

Be a part of something new. Support us with any amount you have! Everything counts!

story:
Your Contribution is Tax-Deductible

You can contribute to this campaign in the same way that you normally contribute to other IndieGoGo campaigns; the above language just means that the money flows to us through our fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas, so that you can legally claim a tax deduction (minus the value of any material goods that we send you such as t-shirts etc.).

About We the People

Please help us to fund these shows in which we are making a fun and thought-provoking dance available to the public for free!

We are seeking to cover production expenses for our upcoming performances of We the People in the 2011 Philly Fringe/Live Arts Festival.  For the Fringe performances we'll have a cast of 7 dancers, with artists from Philadelphia and New York performing together in these shows.  We've been developing this dance since November 2010 and will bring it to historic Washington Square park in Philadelphia this September.  Since we're performing in a public park, we won't be charging admission to our Fringe shows and are thus completely dependent on donations to cover costs. 

We the People is a game-like structured improvisation that changes each time it is performed.  Moving between conflict and cooperation, our dance reflects on political polarization and explores struggle as both a personal and a shared experience.

Read our Fringe Blog article

The Philly Fringe blog recently interviewed Lacy about the creation of We the People.  Read Logan Tiberi-Warner's article about our Fringe performances here.


For a "Backstage" View

We've been keeping a video journal blog throughout the development of We the People.  For this inside look at our dance, visit http://dancejournal.lacyjames.com


Where the Money Goes

This project has a relatively modest budget, since we don't have to rent a theater for our Fringe shows.  However, there are many expenses to cover -- such as our Philly Fringe fees ($320), travel expenses for those artists who are coming from NYC to perform ($25 round trip per artist), studio space for the rehearsal and development of the work ($10/hour), the fee for a permit to perform in Washington Square ($75) and a $100 stipend for each artist -- a stipend which represents only a token payment, given the many hours of rehearsal time and the expertise that each artist has devoted to this project.


The Perks!

We hope that you will enjoy the special perks to the right.  And of course, we hope that you can join us in Washington Square on the afternoon of September 4th or 5th -- but even if you can't be there in person you can still see the show!  Each contributor to this IndieGoGo campaign will be sent a link to a video of one of our Fringe performances.

Thanks for helping us to fund our work!

--------

Lacy James is a choreographer, singer/songwriter and performer who has been creating dances and music in New York City, Philadelphia, and beyond for the past 25 years.   She is currently working with dancers in both Philadelphia and NYC to create the structured improvisation We the People.  To learn more about Lacy and Mereminne Dancers, visit our website.

Photos 1-9, 11-12 and 14 in our pitch video: Bill Hebert

story:
Heres The Idea

 We (NathanaelT Productions LLC) want to pay artists. We all know them by name the guys and gals that get on stage an wow us with their talents! But do we know the situation? What if I were to tell you that on average each actor on that stage had to spend $300-$500 in expenses during the run of the show. You would think I was crazy. What do you mean they have to pay that much? Could you imagine having to shell out that kinda of money to get the chance just to do your job? Now what if I was to tell you that very few of them ever get reimbursed for that expense?"Where does the money go?" you ask.  The money goes to things like gas, costumes, food, and other expenses just needed to get from the audition stage to the performance stage.

The Math: 

Now your thinking well why don't we pay them? Don't I pay like $15 a ticket? There in lies the problem. The following is an example of where the money goes to an average non musical performance: Tickets in this area are $15 a piece on average for public use theaters being able to sit around 100 people a night. ($15 X 100 people = $1500 a night right?) Well not quite. Most theaters will require comps, lets average those to 5 people a night, shall we? ($15 per ticket X 95 people= $1,425 gross) thats only if we sell out, not very likely. Now lets say the show runs for two weekends at four nights a weekend to sold out crowds, thats (($1,425 gross X4 nights) X 2 weekends= $11,400) with average theater rental a night being $250 a night, and the show running for 8 performances that ($250 rental X 8 performances= $2,000 in rent) and the average performance rights fees totaling about $400 for that length of time  ($2,000 rent+ $400 rights = $2,400) Then add in the cost of props and set around another $4,000 depending on the show. ($2,400 rent and rights + $4,000 props and sets = $6,400) WOW thats a lot of money, but unfortunately we are not done yet. We still haven't gotten to costumes or lighting or advertising and printing cost. Lets lump those all together and conservatively say the total is $3,000. Honestly I've seen this go a lot higher. ($6,400 + $3,000 = $9,400 total cost). Now lets subtract what we owe from what we made, shall we? ( $11,400 gross profit - $9,400 cost= $2,000 net profit). $2,000 thats kinda sad, and remember this is the best case scenario. Thats with sold out crowds every night. Some Theater Companies lose money on most of their shows. This is really a labor of love.

 

What You Can Do:

With all of the cost there really isn't any money left to pay the people that work so hard to bring us these shows, but we can all be a part of changing that. Your Donation will simply go to paying the artists, thats it! Nothing more, nothing less. Thats what we want to do is get them payed. Will you help?  

                 

 

What You Get & What We Need

 -Now Your thinking to yourself "Great You need money but whats in it for me?"  

  • Contributor Perks 
    • $1-$100  Thespian Level: For Sponsorship of $1 to $100 Your name appears in the program in the Thespian sponsors section.   
    • $101-$300 Stage Manager Level: For Sponsorship of $101 to $300 you receive One free ticket to the performance of your choice. Your name will also appear in the program in the Stage Manager sponsors section.
    • $301-$500 Director Level: For Sponsorship of $301 to $500 you receive two free tickets to the Performance of your choice. Your name will also appear in the program in the Director sponsors section.
    • $501-$1,000 Producer Level: For Sponsorship of $501 to $1,000 YOU  ARE OUR HERO! You receive One free Season Pass. Which allows you access to any of the performances (thats over 27 performances just in 2012!) provided that there is available seating. Your name will also appear in the program in the Producers sponsors section.
    • $1,001+ Executive Producer Level: For Sponsorship of$1,001+ YOU ARE A SUPER HEREO! You receive Two Free Season Passes. Which allows you and a guest access to any of the performances (thats over 27 performances just in 2012!)  provided that there is available seating. Your name will also appear in the program in the Executive Producers sponsors section.

 

  • Where is the money going? 
    • The business of Theater is a tricky one. Companies are constantly trying to make sure they have enough to pay all the bills. The money that you will be contributing will not be going into the normal production fund but will be held specifically to pay all the great artists that have come together to produce the shows that we all love so much. These funds are not to pay for the extravagance of the production but are going to be used to pay the people who on average spend $300-$500 in expenses just to be able to grace us with their presence on stage.They support us in the development of our ideas, and life experiences. its about time we started supporting them.     

 

  • What happens if we don't raise the whole $2,500 by August 26th ? 
    • This Campaign is a Flexible Funding Campaign which means that we get to keep whatever we make by the end of the campaign. Thats Fabulous cause it means the money will still go to help artists! 

 

I'm a bit short on cash, can I still help?

You can be a huge help by spreading the word! Facebook, Twitter, Google+, and word of mouth are all great ways to tell everyone you know how they can help bring this huge dream to life.

What if I were to tell you that on average each actor on that stage had to spend $300-$500 in expenses during the run of the show. You would think I was crazy. What do you mean they have to pay that much? Could you imagine having to shell out that kinda of money to get the chance just to do your job? Now what if I was to tell you that very few of them ever get reimbursed for that expense?"Where does the money go?" you ask.  The money goes to things like gas, costumes, food, and other expenses just needed to get from the audition stage to the performance stage.
The Math: 
Now your thinking well why don't we pay them? Don't I pay like $15 a ticket? There in lies the problem. The following is an example of where the money goes to an average non musical performance: Tickets in this area are $15 a piece on average for public use theaters being able to sit around 100 people a night. ($15 X 100 people = $1500 a night right?) Well not quite. Most theaters will require comps, lets average those to 5 people a night, shall we? ($15 per ticket X 95 people= $1,425 gross) thats only if we sell out, not very likely. Now lets say the show runs for two weekends at four nights a weekend to sold out crowds, thats (($1,425 gross X4 nights) X 2 weekends= $11,400) with average theater rental a night being $250 a night, and the show running for 8 performances that ($250 rental X 8 performances= $2,000 in rent) and the average performance rights fees totaling about $400 for that length of time  ($2,000 rent+ $400 rights = $2,400) Then add in the cost of props and set around another $4,000 depending on the show. ($2,400 rent and rights + $4,000 props and sets = $6,400) WOW thats a lot of money, but unfortunately we are not done yet. We still haven't gotten to costumes or lighting or advertising and printing cost. Lets lump those all together and conservatively say the total is $3,000. Honestly I've seen this go a lot higher. ($6,400 + $3,000 = $9,400 total cost). Now lets subtract what we owe from what we made, shall we? ( $11,400 gross profit - $9,400 cost= $2,000 net profit). $2,000 thats kinda sad, and remember this is the best case scenario. Thats with sold out crowds every night. Some Theater Companies lose money on most of their shows. This is really a labor of love.
 
What You Can Do:
With all of the cost there really isn't any money left to pay the people that work so hard to bring us these shows, but we can all be a part of changing that. Your Donation will simply go to paying the artists, thats it! Nothing more, nothing less. Thats what we want to do is get them payed. Will you help?  
                 
 
What You Get & What We Need


 -Now Your thinking to yourself "Great You need money but whats in it for me?"  

Contributor Perks 

$1-$100  Thespian Level: For Sponsorship of $1 to $100 Your name appears in the program in the Thespian sponsors section.   






$101-$300 Stage Manager Level: For Sponsorship of $101 to $300 you receive One free ticket to the performance of your choice. Your name will also appear in the program in the Stage Manager sponsors section.






$301-$500 Director Level: For Sponsorship of $301 to $500 you receive two free tickets to the Performance of your choice. Your name will also appear in the program in the Director sponsors section.






$501-$1,000 Producer Level: For Sponsorship of $501 to $1,000 YOU  ARE OUR HERO! You receive One free Season Pass. Which allows you access to any of the performances (thats over 27 performances just in 2012!) provided that there is available seating. Your name will also appear in the program in the Producers sponsors section.






$1,001+ Executive Producer Level: For Sponsorship of$1,001+ YOU ARE A SUPER HEREO! You receive Two Free Season Passes. Which allows you and a guest access to any of the performances (thats over 27 performances just in 2012!)  provided that there is available seating. Your name will also appear in the program in the Executive Producers sponsors section.



 

Where is the money going? 

The business of Theater is a tricky one. Companies are constantly trying to make sure they have enough to pay all the bills. The money that you will be contributing will not be going into the normal production fund but will be held specifically to pay all the great artists that have come together to produce the shows that we all love so much. These funds are not to pay for the extravagance of the production but are going to be used to pay the people who on average spend $300-$500 in expenses just to be able to grace us with their presence on stage.They support us in the development of our ideas, and life experiences. its about time we started supporting them.     



 

What happens if we don't raise the whole $2,500 by August 26th ? 

This Campaign is a Flexible Funding Campaign which means that we get to keep whatever we make by the end of the campaign. Thats Fabulous cause it means the money will still go to help artists! 





 


I'm a bit short on cash, can I still help?
You can be a huge help by spreading the word! Facebook, Twitter, Google+, and word of mouth are all great ways to tell everyone you know how they can help bring this huge dream to life.

story:
Eclectic Company Theatre is unlike any other local theatre in that we have no artistic director.  The members decide what ought to be produced, and the result is a rare collection of high quality productions that many other theatres would be too afraid to produce. 

Our next show, Last Train to Nibroc is a wonderful play by Arlene Hutton...and is set to open at Eclectic on April12, 2012!

 

December, 1940.  A train bears east carrying the bodies of two legendary authors.  It also carries two people in search of happiness. All aboard for this funny, touching journey of the heart.

 

This charming character-driven piece played to great acclaim at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and Off-Broadway.  Our production is being directed by the multi-talented Kerr Seth Lordygan and features the amazing acting talents of Frank Krueger and Rebecca Lane.

Live theatre is a vital necessity to contemporary culture, even more so now than in past years due to its lack of public funding.  Last Train to NIbroc has something for everyone, which makes it the ideal production worthy of your generous, tax-deductible donation.  Any amount helps!  We cannot do it without you!

Your donations will pay for our set, performers, stage manager, posters, publicity, programs and designers. We have some great perks - exclusive only to our donors! 


Thank you for supporting live theatre!!  

Help get the word out by using Indiegogo's share tools.  Post and email whomever you think can help out!

story:
ABOUT THE PROJECT

Cloven Tongues is a new play written by Victor Lesniewski.

The show will have a three week run in November 2013, at The Wild Project.

Cloven Tongues

Written by: Victor Lesniewski
Directed by: Michelle Bossy
Starring: Ema Lakovic

Synopsis:

When Lela, a woman with an unknown past, is arrested and held at the border, she is taken in by Jenny, a social worker, and Ronald, a priest, who find it takes nothing less than a miracle to unlock her deepest secrets.  As Lela's brutal personal history is revealed, Jenny and Ronald struggle with how best to heal her and find that they must also come to terms with their reasons for trying to help her in the first place.

A riveting drama about the effects of sex trafficking and war, Cloven Tongues is a fierce, biting play about the power and limitations of communication, altruism, and faith. Rendered with unapologetic grace, it is sure to be a compelling work of theater.

WHY WE NEED FUNDING TO MAKE IT HAPPEN

This campaign is geared specifically toward raising the funds necessary for our venue rental in order to house the production. The show will be presented at The Wild Project over three weeks in November 2013.

Any funds we raise in excess of our goal will be held and applied to production costs including marketing, design execution, and artist remuneration.

It is our hope that this production will serve as a launchpad for these amazing emerging artists, and that this premiere of Cloven Tongues is just the beginning of a very long life for the play.

Because our producer, Lauren Rayner, is fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, all donations are tax-deductible.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We understand that not everyone is in a position to give to this campaign. If you cannot help us out financially, please help us by spreading the word. Email this campaign to your friends, share us with your friends on Facebook or Twitter, and share us using your Indiegogo tools.

And, in just a few months, make sure to come out to the show! We're excited to see you there!

THE TEAM

Victor Lesniewski's (Playwright) plays include Where Bison Run (Ars Nova Out Loud) and Couriers and Contrabands (Workshop Presentation at New York Theatre Workshop).  He also wrote the book and lyrics for Conspiracy: A Love Story, a musical comedy that premiered in the Midtown International Theatre Festival and received five Best of the Festival nominations including Best Musical and Best Music & Lyrics.  His short play First Breath After Total Devastation was produced in The Samuel French OOB Festival as well as by NYTE as part of their Capture the Flag Festival and his short play A50 was produced by F*It Club as part of their Spring Fling.  He is a 2012-13 Dramatists Guild Fellow.
 
Michelle Bossy (Director) is a New York based director and producer dedicated to bringing new plays to the stage.  She is the Associate Artistic Director of Primary Stages, where she has worked for the past decade and serves as the director of the Dorothy Strelsin New American Writer’s Group. She produced the World Premiere of Dread Awakening and directed and produced the premieres of Un Plugged In (by Brian Pracht); High School Confidential (for Primary Stages); Little Monsters (by Maria Alexandria Beech); South Beach Rapture (by David Caudle); Sarajevo’s Child; Cumberland; Low Brow; and Missing Mike Vitelle.  Michelle holds the first undergraduate directing degree from Webster University’s Conservatory of Theatre Arts. She teaches acting and playwriting for the Einhorn School of Performing Arts (ESPA) and directing for Syracuse University. Member: Lincoln Center Director’s Lab and the League of Professional Theatre Women.

Ema Lakovic (Actor) is from Bosnia. MFA: Acting, The New School for Drama. NYC credits: Eating the Newspaper performance, The New Museum; Displaced Wedding (Rivke), West End Theater; Neither Haven Nor Earth (Sima), Poliglot Theater; Hecuba (Hecuba), Theater for the New City; NSD credits: 4.48 Psychosis (Lead), Orestes 2.0 (Phrygian), Richard III (Queen Margaret), Stage Door (Olga Brant), Action (Lupe); European credits: Macbeth (Lady Macbeth), Antigone (Antigone), Message (Witch), Pax Bosnais (movement production played in more than ten different countries around the world). Other credits: acting and movement coach, drama therapy, teaching in Eastern Europe, The U.S., England, Singapore, Jordan, Italy, Greece, etc. Directing: Human Rites, Virginia Tech University (visiting professor 2003); The Sleepy Beauty, Acting Studio Sarajevo Bosnia; UrbanEtno, Sarajevo Bosnia; Masks, MTM Bosnia.

-----

Video directed by Mark Satin.

story:
WireBird Productions

WireBird was founded in 2013. Our aim is to present new, original, challenging dramatic works that have something to say about this world we live in, while never forgetting that our first job is to tell a damn good story.

Joanna is a dark comedy written by Neil Sharpson and directed by Aoife O' Donoghue. After a successful run as part of the 10 Days in Dublin festival, Wirebird are bringing Joanna back for a limited run in The New Theatre, Temple Bar, Dublin (http://www.thenewtheatre.com). 

JOANNA

Sharon’s dead. She said she was raped and no believed her. Then she killed herself and they believed that just fine. Now her sister Maria and best friend Nadine want revenge. So they contact Joanna. Joanna is an urban legend; a brutal vigilante who tortures and kills rapists. She arrives in town and soon Maria and Nadine are waiting in an abandoned ghost estate while Joanna very, very slowly murders the man who caused Sharon’s death. But when Joanna starts uncovering more details as to what actually happened to Sharon, will Nadine and Maria come to regret the force they’ve unleashed? For Joanna is not justice. She is not the law. She is not society. She is what comes after.

JOANNA - The New Theatre - 17th Feb to 22nd Feb 2014

Starring:

  • Paddy-Jo Malpas as Joanna
  • Clodagh Duggan as Maria
  • Caroline Harvey as Nadine

  • Written by Neil Sharpson
  • Directed by Aoife O'Donoghue 
  • Lighting Design by Eoghan Carrick
  • Images and Poster by Ste Murray
  • Produced by Emma Coen 

How you can help

In order to bring this story to life, we need a little bit of your help. If we reach our target, the money donated will help us to cover theatre rental fees, rehearsal space, marketing and set materials. 

The Impact

We believe this production will not only make for an enjoyable evening, but also raise awareness about important issues everyone comes in to contact with at some point in their lives. We received wonderful feedback from our run in 10 Days in Dublin and we're eager to share what we've done with an even bigger audience in the new year. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can afford to donate - and that's fine! Instead, we ask that you tell everyone about us - share our Indiegogo page, like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter and of course, come see us in The New Theatre next February! 

Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/WirebirdTheatreCompany

Tweet us: https://twitter.com/WireBirdTheatre

story:
Short Summary

Savage Wilde Traveling Players is a brand new Shakespeare company in the San Francisco Bay Area.  For our first show, we are partnering with Made Up Theatre in Fremont to put on Much Ado About Nothing.  Our goal as a company is to provide fast paced, small cast Shakespeare that's accessible to everyone.  Every show we perform will be no longer that 1.5 hours!  Future plans include presenting pop-up Shakespeare in parks all around the Bay Area and performing 1-hour cuts of Shakespeare's plays for school assemblies.

More information on the company at: http://savagewildeplayers.weebly.com

This campaign will help us get off the ground.  This first show is not only about putting on great theatre, but building relationships with patrons, actors, and our venue.  To get started, we need your help.  Your contributions at the ground level will help this company get off to a solid financial start and lead us down the road to producing Shakespeare around the Bay Area for years to come!!!


What We Need & What You Get

100% of the funding from this campaign will go to paying our actors.  No tricks.  No games.  No matter how much we raise, we'll pay our actors with it.  We want to see our actors get paid for their hard work, and this is our way of ensuring they will!

-The Thank You note (that you get at any donation level!) is printed on a limited run postcard for the show.  They will be handed out as publicity for the show, but only donors will get them signed by the full cast and the director!!!

-Any recognition on the website will stay with the show even after it's over.  Once "Much Ado" goes into our Past Shows section, all of the donor names will go with it... for as long as our website is up and running!!!  Check out our website at: http://savagewildeplayers.weebly.com

-The tote bag!  It's ONLY available to donors at the $75 level, so it's about as limited edition as you can get.  Here's a preview:

The text on the back reads: "I thank you. I am not of many words, but I thank you." -Don John, Much Ado About Nothing, Act I, Scene 1


The Impact

As a fledgling theatre company, we cannot hope to get off the ground without a little community support.  Thanks to the donations here, we'll make sure our professional actors get paid for their hard work.  It's as simple as that.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute, please help us by spreading the word!  Use Indiegogo's share tools to get the word out on Facebook and Twitter.  Or spread the word in any other way you can.  Thank you, in advance, for your help!

story:
CLICK HERE TO WATCH THE PILOT EPISODE!
CLICK HERE TO WATCH EPISODE 2: LADY'S MAN!

The New Colony is teaming up with The Inconvenience and The University of Chicago Theater and Performance Studies Program to produce our most ambitious project to date: B-Side Studio! This four week episodic adventure follows the motley staff of B-Side Studio, their antics, and their attempts to save their south side business in 1977.

Written and created by Ike Holter (Hit The Wall, ran Off-Broadway at the Barrow Street Theatre) and Evan Linder (5 Lesbians Eating a Quiche, ran Off-Broadway at the SoHo Playhouse), this all-American sitcom is sure to be a hit!

Each week of the run will feature a new episode which is filmed live to be released online as a web series the following week. This unique hybrid of The New Colony's stage and film departments will be crazy and we need your help to make it happen. Your contribution will help support film staff (camera operators, editors, engineers), equipment, and more!

Be a part of our live studio audience and watch the whole series:

Pilot: September 13 and 14 at 9/8c
Episode 2: Lady's Man: September 27 and 28 at 9/8c
Episode 3: A New Lady: October 4 and 5 at 9/8c
Finale: October 11 and 12 at 9/8c

Subscriptions and single tickets are available here!

Then, check in each Monday following performances to see the episodes online.

If you like what you see, please consider a donation to keep us going and to see more!

More about the Show:

Gary and Felix McNamara are failures. Despite Felix’s get-rich-quick schemes, it seems that their Chicago recording studio is never going to reach the heights of success that the once-promising McNamara brothers always dreamed of. When Felix decides to use the studio to record “Song Poems” with the help of their assistant Janice and in-house musicians Butch and Marvin, there might be hope yet to save the studio. They just have to convince Lady, the overbearing trophy wife of their absentee landlord. Will this group of failures turn their fortunes around? Or is the studio doomed?

Oh, and by the way, The New Colony is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization so your donation is totally tax-deductible!
